PREFACE
   This code of the Village of North Pekin, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 1049, passed April 12, 2021. 
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions
of this code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular
provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
Sterling Codifiers
Cincinnati, Ohio

Listed ordinances have been passed, but they have not been incorporated into

the ordinances listed.
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Interpretations
1-1-5: Intent
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the Board of Trustees, this Village Code is hereby declared to
be and shall hereafter constitute the Official Village Code of the Village of
North Pekin. Any reference made to the number of any section contained herein
shall be understood to refer to the position of the same under its appropriate
chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause relating thereto,
as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to this Code by title
in any legal document. (1971 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this
State as the ordinances of the Village of general and permanent effect, except
the excluded ordinances enumerated in Section
1-2-1 of this Title. (1971 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this Code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute a
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this Code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this Code
within thirty (30) days from the date of its final passage. (1971 Code)
1-1-4: INTERPRETATIONS:
In the determination of the provisions of each section of this Code, the
following rules shall be observed:
   (A)   Intent To Defraud: Whenever an intent to defraud is required in order
to constitute an offense, it shall be sufficient if an intent appears to
defraud any person.
   (B)   Liability Of Employers And Agents: When the provisions of any section
of this Code prohibits the commission of an act, not only the person actually
doing the prohibited act or omitting the directed act, but also the employer
and all other persons concerned with or in aiding or abetting the said person
shall be guilty of the offense described and liable to the penalty set forth.
(1971 Code)
1-1-5: INTENT:
All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code
shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent of the Board of
Trustees may be fully carried out. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the Village passed prior to the adoption of this Code
are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being still in
force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to
the saving clauses contained in the following Section), from which are excluded
the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances;
appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries; franchise
ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
Village; and all special ordinances. (1971 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other
public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this Code or by virtue
of the preceding Section, excepting as this Code may contain provisions for
such matters, in which case this Code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (1971 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance,
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied
to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This Section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any action now
pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the Village herein
repealed and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this Code
shall be deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the same
provision; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the
Village under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this Code. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this Code importing the plural number is
used, in describing or referring to any matters, parties, or persons, any
single matter, party, or person shall be deemed to be included, although
distributive words may not have been used.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this Code by words
importing the singular number only, or the masculine gender, several matters,
parties, or persons and females as well as males and bodies corporate shall be
deemed to be included; provided, that these rules of construction shall not be
applied to any section of this Code which contains any express provision
excluding such construction or where the subject matter or content may be
repugnant thereto. (1971 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another.
CODE: Unless otherwise specifically stated, shall mean this Village Code.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the
Village of North Pekin" and shall be taken to mean the employee of the Village
performing the duties indicated.
FEE: A sum of money charged by the Village for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
FISCAL YEAR: The fiscal and Municipal year of the Village shall commence on the
first Monday in May of each year.
KNOWINGLY: Imports only a knowledge that the facts exist which brings the act
or omission within the provisions of this Code. It does not require any
knowledge of the unlawfulness of such act or omission.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense deemed a violation of the provisions of this Code
which is a lesser offense than a felony as defined by State law.
NEGLIGENT, NEGLECT, NEGLIGENCE, NEGLIGENTLY: Imports a want of such attention
to the nature of probable consequences of the act or omission as a prudent man
ordinarily bestows in acting in his own concern.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the Village; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a
hazard to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or
to the community.
OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this Code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the Village
of North Pekin", and shall be taken to mean the officer of the Village having
the title mentioned.
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: Applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of such
building or land.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation, joint stock association or
the State of Illinois or any subdivision thereof, and includes any trustee,
receiver, assignee, or personal representative thereof.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small quantities
direct to the consumer.
STREET: Includes alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public squares, public
places and sidewalks.
TENANT: Applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies the
whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The Village of North Pekin, County of Tazewell, State of Illinois.
WHOLESALER, WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be
understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in
quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WILFULLY: When applied to the intent with which an act is done or omitted,
implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or make the omission
referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law, or to injure
another, or to acquire an advantage.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in
the proper handwriting of such person, or in case he is unable to write, by his
proper mark. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947; amd. 1971 Code)
CHAPTER 4
PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: Penalty, General
1-4-2: License
1-4-3: Application
1-4-4: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: PENALTY, GENERAL:
   (A)   General Penalty Established: Whenever in this code or in any ordinance
of the village any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or
an offense, or whenever in such code or ordinance the doing of any act is
required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no
specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of
this code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifteen
dollars ($15.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
each offense. Each day any violation of any provision of this code or of any
ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   Payments:
      1.   Payments in settlement of those violations set forth in subsection
(C) of this section, or any other violation hereafter added, shall be made
within twenty one (21) days after the date that the citation was issued. Said
payment shall be considered made within twenty one (21) days if the payment is
actually received by the village treasurer's office within twenty one (21)
days. Payments shall be made by cash, certified check, cashier's check or money
order made payable to the village of North Pekin, and may be paid by mail or in
person at the village hall.
      2.   The corporation counsel shall have the authority to delay filing
with the court any citation charging a person with violation of the code in
order to allow that person an opportunity to settle the case prior to his or
her court appearance.
      3.   If the fine, as set forth in subsection (C) of this section is paid
within twenty one (21) days provided above, no complaint charging the person
with the particular violation shall be filed by the office of the corporation
counsel.
      4.   Upon the request of the violator, and at the election of corporation
counsel for the village, fines may be converted to hours of public service at
an hourly rate in accordance with federal minimum wage guidelines.
      5.   The fines for violation of the sections of this code are set forth
in subsection (C) of this section.
   (C)   Fines For Violations:

   (D)   Real Property Violations: In addition to any penalty assessed above,
the cost incurred by the village in abating any violation of village ordinances
relating to real property, together with an administrative fee, recording and
releasing of any lien, and any attorney fees, shall be recoverable from the
owner or person in control of the real estate, and shall constitute a lien
thereon.
   (E)   Vehicle Violations: In addition to any penalty assessed above, the
cost incurred by the village in abating any violation of village ordinances
relating to vehicles, together with an administrative fee, and any attorney
fees, shall be recoverable from the owner or person in control of the vehicle,
and shall constitute a lien thereon. (Ord. 969, 4-28-2014)
1-4-2: LICENSE:
When a person is convicted of a violation of any section of this code, any
license previously issued to him by the village may be revoked by the court or
by the board of trustees. (1971 Code)
1-4-3: APPLICATION:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where any
action which is of a continuing nature or declared to be unlawful, shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
upon each day such duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act
continues, unless otherwise specifically provided in this code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of this code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter
shall apply and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a breach or violation occurs or continues. (1971 Code)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 5
OFFICERS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Elective Officers
1-5-2: Appointive Officers
1-5-3: Oath Of Office
1-5-4: Bonds
1-5-5: Pro Tem Officers
1-5-6: Compensation
1-5-7: Special Policemen
1-5-8: Elective Officers As Policemen Or Firemen
1-5-1: ELECTIVE OFFICERS:
The electors of the Village shall elect a President of the Board of Trustees,
six (6) Trustees and a Village Clerk, who shall be elected and shall hold
office as provided by law 1 . (Ord. 323, 11-12-1979)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-5-1.
1-5-2: APPOINTIVE OFFICERS:
The President and Board of Trustees of the Village shall annually appoint the
following officers, which appointments shall be approved by the Board of
Trustees:
Building Inspector
Chairman of Planning and Zoning Commission
Chief of Police
Freedom of Information Act Officer
   Superintendent of Public Works
Village Attorney
Village Engineer
Village Treasurer
Zoning Enforcing Officer
each to hold their respective offices for the term of one year or until their
successors are appointed and qualify; provided, however, that their terms of
office shall not extend beyond the end of the Municipal year in which they were
appointed. (Ord. 1025, 3-11-2019)
1-5-3: OATH OF OFFICE:
All officers of the Village shall, before entering upon the duties of their
respective offices, take and subscribe to the oath prescribed by the Statutes
of the State, which oaths shall be filed in the Office of the Clerk. (Ord. 8,
8-6-1947)
1-5-4: BONDS:
All officers of the Village, whether elected or appointed, except the Trustees,
shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, execute a
bond with surety to be approved by the Board of Trustees, payable to the
Village in such penal sum as may be determined by resolution or ordinance of
the Board, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of their
respective offices, and the payment of all monies received by such officers
according to law and the provisions of this Code. Such bonds, when duly
executed and approved, shall be filed in the Office of the Clerk, except for
the bond of the Clerk which shall be filed with the Treasurer. (Ord. 8, 8-6-
1947)
1-5-5: PRO TEM OFFICERS:
When any officer of the Village shall be absent or is from any cause
incapacitated or unable to perform the duties of his office, the President and
Board of Trustees may appoint an officer pro tem to perform the duties of such
office and any person so appointed shall have the same powers and be clothed
with the same authority as the officer whose place he is appointed to
temporarily fill. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-5-6: COMPENSATION:
   (A)   Compensation: Compensation of elected or appointed officials to the
Village Board shall be an amount as is to be set by the Village Board from time
to time through an ordinance enacted by the Village Board, and which specifies
the same. (Ord. 845, 8-13-2007)
   (B)   General Or Special Meetings:
      1.   With respect to the President and Trustees, each shall be paid the
per meeting compensation for each general or special meeting of the Village
Board so attended. The President and the Trustees shall not receive
compensation for committee meetings unless said committee meeting is called as
a joint committee meeting of the Village Board. (Ord. 845, 8-13-2007; amd. Ord.
1001, 1-25-2016)
      2.   Compensation for the Village Clerk shall be per meeting of the
Village Board as defined in this section. (Ord. 1001, 1-25-2016)
   (C)   Definition: For the purpose of this section, the term "meeting" shall
be defined as a gathering of the Board of Trustees which is duly called and
attended pursuant to section
1-6-3 of this title; or any gathering of the Board of Trustees for the purpose
of conducting any hearing or meeting which may be required by local, State, or
Federal law, including, but not limited to, items such as public hearings or
preannexation agreements, and hearings on the use of revenue sharing funds.
   (D)   Quarterly Installments: The compensation to be paid to the Village
Clerk shall be paid in four (4) equal quarterly installments, to be paid at the
conclusion of each quarter. The President and Trustees shall each be paid on a
quarterly basis, at the end of each quarter in an amount equal to that earned
for all meetings of the Village Board attended during each quarter.
   (E)   Other Officers: Unless otherwise provided by the provisions of this
Code, the salaries of all other officers of the Village will be as set forth by
ordinance of the Village Board from time to time. (Ord. 845, 8-13-2007)
1-5-7: SPECIAL POLICEMEN:
The President may, on special occasions when in his judgment the public peace
and order of the Village shall so require, appoint such number of special
policemen as may be necessary and fix the time during which they shall serve.
Such special policemen shall possess the powers and exercise the duties of
regular policemen or constables within the Village limits; provided their
appointment when made shall be reported by the President at the next regular
meeting of the Village Board after such appointment, for approval; and the
Board shall fix their compensation at such sum as they may deem just and
proper. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-5-8: ELECTIVE OFFICERS AS POLICEMEN OR FIREMEN:
All elective officers of the Village, whether elected or appointed shall,
before entering upon or qualifying to enter upon the duties of their respective
offices, resign any position they may hold with the North Pekin Police
Department or with the North Pekin Fire Department. Any member of the North
Pekin Police Department or North Pekin Fire Department, who is elected or
appointed to an elective office of the Village, shall, before entering upon the
duties of his office, submit an affidavit to the Clerk in a form prescribed by
the Clerk, which affidavit shall confirm the resignation from the North Pekin
Police Department or the North Pekin Fire Department of the person elected or
appointed to an elective office. (Ord. 344, 4-27-1981)
CHAPTER 6
BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Election; Term
1-6-2: Oath; Bond
1-6-3: Meetings
1-6-4: Presiding Officer
1-6-5: Quorum
1-6-6: Committees
1-6-7: Order Of Business
1-6-8: Addressing Meetings
1-6-9: Suspension Of Rules
1-6-10: Robert's Rules Of Order
1-6-1: ELECTION; TERM:
The board of trustees of the village shall consist of six (6) members who shall
each be elected to office for a four (4) year term as provided by statute. Said
board of trustees shall be the legislative department of the village government
and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated to it by
statute 1 . Newly elected trustees shall be inaugurated at the first regular
meeting of the board of trustees in the month of May following their election.
(Ord. 718, 4-22-2002)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1.
1-6-2: OATH; BOND:
The members of the board of trustees shall subscribe to the oath as required by
section
1-5-3 of this title and shall secure a surety bond as required by section
1-5-4 of this title before entering upon the duties as trustees of the village.
(1971 Code)
1-6-3: MEETINGS:
The regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held on the second and
fourth Mondays of each month at the hour of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M., and no
notice of such regular meeting shall be required. (Ord. 187, 9-23-1968)
Special meetings of the board of trustees may be called by the president or any
three (3) trustees, by filing with the clerk a notice of such meeting in
writing, stating the time and place of such meeting and the object for which
said meeting is called; provided, that if all of the trustees and the president
are present at a special meeting, no notice of the meeting shall be necessary,
and such notice shall be deemed waived. The chief of police shall thereupon
deliver a copy of such notice to the president and each member of the board of
trustees at least twenty four (24) hours before the time of such meeting. (Ord.
8, 8-6-1947)
1-6-4: PRESIDING OFFICER:
The president of the board shall be the presiding officer of all regular and
special meetings of said board of trustees and at all times when the board
meets as a committee of the whole.
During the absence of, or disability of the president, the board may select one
of its number to act as president pro tem, who, while presiding, shall possess
all the powers of the president. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-6-5: QUORUM:
A majority of the trustees shall constitute a quorum to do business, but no
ordinance shall be passed except upon a favorable vote of a majority of the
elected members, as provided by statute. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-6-6: COMMITTEES:
The following shall be the standing committees of the board of trustees:
   Finance committee
   Liquor commission
   Public health and safety
   Street and alley committee
Special committees shall be created from time to time as may be directed by the
board.
All standing and special committees shall consist of three (3) members,
including the chairman unless the board directs otherwise. All committees shall
be appointed by the president. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-6-7: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The order of business of the Board of Trustees shall be as follows:
   (A)   Roll call.
   (B)   Reading of minutes of the last regular, intervening, adjourned and
special meetings.
   (C)   Correspondence.
   (D)   Reports of officers.
   (E)   Reports of standing committees.
   (F)   Reports of special committees.
   (G)   Reading of bills.
   (H)   Presentation of petitions.
   (I)   Reading of finances.
   (J)   Unfinished business.
   (K)   New business. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-6-8: ADDRESSING MEETINGS:
   (A)   Recognition By President: When two (2) members arise at the same time,
the President shall recognize one of them, but in all cases the one rising
first shall be recognized by the President. When one is recognized by the
President, all others shall resume their seats. No member shall speak more than
twice on the same subject without unanimous consent.
   (B)   Motion Seconded: No motion shall be entertained until seconded. When a
motion is made and seconded, it shall be reduced to writing, if requested by
the President or any member of the Board. No motion shall be debated until
slated by the President.
   (C)   Question Under Debate: When a question is under debate, no motion
shall be entertained except a motion to adjourn, to lay on the table, to
postpone indefinitely, to postpone to a certain time, to commit or to amend;
which several motions shall have precedence in order they are herein stated;
but a motion to adjourn shall always be in order except when taking a vote, and
motions to adjourn or to lay on the table shall not be debatable.
   (D)   Voting: If any member of the Board is present but refuses to vote, the
President shall count him as voting in the negative, and if such counting makes
a tie, then the President shall then cast the deciding vote. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
   (E)   Attendance, Participation And Voting By Electronic Means: A Trustee
may be authorized to attend, participate and/or vote by electronic means at any
Village meeting of the Village of North Pekin if said Trustee is unable to
physically attend the meeting if approved by a majority vote of the Corporate
Authorities physically present in each instance.
In order to allow a Trustee to attend, participate and vote by electronic means
at a Village meeting, a quorum of the members of the Village Authorities must
be physically present at said meeting.
In addition, the Trustee must notify the Clerk of the Village prior to the
meeting no later than forty eight (48) hours prior to the meeting. The Trustee
must advise the Village Clerk of the reason for his or her inability to
physically attend the Village meeting. The Village Clerk shall take all
reasonable measures to notify the Mayor and remaining Village Trustees of the
request and the reason for said request.
At the Village meeting, the members of the Village Board that are physically
present shall vote to either allow or disallow the Trustee to attend,
participate and/or vote by electronic means. (Ord. 982, 12-8-2014)
1-6-9: SUSPENSION OF RULES:
The rules of order, other than those prescribed by statute, may be suspended at
any time by the consent of a majority of the members present at any meeting.
(1971 Code)
1-6-10: ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER:
"Robert's Rules of Order" shall govern the deliberations of the Board of
Trustees except when in conflict with any of the foregoing provisions. (1971
Code)
CHAPTER 7
PRESIDENT
SECTION:
1-7-1: Election; Term
1-7-2: Duties
1-7-3: Bond; Oath
1-7-4: President Pro Tem
1-7-1: ELECTION; TERM:
The Village President shall be elected for a term of four (4) years, and he
shall be the President of the Board of Trustees as is provided by statute 1 .
(1971 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-5-1.
1-7-2: DUTIES:
   (A)   The President shall be the chief executive officer of the Village and
shall perform all duties that may be required of him by statute or ordinance.
He shall have supervision over all the executive officers of the Village and
shall have the power and authority to inspect all books and records kept by any
Village officer or employee at any reasonable time.
   (B)   The President shall preside at all meetings of the Board of Trustees
and shall sign all contracts and licenses legally issued.
   (C)   Whenever there is a question as to the respective duties and powers of
any appointed officer of the Village, this shall be settled by the President;
and he shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which is
to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform that
specific duty. (1971 Code)
1-7-3: BOND; OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the President shall give a bond
with sureties to be approved by the Board of Trustees conditioned upon the
faithful performance of his duties, in such sum as directed by the Board. He
shall take the oath of office required by Section
1-5-3 of this Title. (1971 Code)
1-7-4: PRESIDENT PRO TEM:
During a temporary absence or disability of the President, the Board of
Trustees shall elect one of its number to act as President Pro Tem, who during
the absence or disability of the President, shall perform the duties pertaining
to the office. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 8
CLERK
SECTION:
1-8-1: Election
1-8-2: Bond; Oath
1-8-3: Duties
1-8-1: ELECTION:
The Clerk shall be elected and serve for a four (4) year term and until his
successor is elected and qualified as is provided by statute, and shall receive
as compensation a sum to be fixed by the Board of Trustees from time to time by
resolution or ordinance. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-8-2: BOND; OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Clerk shall give a bond with
sureties to be approved by the President and Board of Trustees conditioned upon
the faithful performance of his duties, in such sum as directed by the Board.
He shall take the oath of office required by Section
1-5-3 of this Title. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-8-3: DUTIES:
The Clerk shall perform, among others, the following duties:
   (A)   He shall be custodian of the Village Seal and keep the same in his
office.
   (B)   He shall attend all meetings of the Board of Trustees, and keep a full
record of their proceedings in a book provided for that purpose.
   (C)   Copies of all papers filed in his office and transcripts from the
journal, and all other records and files of his office shall be furnished by
him, duly certified when required by the President and Board of Trustees.
   (D)   He shall file the originals of all ordinances in his office, and is
authorized and empowered to correct any errors in the numbering of any section
of any ordinance. He also may omit words inserted erroneously, or supply in
brackets words omitted by mistake in any ordinance.
   (E)   He shall superintend the printing or publication of all ordinances
requiring publication.
   (F)   He shall record in a book kept for that purpose all ordinances passed
by the President and Board of Trustees and at the foot of the record of each
ordinance he shall make a memorandum of the date of passage, approval and
publication thereof.
   (G)   The Clerk shall also perform all other duties which may be required of
him by statute or the provisions of this Code. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
CHAPTER 9
TREASURER
SECTION:
1-9-1: Appointment; Term
1-9-2: Bond; Oath
1-9-3: Duties
1-9-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM:
The Treasurer of the Village shall be appointed by the President and Board of
Trustees as provided by statute and shall serve for a term of one year or until
his successor is duly appointed and qualifies. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-9-2: BOND; OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Treasurer shall give a bond
with sureties to be approved by the President and Board of Trustees conditioned
upon the faithful performance of his duties in an amount of money that is not
less than three (3) times the latest Federal census population or any
subsequent census figure used for motor fuel tax purposes. He shall take and
subscribe to the oath of office required by Section
1-5-3 of this Title 1 . (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-8-1.
1-9-3: DUTIES:
The Treasurer shall perform the following duties and do and perform such other
duties as may be prescribed by the President and Board of Trustees from time to
time:
   (A)   He shall receive all monies coming into his hands as such Treasurer
and keep a correct account of the same.
   (B)   He shall keep a detailed account of each separate fund and with all
persons having accounts with the Village.
   (C)   He shall at the end of each month, and more often if so required by
the Board of Trustees, render an account showing the amount of money on hand,
the amount received since his last report, together with a statement of all
warrants paid by him, which warrants and all other vouchers held by him shall
be delivered with said report to the Clerk to be by him filed in his office.
   (D)   He shall annually between April 1 and April 10 of each year, make out
and file with the Clerk a full and detailed amount of all receipts and
expenditures during the preceding year, which shall be filed with said Clerk
and may be published in the official newspaper in the Village, if so ordered by
the President and Board of Trustees.
   (E)   He shall not honor any warrant on the Treasury unless it is signed by
the President of the Village and countersigned by the Clerk, with the Corporate
Seal affixed thereto, and unless said warrant shows the particular fund upon
which drawn and to whom payable. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
CHAPTER 10
ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-10-1: Creation Of Office; Appointment
1-10-2: Suits And Actions
1-10-3: Judgments
1-10-4: Advice
1-10-5: Special Assessments
1-10-6: Ordinances And Documents
1-10-7: Retaining Law Firm To Act As Village Attorney
1-10-8: Conflict Of Interest
1-10-1: CREATION OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of village attorney, an executive office of
the village. The attorney shall be appointed by the president by and with the
advice and consent of the board of trustees. (1971 Code)
1-10-2: SUITS AND ACTIONS:
The attorney shall prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions at law or
equity to which the village may be a party, or in which it may be interested,
or which may be brought against, or by, any officer of the village on behalf of
the village, or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the village.
(1971 Code)
1-10-3: JUDGMENTS:
It shall be the duty of the attorney to see to the full enforcement of all
judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor of the village, and of all
similar interlocutory orders. (1971 Code)
1-10-4: ADVICE:
The attorney shall be the legal advisor of the village, and shall render advice
on all legal questions affecting the village, whenever requested to do so by
any village official. Upon request by the president or by the board of
trustees, he shall reduce any such opinion to writing. (1971 Code)
1-10-5: SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS:
It shall be the duty of the attorney to see to the completion of all special
assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings. (1971 Code)
1-10-6: ORDINANCES AND DOCUMENTS:
It shall be the duty of the attorney to draft or supervise the phraseology of
any contract, lease or other documents or instruments, to which the village may
be a party; and upon request of the board to draft ordinances covering any
subjects within the power of the village. (1971 Code)
1-10-7: RETAINING LAW FIRM TO ACT AS VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
The board of trustees is hereby authorized to retain a law firm, be it a
partnership, corporation or professional association, to act as its legal
advisor, to represent the village in litigation except where the board directs
otherwise, to draft all contracts, ordinances and other documents needed by the
village, to advise the village officers and employees on matters pertaining to
their duties, and to render such other legal services as may be required by the
board. The board of trustees is further authorized to appoint one or more
members of said law firm to act in the capacity of village attorney and to
carry out the above mentioned duties. (1971 Code)
1-10-8: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
The president of the village of North Pekin, by and with the advice and consent
of the board of trustees, is hereby authorized to appoint a special attorney
for the prosecution, defense or other conduct of village business where an
actual conflict of interest, and/or appearance of conflict of interest may
exist. The intent of this section is that the village attorney shall not
represent both the village and the opposite party in any litigation,
negotiations or development within the village and to provide for a method of
retaining special legal counsel in the event of a conflict of interest or
appearance of conflict of interest. (Ord. 760, 9-22-2003)
CHAPTER 11
SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
SECTION:
1-11-1: Office Created
1-11-2: Waterworks And Sewer
1-11-3: Streets
1-11-4: Buildings
1-11-5: Other Physical Property
1-11-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of Superintendent of Public Works who shall
be appointed by the President and the Board of Trustees. (1971 Code)
1-11-2: WATERWORKS AND SEWER:
The Superintendent of Public Works shall have charge of the water and sewer
systems. He shall be responsible for the proper operation of the same; and he
is hereby authorized to see to the enforcement of all laws and provisions
pertaining thereto. (1971 Code)
1-11-3: STREETS:
The Superintendent of Public Works shall have charge of the public streets and
supervision over the maintenance and repair of the same. (1971 Code)
1-11-4: BUILDINGS:
The Superintendent of Public Works shall have charge of the maintenance and
repair of all Village-owned buildings. (1971 Code)
1-11-5: OTHER PHYSICAL PROPERTY:
All physical property of the Village which is not assigned by the Board to some
other officer or employee shall be in the care and custody of the
Superintendent of Public Works. (1971 Code)

CHAPTER 13
SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS
SECTION:
1-13-1: Office Created; Appointment
1-13-2: Bond; Oath
1-13-3: Duties
1-13-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Superintendent of Streets for the
Village; this office shall be held by the Superintendent of Public Works unless
a separate appointment to such office is made by the Village Board. (Ord. 8, 8-
6-1947)
1-13-2: BOND; OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Superintendent of Streets
shall give a bond with sureties to be approved by the President and Board of
Trustees conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties, in such sum
as directed by the Board. He shall also take and subscribe to the oath of
office required by Section
1-5-3 of this Title. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-13-3: DUTIES:
The Superintendent of Streets shall perform the following:
   (A)   He shall have charge of all the improvements upon the streets and
alleys of the Village, and shall make all necessary repairs of sidewalks,
culverts, crossings, and bridges in the Village. He shall without any delay
cause all breaks in any bridge, culvert, or crossing to be repaired.
   (B)   He shall as early in the spring of each year as is practicable, cause
all the streets, alleys and other public places in the Village to be cleaned
and kept in good condition and repair.
   (C)   When authorized by the President and Board of Trustees, he may employ
such laborers and teams of trucks and equipment as are needed to work upon the
streets, at such prices as may be determined by the Board.
   (D)   He shall be subject to the Street and Alley Committee, and with their
consent may purchase the necessary tools and implements for the use in his
work.
   (E)   He shall keep an accurate account of all expenditures made under his
direction, and keep a list of all tools and implements, material and other
property of the Village and shall be held accountable therefor.
   (F)   At the expiration of his term of office, he shall deliver to his
successor in office all property of the Village in his hands, taking a receipt
therefor, which shall be filed with the Clerk, who shall credit him with same
and charge his successor therefor.
   (G)   He shall cause all tools and implements of the Village to be marked or
branded with the letters "V. of N.P.".
   (H)   He shall report each month to the Board giving a statement of all
expenditures made under his supervision during the preceding month and state
what work has been done and the character of the same. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)

work as the board may request, and shall make such suggestions to the board of
trustees, regarding the same, as shall in his judgment seem best and proper.
(1971 Code)

of the board of trustees, is hereby authorized to appoint a special engineer
for any conduct of village business where an actual conflict of interest, and/
or appearance of conflict of interest may exist. The intent of this section is
that the village engineer shall not represent both the village and the opposite
party in any litigation, negotiations or development within the village and to
provide for a method of retaining a special engineer in the event of a conflict
of interest or appearance of conflict of interest. (Ord. 759, 9-22-2003)

CHAPTER 18
CLAIMS AND ORDERS
SECTION:
1-18-1: Statement Of Claims
1-18-2: Orders On Treasury
1-18-3: Checks And Drafts
1-18-1: STATEMENT OF CLAIMS:
All persons having claims against the Village shall file with the Clerk an
itemized statement of the same, and if for labor on the public streets or
public works, such statement shall show the character of the work done, and the
time employed in doing such work, and be subscribed and sworn to by the
claimant. No claim against the Village will be paid unless presented as herein
provided, and passed upon by the Finance Committee of the Board of Trustees and
allowed by the President and said Board. The Clerk shall furnish claimants with
the proper blanks on which to make out their claims, and when requested, shall
swear the claimant to the claim without charge. This Section shall not be
construed to apply to salaries of the officers and employees of the Village or
to contracts. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-18-2: ORDERS ON TREASURY:
All orders issued by authority of the Board of Trustees shall have endorsed on
the stub of issue the amount, to whom issued, and fund upon which drawn. All
such orders shall be signed by the President and countersigned by the Clerk.
They shall be numbered consecutively, commencing with the number one at the
beginning of each Municipal year. The Clerk shall deliver all orders to the
Village Treasury. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
1-18-3: CHECKS AND DRAFTS:
There shall be a service charge in an amount to be fixed from time to time by
resolution by the Village Board of Trustees for all and any checks or drafts
written to the Village or any of its departments or subdivisions which are
returned unpaid for any reason. If said check or draft is in payment for
services or any license or permit, then such services shall be considered
unpaid and any licenses or permits revoked until the amount of said check or
draft, plus the above referenced service charge, is paid in full. (Ord. 626,
10-28-1996)
