CHAPTER 20
VILLAGE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS
SECTION:
1-20-1: Prohibited Political Activities
1-20-2: Gift Ban
1-20-3: Gift Ban Exceptions
1-20-4: Gift Ban; Disposition Of Gifts
1-20-5: Penalties
1-20-1: PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES:
   (A)   Village employees shall not intentionally perform any prohibited
political activity during any compensated time (other than vacation, personal,
or compensatory time off). Village employees shall not intentionally
misappropriate any village property or resources by engaging in any prohibited
political activity for the benefit of any campaign for elective office or any
political organization.
   (B)   At no time shall any executive or legislative branch constitutional
officer or any official, director, supervisor, or village employee
intentionally misappropriate the services of any village employee by requiring
that village employee to perform any prohibited political activity: 1) as part
of that employee's village duties; 2) as a condition of village employment; or
3) during any time off that is compensated by the village (such as vacation,
personal, or compensatory time off).
   (C)   A village employee shall not be required at any time to participate in
any prohibited political activity in consideration for that village employee
being awarded any additional compensation or employee benefit, in the form of a
salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or
otherwise.
   (D)   A village employee shall not be awarded any additional compensation or
employee benefit, in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time
off, continued employment, or otherwise, in consideration for the village
employee's participation in any prohibited political activity.
   (E)   Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are otherwise
appropriate for a village employee to engage in as a part of his or her
official village employment duties or activities that are undertaken by a
village employee on a voluntary basis as permitted by law.
   (F)   No person either: 1) in a position that is subject to recognized merit
principles of public employment; or 2) in a position the salary for which is
paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal
standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant in
aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of village employment or tenure
solely because he or she is a member or an officer of a political committee, of
a political party, or of a political organization or club. (Ord. 767, 5-24-
2004)
1-20-2: GIFT BAN:
Except as otherwise provided herein, no officer, member, or village employee
shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any prohibited source or in
violation of any federal, state or village statute, rule, regulation or
ordinance. This ban applies to and includes the spouse of and immediate family
living with the officer, member or village employee. No prohibited source shall
intentionally offer or make a gift that violates this section. (Ord. 767, 5-24-
2004)
1-20-3: GIFT BAN EXCEPTIONS:
The gift ban restriction contained in section
1-20-2 of this chapter, does not apply to the following:
   (A)   Opportunities, benefits and services that are available on the same
conditions as for the general public.
   (B)   Anything for which the officer, member or village employee pays the
market value.
   (C)   Any: 1) contribution that is lawfully made under the election code or
under this act; or 2) activities associated with a fundraising event in support
of a political organization or candidate.
   (D)   Educational materials and missions.
   (E)   Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss village business.
   (F)   A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the individual
as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, great aunt,
great uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, grandmother,
grandfather, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law,
daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother,
stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half sister, and
including the father, mother, grandfather or grandmother of the individual's
spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee.
   (G)   Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal
friendship unless the member, officer or employee has reason to believe that,
under the circumstances, the gift was provided because of the official position
or employment of the member, officer, or employee and not because of the
personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of
personal friendship, the member, officer or employee shall consider the
circumstances under which the gift was offered, including, but not limited to:
      1.   The history of the relationship between the individual giving the
gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts
between those individuals;
      2.   Whether to the actual knowledge of the member, officer or employee
the individual who gave the gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax
deduction or business reimbursement for the gift; and
      3.   Whether to the actual knowledge of the member, officer or employee,
the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar
gifts to other members, officers or employees.
   (H)   Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy five dollars ($75.00) per
person in value on a single calendar day; provided, that the food or
refreshments are: 1) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or
prepared; or 2) catered. For the purposes of this subsection, "catered" means
food or refreshments that are purchased ready to eat and delivered by any
means.
   (I)   Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation and other benefits
resulting from the outside business or employment activities (or outside
activities that are not connected to the duties of the officer, member or
employee as an office holder or employee) of the officer, member or employee,
or the spouse of the officer, member or employee, if the benefits have not been
offered or enhanced because of the official position or employment of the
member, officer or employee, and are customarily provided to others in similar
circumstances.
   (J)   Intragovernmental and intergovernmental gifts. For the purpose of this
subsection, "intragovernmental gift" means any gift given to a member, officer
or employee of the village of North Pekin from another member, officer or
employee of the village of North Pekin; and "intergovernmental gift" means any
gift given to a member, officer or employee of the village of North Pekin from
a member, officer or employee of another municipality, state agency, federal
agency or of any governmental entity.
   (K)   Bequests, inheritances and other transfers at death.
   (L)   Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any calendar
year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars
($100.00).
Each of the exceptions listed in this section is mutually exclusive and
independent of one another. (Ord. 767, 5-24-2004)
1-20-4: GIFT BAN; DISPOSITION OF GIFTS:
A member, officer or employee does not violate this chapter if the member,
officer or employee promptly takes reasonable action to return the prohibited
gift to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to its value to an
appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under section 501(c)(3)
of the internal revenue code of 1986, as now or hereafter amended, renumbered
or succeeded. (Ord. 767, 5-24-2004)
1-20-5: PENALTIES:
   (A)   A person is guilty of a violation if that person intentionally
violates any provision of this chapter.
   (B)   A person who intentionally violates any provision of this chapter may
be subject to a fine of up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 767,
5-24-2004)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
BOARD OF HEALTH
SECTION:
2-1-1: Creation; Appointment
2-1-2: Meetings
2-1-3: General Duties
2-1-4: Expenses Of Board
2-1-5: Compensation
2-1-6: Right To Enter Premises
2-1-7: Duty Of Chief Of Police
2-1-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the Board of Health for the Village which shall consist
of three (3) members to be appointed by the President, by and with the consent
of the Board of Trustees. Said members shall serve for a term of one year or
until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
2-1-2: MEETINGS:
The Board of Health shall meet as often as may be necessary and shall so meet
at the call of the chairman of the Board. Said members shall choose from their
number a clerk who shall keep a record of their proceedings, and the Chief of
Police is hereby required to attend said meetings and shall serve all receipts
and notices issued by the order of the Board. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
2-1-3: GENERAL DUTIES:
The Board of Health shall exercise general supervision over the public health
of the Village and shall make diligent examinations into all matters affecting
the same. They have full power and authority to take all steps and use all
necessary measures to promote the cleanliness of the Village. Said Board shall
have the following duties with regard to the above:
   (A)   They shall cause all nuisances to be abated or removed on public or
private property, which they deem prejudicial or obnoxious to the public
health.
   (B)   They shall make such sanitary regulations deemed necessary or
expedient to prevent the introduction or spreading of any contagious, malignant
or pestilential disease.
   (C)   They shall require that every practicing physician shall report to the
President of the Board or to some member of the Board of Trustees every case of
smallpox, scarlet fever, measles, cholera or any other infectious or contagious
disease which may assume a malignant character, which he may be called upon to
attend, and that such report be made within twelve (12) hours after the
physician shall have examined and discovered the character of such disease.
The orders of the Board of Health shall be certified by the Clerk of the
Village to the Village President who shall cause the same to be executed by the
Chief of Police or some other Village officer. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
2-1-4: EXPENSES OF BOARD:
All bills or accounts for expenses incurred by the Board of Health shall be
presented to the Board of Trustees and if found correct shall be paid by said
Board of Trustees. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
2-1-5: COMPENSATION:
Each member of the Board of Health shall receive a reasonable compensation for
attendance on the Board, or other necessary services. The Clerk shall keep a
correct account of the attendance of each member and report the same to the
Board of Trustees, who shall order the amount found to be due each member to be
paid from the Treasury of the Village. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
2-1-6: RIGHT TO ENTER PREMISES:
The members of the Board of Health are hereby empowered at all times of the day
to enter into any grocery, meat shop, hotel, boarding house, factory, stable or
other building within the Village and to examine the cellars, vaults, sinks,
sewers, and drains belonging thereto; and shall also enter all lots or premises
and cause all stagnant pools of water to be drained and all ash heaps to be
cleaned and kept in an unoffensive condition, and cause all dead animals or
other unwholesome thing to be buried or removed beyond the Village limits.
(Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
2-1-7: DUTY OF CHIEF OF POLICE:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to remove or abate all nuisances or
offensive matter which has been condemned by the Board of Health, and when so
ordered by them, to notify the owners of the premises on which such nuisance or
offensive matter is situated to remove or abate the same, and if the owner
fails or neglects to so remove or abate said nuisance, the Chief of Police
shall cause the same to be done and the expense thereof shall be a lien on the
property thereof. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
CHAPTER 2
WATERWORKS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-2-1: Creation; Appointment
2-2-2: Duties
2-2-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby established within the Village a Waterworks Commission to
consist of three (3) members to be appointed by the President with the advice
and consent of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 43, 1-5-1955)
2-2-2: DUTIES:
The Waterworks Commission shall have the powers and duties enumerated herein:
   (A)   They shall have full power to handle all business transactions of the
waterworks system, including providing a proper system of bookkeeping, and
books and records showing all charges made for water service, all revenue
collected and expenditures made, and shall determine the salary of the
Superintendent and other employees of the waterworks system, and shall employ
and discharge said Superintendent and all employees, all subject however, to
the approval of the Board of Trustees as a whole.
   (B)   They shall have the power and authority to make any obligations in
connection with necessary matters of the waterworks system up to the amount of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for any one matter or item without obtaining the
previous approval of the Board, but the same shall be reported to the said
Board at its next regular meeting after said obligation has been entered into;
provided, however, that in case of any emergency repairs to the said waterworks
system that requires immediate attention, the nature of which would not warrant
the matter being delayed until a meeting of the Board, the Waterworks
Commission shall, in that event, have the right to have said repairs made
immediately even though the same may exceed the five hundred dollar ($500.00)
limitation stated above. The Waterworks Commission shall submit a report of the
repairs to the Board at its next meeting.
   (C)   The Waterworks Commission shall pass on all bills and each month shall
present to the Clerk a statement of all of the bills that have been approved by
the Commission; whereupon, the bills shall then be passed upon by the Board as
a whole the same as all other bills and shall be paid in like manner.
   (D)   The Superintendent of Waterworks shall work under the direction of the
Waterworks Commission and shall be subject to the orders and directions of said
Commission; and he shall collect all water revenue and deposit the same in the
Water Fund of the Village in the bank so designated by the Board. Immediately
after having made each deposit, the Superintendent shall give the Treasurer a
duplicate of such deposit slip and furnish the Waterworks Commission with a
complete itemized statement setting forth in detail the receipts by him, which
constituted the total amount of the deposit.
   (E)   The Superintendent of Waterworks shall meet with the Commission and
shall keep a record of all business of the Commission which shall be transacted
at each meeting, which record shall be signed by the chairman and secretary of
the Commission and a copy of the same shall be filed with the Clerk. (Ord. 43,
1-5-1955)
   (F)   In all cases of petty cash payments, a voucher shall be signed by the
officer or employee of the Village when a petty cash payment is made to him,
and said voucher shall then be presented to and filed with the office of the
Clerk of the Village, and upon the payment of said petty cash by said officer
or employee, he shall obtain a signed receipt from the person to whom said
payment is made and said signed receipt shall also be presented to and filed
with the office of the Clerk. (4-21-64)
   (G)   No interest shall be paid to water users on any deposits made by any
user, which deposit or deposits may be required by virtue of the provisions of
this Code; and provided, further, that when any subscriber who has made a
deposit ceases to use said water service and has paid all of his water bill,
said deposit shall be immediately paid to him by the Superintendent of
Waterworks or any balance due him, and said Superintendent shall have the right
to make the refund without any previous action by the Waterworks Commission.
(Ord. 43, 1-5-1955)
CHAPTER 3
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
2-3-1: Creation; Appointment
2-3-2: General Duties
2-3-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby established a Board of Local Improvements for the Village which
shall consist of the President of the Village, who shall be the president of
the Board of Local Improvements, and all of the members of the Board of
Trustees of the Village. The President with the approval of the members of the
Board of Local Improvements, shall appoint a member of said Board to serve as
clerk. (Ord. 56, 3-7-1956; amd. 1971 Code)
2-3-2: GENERAL DUTIES:
The Board of Local Improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties
assigned to it by statute or provisions of this Code, and shall have the power
of employing the services of an engineer for any local improvement originated
by it. (Ord. 56, 3-7-1956; amd. 1971 Code)
CHAPTER 4
BOARD OF APPEALS
(Rep. by Ord. 220, 5-8-1972)
CHAPTER 5
PLANNING COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-5-1: Organization
2-5-2: Powers And Jurisdiction
2-5-3: Appeals
2-5-4: Appeals To Court
2-5-1: ORGANIZATION:
There is hereby created a planning commission for the village which shall at
all times be under the jurisdiction of the board of trustees.
The planning commission shall consist of no more than eleven (11) members who
shall be appointed by the president and confirmed by the board on an annual
basis for a term of one year. All members of the commission shall be
compensated as determined from time to time by the village board by resolution
or ordinance.
   (A)   Chairman Of Planning Commission: There is hereby created the office of
chairman of planning commission, who shall be appointed by the president by and
with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The chairman shall serve
for a term of one year. (Ord. 924, 1-9-2012)
2-5-2: POWERS AND JURISDICTION:
   (A)   No plans, plats or replats of land within the corporate limits of the
village or in contiguous territory outside of the distant not more than one and
one-half (11/2) miles from such limits shall be entitled to record or shall be
valid unless the subdivision shown thereon shall provide for streets, alleys
and public grounds in conformity with the recommendation of the commission. In
cases of the disapproval by the commission of any such plot, the reason for
such disapproval shall be submitted to the board of trustees, which may
overrule such disapproval by majority vote of its members. The failure of the
commission to disapprove any properly submitted plat within a period of sixty
(60) days from the date of its filing shall be deemed acceptance of such plat.
   (B)   Before approval by the board of trustees of the issuance of any
special permit for the uses described in the zoning title of this code, the
planning commission shall be given thirty (30) days in which to make such
report to the board of trustees; provided however, that if no report is
received from the commission within thirty (30) days, it shall be assumed that
approval of the application has been given by the commission.
   (C)   The planning commission shall hear and decide appeals from any order,
requirement, decision or determination made by the zoning enforcing officer. It
shall also hear and decide all matters referred to it or upon which it is
required to pass under the provisions of this code. The commission may reverse
or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify or amend the order, requirement,
decision or determination appealed from to the extent and in the manner that
the commission may decide to be fitting and proper in the premises, and to that
end the commission shall also have all the powers of the officer from whom the
appeal is taken.
When a property owner shows that a strict application of the terms of the
zoning provisions of this code relating to the use, construction or alteration
of buildings or structures or to the use of land, imposes upon him practical
difficulties or particular hardships, then the commission may make such
variations of the strict application of said terms as are in harmony with its
general purpose and intent when the commission is satisfied, under the evidence
heard before it, that the granting of such variations will not merely serve as
a convenience to the applicant, but is necessary to alleviate some demonstrable
hardship so great as to warrant a variation in the following instances:
      1.   To permit the extension of a district where the boundary line of a
district divides a lot in single ownership as shown of record;
      2.   To permit the reconstruction of a nonconforming building which has
been destroyed or damaged to an extent of more than fifty percent (50%) of its
value, by fire or act of God, or the public enemy, where the board shall find
some compelling public necessity requiring a continuance of the nonconforming
use, and in no case shall such a permit be issued if its primary function is to
continue a monopoly;
      3.   To make a variance, by reason of an exceptional situation,
surroundings, or conditions of a specific piece of property of record, or by
reason of exceptional topographical conditions the strict application of any
provisions of the zoning title of this code would result in peculiar and
exceptional practical difficulties or particular hardships upon the owner of
such property and amount to a practical confiscation of property, as
distinguished from a mere inconvenience to such owner, provided such relief can
be granted without substantial detriment to the public good and without
substantially impairing the general intent and purpose of the comprehensive
plan as established by the provisions of this code;
      4.   To interpret the provisions of the zoning title of this code where
the street layout actually on the ground varies from the street layout as shown
on the district map fixing the several districts;
      5.   To waive the parking requirements in the business or industrial
districts whenever the character or use of the building is such as to make
unnecessary the full provisions of parking facilities or where such regulations
would impose an unreasonable hardship upon the use of the lot, as contrasted
with merely granting an advantage or convenience;
      6.   To permit a building to be erected, reconstructed, altered or
enlarged so that the building lines will extend beyond the distance specified
in the zoning provisions into side yards or into front yards, provided that
such variances may not be granted: a) unless there is a building in the block
which extends beyond the distance from the front street line specified in the
zoning provisions, in which case the building line may be permitted to extend
as near to the front street line as such nonconforming building; or b) unless
the lot is irregular in shape, topography or size; or c) unless the street line
of the lot is directly opposite the street line of a lot which is irregular in
shape, topography or size;
      7.   To permit in any district such modification of the requirements of
the zoning regulations of this code as said commission may deem necessary to
secure an appropriate development of a lot where adjacent to such lot on two
(2) or more sides there are buildings that do not conform to the regulations of
the district.
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to give or grant to the commission
the power or authority to alter or change the zoning regulations or the
district map; such power and authority being reserved to the board of trustees.
The commission may recommend to the village board such conditions and
restrictions upon the use of the premises benefited by a variation, except in
the specified case, after an application for a permit has been made to the
village and after duly advertised public hearing held by the commission as
prescribed by statute. The notice of hearing shall contain the address or
location of the property for which the variation or either ruling of the
commission is sought, as well as a brief description of the nature of the
appeal. In order to partially defray the expenses of the public hearing
involving variances, the applicant shall pay a fee in an amount to be
determined from time to time by the village board by resolution or ordinance.
(Ord. 924, 1-9-2012)
2-5-3: APPEALS:
Appeals to the commission may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any
officer, department, board or bureau of the village. Such appeal shall be taken
within twenty (20) days from the date of the action appealed from, by filing
with the zoning enforcing officer and the commission a notice of appeal,
specifying the grounds thereof. The zoning enforcing officer shall forthwith
transmit to the commission all papers constituting the record upon which the
action appealed from was taken. An appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance
of the action appealed from unless the zoning enforcing officer certifies to
the commission, after the notice of appeals has been filed with him, that by
reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would in his opinion, cause
imminent peril to life or property. The commission shall fix a reasonable time
for hearing of the appeal and give due notice thereof to the parties and decide
the same within a reasonable time. The commission may reverse or affirm, wholly
or partly, or may modify the use, requirements, decision or determination as,
in its opinion, ought to be made in the premises. (Ord. 924, 1-9-2012)
2-5-4: APPEALS TO COURT:
All final administrative decisions of the planning commission rendered under
the terms of this chapter shall be subject to judicial review pursuant to the
administrative review act of the state of Illinois and all amendments and rules
adopted pursuant thereto. (Ord. 924, 1-9-2012)
CHAPTER 6
CIVIL DEFENSE
SECTION:
2-6-1: Organization Created
2-6-2: Members
2-6-3: Director
2-6-4: Duties
2-6-5: Mutual Aid Agreements
2-6-6: Mobile Support Team; Compensation
2-6-7: Cooperate With State
2-6-8: Compensation For Time Spent
2-6-9: Purchases
2-6-10: Oath
2-6-11: Office Of Organization
2-6-12: Appropriation
2-6-1: ORGANIZATION CREATED:
In accordance with "The Illinois Civil Defense Act of 1951", as amended, there
is hereby created the North Pekin Civil Defense Organization as a part of this
Village to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury, loss or damage
resulting from disaster, whether caused by enemy action, sabotage, storm or
other natural causes. (1971 Code)
2-6-2: MEMBERS:
The North Pekin Civil Defense Organization shall consist of a director, one
assistant director and such department heads as may be appointed by the
director, as prescribed by said Illinois Civil Defense Act. (1971 Code)
2-6-3: DIRECTOR:
The director of the North Pekin Civil Defense Organization shall be appointed
by the President with the consent of the Board of Trustees without regard to
political affiliations, and he shall serve until removed by the Board of
Trustees. The director shall have direct responsibility for the organization,
administration, training, and operation of said organization, subject to the
direction and control of the Village President. In the event of the director's
absence, resignation, death or inability to serve, the assistant director shall
act in that capacity. (1971 Code)
2-6-4: DUTIES:
The North Pekin Civil Defense Organization shall perform such functions within
the Village as shall be prescribed by the State Civil Defense Plan. In
addition, it shall perform such orders, rules and regulations as may be
promulgated by the Governor or State Director, and such duties outside the
corporate limits of the Village as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid
agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality, or quasi-
municipality as may be entered into pursuant to said Illinois Civil Defense
Act, as amended. (1971 Code)
2-6-5: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS:
The director shall negotiate mutual aid agreements with other municipal
corporations or political subdivisions of the State, but no such agreement
shall be effective until it has been confirmed by the Board of Trustees and by
the State Director of Civil Defense. (1971 Code)
2-6-6: MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM; COMPENSATION:
All or any members of the Civil Defense Organization may be designated as
members of a mobile support team created by the State Director of Civil Defense
as provided by law. The leader of the mobile support team may be designated by
the local director. Any member of a mobile support team is a Municipal employee
or officer while serving on call to duty as such by the Governor, or the State
Civil Defense Director, and shall receive the compensation and have the powers,
duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such
member who is not a paid officer or employee of the Village, while so serving,
shall receive from the State reasonable compensation as provided by law. (1971
Code)
2-6-7: COOPERATE WITH STATE:
In the event that the Governor declares that a civil defense emergency exists
due to actual or threatened enemy attack upon the United States, or the
occurrence within this State of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage
or other hostile action, or from natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the
local Civil Defense Organization to cooperate fully with the State office of
Civil Defense and with the Governor in the exercise of the emergency powers
provided by law. (1971 Code)
2-6-8: COMPENSATION FOR TIME SPENT:
Members of the North Pekin Civil Defense Organization who are officers or
employees of the Village, if called for training by the State Director, shall
receive for the time spent in training the compensation incidental to their
employment; members who are not Village employees shall receive such
compensation as may be established by the Village authorities. (1971 Code)
2-6-9: PURCHASES:
The Board of Trustees shall cooperate in the procurement of necessary supplies
or equipment as may be necessary to effectively carry out the purposes of civil
defense. On recommendation of the director, the Board of Trustees may authorize
any purchase or contracts necessary or advisable to place the Village in a
position to effectively carry out its duty to combat any disaster resulting
from the explosion of any nuclear bomb or missile; to provide emergency
assistance to victims of such disaster, or from natural disaster; to protect
property and lives, and the public peace, health and safety. (1971 Code)
2-6-10: OATH:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the North Pekin Civil
Defense Organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the
following oath, which oath shall be filed with the director:
I,               , residing at               in the Village of North Pekin,
Illinois, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear
true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the
Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and
facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and
domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or
purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties
upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do
not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or
organization that advocates the overthrow of the Government of the United
States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I am
affiliated with the North Pekin Civil Defense Organization I will not advocate
nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the Government of the United States or of this State by force or
violence.
(1971 Code)
2-6-11: OFFICE OF ORGANIZATION:
The Village President is authorized to designate suitable space in the Village
to be provided by the Village for the North Pekin Civil Defense Organization,
as its office and for storage of supplies and equipment. (1971 Code)
2-6-12: APPROPRIATION:
The Board of Trustees may make an appropriation for civil defense purposes in
the manner provided by law. (1971 Code)
TITLE 3
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
LICENSES
SECTION:
3-1-1: Applications
3-1-2: Forms
3-1-3: Signatures
3-1-4: Investigations
3-1-5: Fees
3-1-6: Termination Of Licenses
3-1-7: Building And Premises
3-1-8: Transfer; Change Of Location
3-1-9: Frontage Consents
3-1-10: Nuisances
3-1-11: Inspections
3-1-12: Revocation
3-1-13: Notice Of Revocation; Request For Hearing; Suspension Of Revocation
3-1-14: Posting License
3-1-15: Waiver Of Fees For Disabled Veterans
3-1-1: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for all licenses and permits required by provision of this Code
shall be made in writing to the Clerk in the absence of provision to the
contrary. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or
license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee
to be paid; and each application shall contain such additional information as
may be needed for the proper guidance of the Village officials in the issuing
of the permit or license applied for 1 . (1971 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1.
3-1-2: FORMS:
Forms for all licenses and permits and applications therefor, shall be prepared
and kept on file by the Clerk. (1971 Code)
3-1-3: SIGNATURES:
Each license or permit issued shall bear the signature of the President and the
Clerk of the Village in the absence of any provision to the contrary. (1971
Code)
3-1-4: INVESTIGATIONS:
Upon the receipt of an application for a license or permit where the provision
of this Code necessitates an inspection or investigation before the issuance of
such permit or license, the Clerk shall refer such application to the proper
officer for making such investigation within forty eight (48) hours of the time
of such receipt. The officer charged with the duty of making the investigation
or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten
(10) days after receiving the application or a copy thereof. (1971 Code)
3-1-5: FEES:
In the absence of provision to the contrary, all fees and charges for licenses
or permits shall be paid in advance at the time application therefor is made to
the Clerk.
When a business is commenced after the expiration of a part of the license
year, an annual license for the balance of the year will be issued for a
proportionate part of the annual fee. (1971 Code)
3-1-6: TERMINATION OF LICENSES:
All annual licenses and permits shall terminate on the last day of the fiscal
year of the Village in which they are issued, where no provision to the
contrary is made. And each daily license shall terminate at twelve o'clock (12:
00) midnight of the day for which the license or permit is granted. (1971 Code)
3-1-7: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
No licenses shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no permit for
anything, or act, if the premises and building to be used for the purpose do
not fully comply with the requirements of the Village. No such license or
permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of any
act which would involve a violation of the zoning provisions of this Code.
(1971 Code)
3-1-8: TRANSFER; CHANGE OF LOCATION:
Licenses issued may be transferred by the original licensee provided that
written notice thereof is given to the Clerk within ten (10) days before the
transfer is made, but no more than one transfer of any license shall be made
within the license year; provided that it shall be unlawful to transfer any
peddler's or itinerant merchant's license or permit, and any attempted transfer
of such a license or permit shall have no effect.
The location of any licensed business or occupation, or of any permitted act,
may be changed, provided ten (10) days' notice in writing thereof is given to
the Clerk, in the absence of any provision to the contrary; provided that the
building, zoning and frontage consent requirements of the provisions of this
Code are complied with. (1971 Code)
3-1-9: FRONTAGE CONSENTS:
Whenever the consent of adjoining or neighboring owners is required as a
prerequisite of the conduct of any business or occupation, or the location of
any establishment, such consent must be obtained by securing the necessary
signatures to a written consent petition. Such petition shall be filed with the
Clerk when signed.
Consent once given and filed shall not be renewed for the continuous conduct of
the same business, whether by the same proprietor or not.
It shall be unlawful to forge any name to such a petition or to falsely
represent that the names thereon have been properly placed thereon if such is
not the fact.
Each consent when filed shall be accompanied by the affidavit of the person
securing the signatures that each signature appearing thereon was properly
secured and written on; and that the petition contains the necessary number of
signatures required by ordinance.
The frontage consent requirements contained in this Code shall not be construed
as amending or changing any zoning provision of the Village; and no such
provision shall be construed as permitting the erection of a structure or
building, or the conduct of a business, or the commission of any act in any
location where such structure, building, business or act is or are prohibited
by any zoning provision of the Village. (1971 Code)
3-1-10: NUISANCES:
No business, licensed or not, shall be so conducted or operated as to amount to
a nuisance in fact. (1971 Code)
3-1-11: INSPECTIONS:
Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the
operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by
ordinance, or are reasonably necessary to secure compliance with any ordinance
provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the
licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit
thereto for the purpose of making such inspection at any reasonable time that
admission is requested, any authorized officer or employee of the Village.
In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the President of the
Board may revoke the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed
business in the Village who refuses to permit any such officer or employee, who
is authorized, to make such inspection, or who interferes with such officer or
employee while in the performance of his duty in making such inspection.
Provided that no license shall be revoked for such cause unless written demand
is made upon the licensee or person in charge of the premises, in the name of
the Village, stating that such inspection is desired and the time it is sought
to make the inspection. (1971 Code)
3-1-12: REVOCATION:
Any license or permit for a limited time may be revoked by the President at any
time during the life of such license or permit for any violation by the
licensee or permittee of the provisions relating to the license or permit, the
subject matter of the license or permit or to the premises occupied; such
revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed. (1971 Code)
3-1-13: NOTICE OF REVOCATION; REQUEST FOR HEARING; SUSPENSION OF REVOCATION:
   (A)   Unless any provision of this Code provides to the contrary, no
revocation or suspension of any license or permit issued hereunder shall be
deemed effective until notice thereof has been served personally upon or mailed
to the named licensee or permittee at the address specified in the application
for the said license or permit.
   (B)   If, within five (5) days of the date of notice of the revocation or
suspension of any license or permit, the named licensee or permittee submits to
the Village Clerk in writing a request for a hearing concerning such revocation
or suspension, said revocation or suspension shall be suspended until such time
as the Board of Trustees shall grant the licensee or permittee a special
hearing.
   (C)   If the Board of Trustees after such hearing affirms the revocation or
suspension of said license or permit, the same shall become immediately
effective; if the Board of Trustees by a majority vote overrules the revocation
or suspension, the same shall be deemed null and void. (1971 Code)
3-1-14: POSTING LICENSE:
It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the
Village to keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises used
for such business at all times. (1971 Code)
3-1-15: WAIVER OF FEES FOR DISABLED VETERANS:
The Board of Trustees shall have the power to waive the fees for vending
licenses required under any provisions of this Code, upon application for such
license by disabled veterans who are residents of the Village; provided,
however, that such waiver is recommended by the Veteran's Relief Officer of
Tazewell County. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 2
AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
3-2-1: Application Of Provisions
3-2-2: License Required
3-2-3: Street Shows
3-2-4: Athletic Exhibitions
3-2-5: Order; Crowding
3-2-6: Inspections
3-2-7: Smoking
3-2-8: Signs
3-2-9: Exit Lights
3-2-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this Chapter, except as to licensing and fees, shall apply to
all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the Village,
whether specifically licensed in another chapter hereof. (1971 Code)
3-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the
public and for admission to which a fee is charged without having first secured
a license therefor, except that motion pictures and theatricals are
specifically exempted from licensing. Provided, however, that the provisions of
this Section shall not be held to apply to those amusements which are
specifically licensed by any other section or chapter in this Code.
Application for such licenses shall be made to the Clerk, and shall comply with
the general provisions relating to such application. For such licenses the
following fees shall be paid:
 
Carnivals                        $75.00 per week
Circus or hippodrome             25.00 per day
Exhibitions of inanimate objects 25.00 per day
Menageries                       5.00 per day
Rodeos                           25.00 per day
Shooting gallery                 5.00 per day
 
(1971 Code)
3-2-3: STREET SHOWS:
No permit shall be granted for any carnival, circus, exhibition show or other
amusement to be given on any public street or sidewalk or in such a place that
the only main accommodation for the public or the audience will be in a public
place, except on order of the Board of Trustees. (1971 Code)
3-2-4: ATHLETIC EXHIBITIONS:
It shall be unlawful to conduct, operate or exhibit any race between persons,
animals or vehicles, or any baseball games, boxing or wrestling matches or any
other athletic contest or exhibition for admission to which a fee is charged
without having procured a license therefor, except such events as may be
conducted by duly accredited schools.
The proprietor of such exhibition shall submit to the Clerk a statement
verified under oath of the gross receipts of each such game, contest or race,
within one week after such exhibition. At the same time such proprietor or
person exhibiting or operating such exhibition shall pay to the Clerk a sum
equal to three percent (3%) of the gross receipts.
Sufficient members of the Police Department shall be admitted free of charge to
all such exhibitions for the purpose of preserving and maintaining order; and
the Clerk may post a person or any number of persons at the box office of each
such performance; and may examine all the books pertaining to such performance
showing or tending to show the gross receipts. (1971 Code)
3-2-5: ORDER; CROWDING:
The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly and quiet at
all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such amusement,
show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience.
It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any amusement
or show so as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other risks.
(1971 Code)
3-2-6: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to see that every exhibition,
amusement, theatrical or other public show or amusement is inspected by a
member of the Police Department and to ensure conformity with the provisions
concerning such amusements. (1971 Code)
3-2-7: SMOKING:
It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe
beneath the stage or in a dressing room of any building used as an assembly
hall with seating accommodations for more than one hundred (100) persons or in
which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other entertainments are
offered, operated, presented or exhibited. (1971 Code)
3-2-8: SIGNS:
It shall be the duty of the owner of such premises or the occupant in charge to
provide and place printed signs on which the words "No Smoking" shall appear in
letters at least four inches (4") high, in conspicuous places, at least two (2)
such signs being upon the stage or in the wings thereof and in each dressing
room. (1971 Code)
3-2-9: EXIT LIGHTS:
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge of any building or hall
used as an assembly hall with accommodations for one hundred (100) persons or
more in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures and other entertainments
is offered, operated or presented to provide and place a sign, on which the
word "Exit" shall appear in letters at least six inches (6") high, over every
door or other opening from such hall to every means of egress therefrom and a
light shall be provided with a red globe and placed at or over such sign, which
light shall be kept burning during the entire period that the hall is open to
the public and until the audience has left the hall. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 3
COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES
SECTION:
3-3-1: Definitions
3-3-2: License Required
3-3-3: Operator's License Fee
3-3-4: Proprietor's License Fee
3-3-5: Application For License; Nontransferable
3-3-6: Increasing Number Of Devices
3-3-7: Evidence Of Ownership To Be Filed With Clerk
3-3-8: Coin Operated Gambling Devices
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any amusement machine or device operated by
means of the insertion of a coin, token or similar object, for the purpose of
amusement or skill and for the playing of which a fee is charged. The term does
not include vending machines in which are not incorporated gaming or amusement
features, nor does the term include any coin operated mechanical musical
devices.
OPERATOR: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association who sets up
for operation by another or leases or distributes for the purpose of operation
by another, any device as herein defined, whether such setting up for
operation, leasing or distributing be for a fixed charge or rental, or on the
basis of a division of the income derived from such device, or otherwise.
PROPRIETOR: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association or club
who, as the owner, lessee or proprietor has under his or its control any
establishment, place or premises in or at which such device is placed or kept
for use or play, or on exhibition for the purpose of use or play. (1971 Code)
3-3-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of an "operator" or
"proprietor" of coin operated amusement devices as the terms are herein
defined, without first having obtained the proper license therefor. (1971 Code)
3-3-3: OPERATOR'S LICENSE FEE:
The license fee for each operator shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). All
operator's license fees shall be payable annually in advance, provided that
where application is made after the expiration of any portion of any license
year a license may be issued for the remainder thereof upon payment of a
proportionate part of the annual fee. In no case shall any portion of said
license fee be refunded to the licensee. (1971 Code)
3-3-4: PROPRIETOR'S LICENSE FEE:
The license fee for each "proprietor", as herein defined, shall be ten dollars
($10.00) per year for each device used or played, or exhibited for use or play.
All proprietor's license fees shall be payable in advance; provided, that where
application is made after the expiration of any portion of any license year a
license may be issued for the remainder thereof upon payment of a proportionate
part of the annual fee. In no case shall any portion of said license fee be
repaid to the licensee. (1971 Code)
3-3-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; NONTRANSFERABLE:
Application for license hereunder shall be filed in writing with the village
clerk, on a form to be provided by the village, and shall specify:
   (A)   The name and address of the applicant, and if a firm, corporation,
partnership or association, the principal officers thereof and their addresses.
   (B)   The address of the premises where the licensed device or devices are
to be operated, together with the character of the business as carried on at
such place.
   (C)   The trade name and general description of the device or devices to be
licensed, the name of the manufacturer and the serial number and, if the
applicant is a proprietor, the number of devices to be licensed.
   (D)   The name and address of the operator of the device or devices, if
other than the proprietor.
The proper license fee shall accompany such application. Application for
license hereunder shall be first referred by the village clerk to the president
and board of trustees who shall make or cause to be made such investigation as
they deem necessary. If the application is approved by the president and board
of trustees, the license shall be issued by the clerk, and the clerk shall
remit the fee to the village treasurer. If the license is denied the fee shall
be returned to the applicant. All licenses under this chapter shall expire on
April 30 following their issuance. The license shall be posted in a conspicuous
place in the establishment of the licensee. Such license shall be nonassignable
and nontransferable, and in the case of a proprietor shall apply only to the
premises for which such license is issued. (1971 Code)
3-3-6: INCREASING NUMBER OF DEVICES:
In case a proprietor licensed under the provisions of this chapter desires,
after the expiration of any portion of any license year, to increase the number
of devices to be used or played, or exhibited for use or play in his
establishment, he shall surrender his license to the village clerk who shall
issue a new license showing the number of devices licensed thereunder, upon
payment of the proper license fee therefor. (1971 Code)
3-3-7: EVIDENCE OF OWNERSHIP TO BE FILED WITH CLERK:
Any proprietor who owns such device or devices at the time this chapter becomes
effective shall file with the village clerk evidence of such ownership prior to
the issuance of a license; and any proprietor purchasing a device or devices
after the effective date of this chapter shall file with the village clerk
evidence of ownership thereof before exhibiting or placing said device or
devices for use or play. (1971 Code)
3-3-8: COIN OPERATED GAMBLING DEVICES:
It shall be unlawful for any person or establishment to keep or use in any
place within the village any coin operated mechanical device for which there
has been purchased a coin operated gambling device special tax stamp, issued by
the internal revenue authorities of the United States government, except as
specifically authorized by chapter 22 of this title. (Ord. 945, 10-8-2012)

(1971 Code)

CHAPTER 6
PUBLIC DANCES AND DANCE HALLS
SECTION:
3-6-1: License Required
3-6-2: Applications; Investigations
3-6-3: Fee
3-6-4: Duty Of Sponsor To Maintain Order
3-6-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance or dance hall in the
Village without having first obtained a license therefor, as is herein
provided. (1971 Code)
3-6-2: APPLICATIONS; INVESTIGATIONS:
Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions
of this Code relating to licenses, and shall specify the location of the
proposed dance or dances and the person or organization sponsoring the same.
No such license shall be issued to a person who is not a person of good moral
character, nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the
Village by a person of good moral character.
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to make or cause to be made an
investigation into the character of each applicant and report the result of
such investigation to the Clerk. (1971 Code)
3-6-3: FEE:
Except for any business which pays a special fee under subsection
3-9-3(F) of this Title, the annual fee to operate a public dance hall shall be
four hundred dollars ($400.00). The fee for public dances, given for public
benefit, shall be one dollar ($1.00), providing the sponsors furnish at their
expense a regular sworn police officer who shall remain in charge during the
time the dance is in progress, and except that if the dance is to be held in
the Village building and rent for its use has been paid, no other fee shall be
charged for a license. (1971 Code)
3-6-4: DUTY OF SPONSOR TO MAINTAIN ORDER:
It shall be the responsibility of the operator of any public dance hall or the
sponsors of any public dance to maintain order and to prevent such dance from
becoming a public nuisance. No license shall issue for a period of one year to
any operator, sponsor or sponsoring group who fails to fulfill the above
mentioned responsibility. (1971 Code)

CHAPTER 9
LIQUOR
SECTION:
3-9-1: Title
3-9-2: Definitions
3-9-3: Licenses; Fees
3-9-4: Special Alcoholic Liquor Licenses
3-9-5: Application For License
3-9-6: Bond
3-9-7: Issuance Of License
3-9-8: Renewals
3-9-9: Posting License
3-9-10: Liquor Control Commissioner
3-9-11: Liquor Control Commission Regulations
3-9-12: Frontage Consents (Rep. by Ord. 402, 12-12-1983)
3-9-13: Closing Hours
3-9-14: Business License Required
3-9-15: Obstructions Prohibited
3-9-16: Sales To Minors, Intoxicated Persons, Etc., Prohibited
3-9-17: Revocation Of License
3-9-18: Club Licensees Prohibited From Advertising That They Are Open To The
Public
3-9-19: Special Club Licenses In Connection With Bingo
3-9-20: Special New Year's Eve Liquor License
3-9-21: Employees Regulated
3-9-22: Food Sales Of Establishment, Percentage Of
3-9-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the NORTH PEKIN LIQUOR CONTROL
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid or solid,
patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and capable of
being consumed as a beverage by a human being 1 .
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR BUSINESS: The conducting of any establishment or place of
business in which alcoholic beverages as herein defined are bartered, sold,
offered for sale, exchanged or given away, either for profit or otherwise.
BEER: A beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or
concoction of barley, or other grain, malt and hops in water, and includes,
among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like 2 .
CLUB: A corporation organized under the laws of this state, not for pecuniary
profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or
consumption of alcoholic liquors, kept, used and maintained by its members
through the payment of annual dues, and owning, hiring or leasing a building or
space in a building, of such extent and character as may be suitable and
adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation of its
members and their guests and provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and
dining room space and equipment and maintaining a sufficient number of servants
and employees for cooking, preparing and serving food and meals for its members
and their guests; provided, that such club files with the local liquor control
commissioner at the time of its application for a liquor license, two (2)
copies of a list of names and residences of its members, and similarly files
within ten (10) days of the election of any additional member his name and
address; and provided further, that its affairs and management are conducted by
a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the
members at their annual meeting, and that no member or any officer, agent, or
employee of the club is paid, or directly or indirectly receives, in the form
of salary or other compensation any profits from the distribution or sale of
alcoholic liquor to the club or the members of the club or its guests
introduced by members beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed and
voted at any annual meeting by the members or by its board of directors or
other governing body out of the general revenue of the club 3 .
DISTRIBUTOR: Any person, other than a manufacturer licensed under the
provisions of the Illinois Liquor Control Act, who is engaged in this State or
in the Village in purchasing, storing, possessing or warehousing any alcoholic
liquors for resale or reselling at wholesale, whether within or without this
State 4 .
DRAMSHOP: Any establishment catering to the general public, whose principal
business is the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
LIQUOR STORE: Any establishment selling alcoholic beverages which are not to be
consumed on the premises. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947; amd. Ord. 72, 8-13-1957; Ord., 5-
19-1964)
 
Notes
1 1. 235 ILCS 5/1-3.05.
2 1. 235 ILCS 5/1-3.04.
3 2. 235 ILCS 5/1-3.24.
4 3. 235 ILCS 5/1-3.15.
3-9-3: LICENSES; FEES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an alcoholic beverage business
either as a dramshop or as a liquor store, or in any other manner in any stand,
place, room, building, enclosure or suite of rooms within the Village, unless
he shall have first secured a license to do so and has paid the Local Liquor
Control Commission the fee for such license as hereinafter set forth; provided,
that no alcoholic beverage business shall be conducted other than upon the
ground or street level floor of any building.
The license fee for the operation of a dramshop shall be classified according
to the hours that the same remains open for business as set forth in section
3-9-13 of this chapter, and shall be designated as Class A and Class B dramshop
licenses. Said fees shall be as follows:
   (A)   The license fee for a Class A dramshop license shall be the sum of
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a period of twelve (12) months
payable in advance.
   (B)   The license fee for a Class B dramshop license shall be the sum of
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a period of twelve (12) months
payable in advance.
   (C)   The operation of a club shall require a Class C dramshop license and
the fee for same shall be the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a period
of twelve (12) months payable in advance.
   (D)   The operation of a liquor store shall require a Class D liquor
license, enabling the establishment to sell at retail for off premises
consumption of beer, wine and other alcoholic beverages. The fee for a Class D
license shall be the sum of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a period
of twelve (12) months payable in advance.
   (E)   The operation of a liquor store shall require a Class E liquor
license, enabling the establishment to sell at retail for off premises
consumption of beer and wine only. The fee for a Class E license shall be the
sum of six hundred dollars ($600.00) for a period of twelve (12) months payable
in advance.
   (F)   The license fee for all classes of liquor licenses, except a club
license, shall be increased to the sum of one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00) for a period of twelve (12) months when there is dancing or paid or
professional entertainment in or upon any tavern or place of business within
the Village where a dramshop or liquor license is required; provided, however,
that this provision shall not apply to private dinners or parties held in any
tavern or such place of business even though there is a professional or paid
entertainment or dancing in connection with said private dinners or parties.
No portion of any license fee shall be refunded for any period, or portion of
any period in which the licensee shall be prohibited from operating under such
license.
No more than a total of ten (10) licenses for the operation of an alcoholic
liquor business, regardless of the classification of such licenses, may be
issued by the Local Liquor Control Commission, whether outstanding or in force
at any one time. In the event that the authorized number of licenses has been
issued, any application for a liquor license may be summarily denied by the
Local Liquor Control Commission without a hearing.
The holder of any license for the operation of an alcoholic liquor business may
renew his license prior to the expiration thereof provided that he is then
qualified to receive a license and provided further that the privilege of
renewal shall not be construed as a vested right which shall, in any case,
prevent the Village Board from decreasing the number of licenses authorized to
be issued within the Village.
Upon denial by the Local Liquor Control Commission of an application for a
license under the provisions of this chapter, it shall be necessary for any
applicant whose application has been denied to reapply for a license in order
to be eligible for the issuance of a license at any subsequent time; provided,
however, that such reapplication is not necessary if the action of the Local
Liquor Control Commission in so denying the application is reversed by final
order of either the State Liquor Control Commission or a court of review.
Among qualified applicants for an available license, priority shall be given to
those pending applications in the order in which they are filed with the Local
Liquor Control Commission. (Ord. 998, 5-23-2016)
3-9-4: SPECIAL ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR LICENSES:
The President and Board of Trustees shall, in their discretion, have the right
and authority to issue a special license for a period of not more than three
(3) days to any lodge or organization for the sale of alcoholic liquor, when
said sale is in connection with any function sponsored by said lodge or
organization for the purpose of raising funds for said lodge or organization,
but no such license shall be issued to any individual or group of individuals
in connection with raising funds for said individual or group of individuals
personally, but merely for the benefit of said lodge or organization.
A license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per day or twenty five dollars ($25.00)
for three (3) days shall be paid by the holder of the special license, to be
paid at the time of the issuance of said license.
Before such a license shall be issued, the licensee shall furnish a bond in the
sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to be approved by the President of the
Board, said President being the Liquor Control Commissioner of the Village,
which bond shall provide that the licensee and all of his agents, employees or
guests will not violate any laws of the State nor violate any Federal laws nor
violate any provisions of this Code, and will save and keep harmless the
Village from any and all liability in connection with the sale of alcoholic
liquor.
The licensee is hereby required to carry dramshop insurance in connection with
any and all liabilities under the Dramshop Act of the State, in an amount of
sufficient protection under said Act.
In the event that during the tenure of this license the Liquor Control
Commissioner has just and reasonable grounds to believe that the law in
connection with the sale of alcoholic liquor under special license is being
violated or the licensee is not complying with the provisions of this section,
said Commissioner shall have the right and shall revoke said license. (Ord., 5-
19-1964; amd. Ord. 338, 5-12-1980)
3-9-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring a license under the provisions of this chapter shall file
an application with the Liquor Control Commissioner or with the Liquor Control
Commission, as the case may be, and shall accompany such application with the
proper license fee. Such application must be sworn to and contain the following
information:
   (A)   The name and address of the applicant, and that he is a resident of
the Village;
   (B)   That he is a citizen of the United States;
   (C)   His place of birth, and if he is a naturalized citizen, the time and
place of naturalization;
   (D)   That he has never been convicted of a felony under Federal or State
law;
   (E)   The location where he proposes to sell alcoholic liquors;
   (F)   That the proposed location is not within one hundred feet (100') of
any church, school, hospital, undertaking establishment or mortuary;
   (G)   That the applicant is not disqualified to receive a license by reason
of any provision or qualification contained in the Illinois Liquor Control Act;
   (H)   Whether said application is for the operation of a dramshop, liquor
store or a distributor; and
   (I)   That the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state, or
the provisions of this code in the conduct of his place of business.
In case of a partnership, the information required by this section shall be
furnished as to each partner, and in the case of a club, association or
corporation, as to the principal officers of such club, association or
corporation. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-6: BOND:
Each person desiring a license to operate a dramshop or liquor store shall be
required to show that he is of good moral character, and shall also execute a
penal bond in form and with security satisfactory to the liquor control
commission, conditioned upon the faithful observance of the provisions of the
Illinois liquor control act and of the provisions of this chapter, relating to
alcoholic liquors. Such bond shall be in the sum of five hundred dollars
($500.00) and shall, upon approval by the liquor control commission, be filed
in the office of the clerk. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-7: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
All applications for licenses under the provisions of this chapter shall be
presented to the liquor control commissioner or any member of the liquor
control commission. Said application shall be investigated by the liquor
control commission, and the commission may, in its discretion, thereafter
approve or reject the application. Upon the approval of such application and
the giving of the proper bond and the license fee having been paid, the liquor
control commission may order and direct the clerk to issue a license to such
applicant, which license must also be signed by the liquor control
commissioner. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-8: RENEWALS:
All applications for renewal licenses must be filed with the liquor control
commissioner or any member of the liquor control commission at least ten (10)
days prior to the date of expiration of said license.
No license shall be renewed if a complaint has been received by the liquor
control commissioner as to the manner in which the applicant for such renewal
has carried on the business authorized by such license, until a hearing has
been had upon such complaint before the liquor control commission. Such hearing
shall be held within thirty (30) days from and after the filing of the written
complaint or protest with the liquor control commissioner or any member of the
liquor control commission. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-9: POSTING LICENSE:
Every person licensed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall
immediately post and keep posted while in force in a conspicuous place on the
premises the license so issued. Whenever such license shall be lost or
destroyed, a duplicate in lieu thereof shall be ordered and issued by the
liquor control commission. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-10: LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
The president of the board of trustees is hereby appointed and designated as
the local liquor control commissioner, and he may appoint a person or persons,
not exceeding two (2) in number, to assist him in the exercise of the powers
and in the performance of the duties of his office. Such person or persons so
appointed shall, with the president, constitute the local liquor control
commission. The local liquor control commission shall have the power:
   (A)   To grant and revoke for cause all licenses issued under the provisions
of this chapter.
   (B)   To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any
time upon any premises licensed under the provisions of this chapter to
determine whether any of the provisions of this chapter or of the Illinois
liquor control act are being violated.
   (C)   To receive complaints from any citizen of the village that any of the
provisions of this chapter have been or are being violated and to act upon such
complaints.
   (D)   To receive all license fees provided for herein, and to pay the same
forthwith to the treasurer. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
   (E)   In any appeal taken by any person or entity from any action or
inaction taken by the local liquor control commissioner of the village, in
accordance with section 7-9 of the liquor control act of 1934, as amended 1 ,
such appeal shall be limited to a review of the official record of the
proceedings of such liquor control commissioner, and in the event of any such
appeal, a certified official record of the proceedings taken and prepared by a
certified court reporter or certified shorthand reporter shall be filed by the
local liquor control commissioner within five (5) days after notice of filing
of any such appeal, if the appellant licensee pays for the cost of the
transcript. Upon any such appeal, the state commission shall review the
propriety of the order or action of the local liquor control commissioner and
shall consider the following questions:
      1.   Whether the local liquor control commissioner has proceeded in the
manner provided by law.
      2.   Whether the order is supported by the findings.
      3.   Whether the findings are supported by substantial evidence in light
of the whole record.
The only evidence which may be considered in such a review shall be the
evidence found in the certified official record of the proceedings of the local
liquor control commissioner and no new or additional evidence shall be admitted
or considered. (Ord. 549, 8-26-1991)
 
Notes
1 1. 43 ILCS 5/7-9.
3-9-11: LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSION REGULATIONS:
The liquor control commission shall not issue a license to any of the
following:
   (A)   A person who is not a resident of the village.
   (B)   A person who is not of good moral character and reputation.
   (C)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   (D)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the
United States or the state of Illinois.
   (E)   A person who has been convicted of any crime or misdemeanor involving
matters of indecency or immorality.
   (F)   A person who for any reason is not eligible or cannot qualify for a
state retailer's license under the Illinois liquor control act.
   (G)   Any public official residing in the village. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-12: FRONTAGE CONSENTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 402, 12-12-1983)
3-9-13: CLOSING HOURS:
The following shall govern the hours during which premises holding licenses
under the provisions of this chapter shall be closed:
   (A)   No class A dramshop shall serve liquor between the hours of one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., of any weekday; and on Sundays
class A dramshops are hereby given authority to remain open for business
between the hours of twelve thirty o'clock (12:30) P.M. until the following one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. All customers of class A dramshops shall vacate the
premises not later than one-half (1/2) hour after closing.
   (B)   No class B dramshop or liquor store shall remain open between the
hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any weekday;
and on Sundays, class B dramshops and liquor stores are hereby given authority
to remain open for business until the hour of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and
between twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight.
   (C)   No class C dramshop shall serve liquor between the hours of one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any weekday; and on Sundays
class C dramshops are hereby given authority to remain open for business
between the hours of twelve thirty o'clock (12:30) P.M. until the following one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. All customers of class C dramshops shall vacate the
premises not later than one-half (1/2) hour after closing.
   (D)   Class D license holders shall not have any closing hours for the sale
of packaged alcoholic beverages.
   (E)   No class E license holder shall sell or offer to sell beer or wine
between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any
weekday; and on Sundays, class E license holders are hereby given authority to
sell or offer for sale beer and wine until the hour of one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
and between twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight.
   (F)   No class F dramshop shall serve liquor between the hours of one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., of any weekday; and on Sundays
class F dramshops are hereby given authority to remain open for business
between the hours of twelve thirty o'clock (12:30) P.M. until the following one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. All customers of class F dramshops shall vacate the
premises not later than one-half (1/2) hour after closing. (Ord. 959, 12-9-
2013)
3-9-14: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall sell, keep for sale or offer for sale any alcoholic beverage
within the village, unless he shall have first obtained an alcoholic beverage
license as herein provided. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-15: OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED:
In premises upon which the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the
premises is licensed, other than a restaurant, hotel or club, no screen, blind,
curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the windows or upon
the doors, or inside such premises, which shall prevent a clear view into the
interior of such premises from the street or sidewalk at all times. Said
premises must be so located that there shall be a full view of the entire
interior of such premises from the street or sidewalk. All rooms where
alcoholic liquors are sold for consumption on the premises shall be
continuously lighted during business hours by natural or artificial white light
so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible. The
liquor control commission may, if it so desires, require any applicant to file
with his application for license, plans, drawings or photographs showing the
clearance of the view as herein required. (Ord. 1, 6-30-1947)
3-9-16: SALES TO MINORS, INTOXICATED PERSONS, ETC., PROHIBITED:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer, associate,
member, representative, agent or employee of said licensee to sell, give, or
deliver any alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty one (21)
years, or to any intoxicated person, or to any person known by him to be a
habitual drunkard, spendthrift, insane, mentally ill, mentally deficient or in
need of mental treatment. (Ord. 327, 12-10-1979)
3-9-17: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The liquor control commissioner or the liquor control commission may levy a
fine in any amount authorized by the state of Illinois plus all costs incurred
by any violation and may suspend or revoke any license issued under the
provisions of this chapter for any one or more of the following reasons:
   (A)   Violation of any of the laws of the state, including the Illinois
liquor control act or any of the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   The wilful making of any false statement as to a material fact in the
application for a license.
   (C)   Permitting any disorderly conduct or immoral practices upon the
premises where the licensee is licensed to conduct an alcoholic liquor
business. (Ord. 698, 2-26-2001)
3-9-18: CLUB LICENSEES PROHIBITED FROM ADVERTISING THAT THEY ARE OPEN TO THE
PUBLIC:
It shall be unlawful for the holder of a club license as defined in this
chapter to advertise or hold themselves out as being open to the public at all
times, except:
   (A)   Those times when a club licensee has been granted a special beer
license pursuant to section
3-9-4 of this chapter.
   (B)   Those times when a club licensee has been granted a special club
license in connection with the playing of bingo pursuant to section
3-9-19 of this chapter. (Ord. 303, 5-8-1978)
3-9-19: SPECIAL CLUB LICENSES IN CONNECTION WITH BINGO:
Any liquor licensee possessing a valid bingo license issued by the state, and a
valid class C club license issued by the village, may apply for a special club
license in connection with bingo. Holders of special club licenses in
connection with bingo shall be governed by all of the applicable provisions of
this chapter with respect to club liquor licensees except as expressly modified
by the provisions contained below:
   (A)   Each liquor license holder who seeks a special club license in
connection with bingo shall apply to the liquor control commissioner. The
application shall include the name of the licensee, the establishment where the
bingo playing is to take place and the reason why permission to serve alcoholic
beverages is sought. It shall be within the sole discretion of the liquor
control commissioner to approve, renew or revoke any license issued under this
section.
   (B)   A license fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for three (3) months
shall be payable at the time of the issuance of said license. In order for a
special license under this section to remain valid, a fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) must be paid in advance, every three (3) months thereafter.
   (C)   Holders of special licenses obtained under this section are hereby
authorized to:
      1.   Open the club to the general public one night per week for the
specific purpose of playing bingo.
      2.   Serve between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. any alcoholic beverage allowed under their club license to
members of the general public who come to the club for the express purpose of
playing bingo.
      3.   Advertise to the public that bingo playing will take place at the
club on the one designated night per week but shall not advertise to the
general public the availability or the consumption of alcoholic beverages on
the premises. (Ord. 303, 5-8-1978)
      4.   Advertise to the public that bingo will take place at the club on
the Saturday afternoon after Thanksgiving between the hours of one o'clock (1:
00) P.M. and four o'clock (4:00) P.M. but shall not advertise to the general
public the availability or the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the
premises. (Ord. 400, 11-14-1983)
   (D)   The liquor control commissioner may, on special application made by
any organization having a bingo license, issue a special permit for conducting
bingo at its designated premises and on other days not exceeding seven (7)
consecutive days. No more than two (2) such special permits may be issued in
one year to any one organization. Such permits shall be prominently displayed
at the site of the bingo games. (Ord. 407, 2-27-1984)
3-9-20: SPECIAL NEW YEAR'S EVE LIQUOR LICENSE:
   (A)   Upon application and payment of the special license fee in the manner
hereinafter set forth, the village clerk shall issue a "special New Year's Eve
liquor license".
   (B)   A special New Year's Eve liquor license shall be available only to
