beings or other domestic animals. However, prior to the destruction of the dog,
control of the dog must be transferred to the administrator pursuant to
subsection (D)2 of this section.
      4.   Any vicious dog which has previously been impounded for not properly
being confined or for running at large in violation of subsection (C)1, (C)2 or
(C)3 of this section, or which has previously bitten or attacked a human being
or other domestic animal without provocation, shall be ordered destroyed in an
expeditious and humane manner upon any subsequent violations of those
subsections or upon any subsequent unprovoked attack or bite.
      5.   Any dog which attacks a human being, except for dogs listed as
exceptions to the definition of "vicious dog" in section
6-4-1-1 of this chapter, which results in severe injury shall automatically be
destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner.
   (E)   Redemption Of Impounded Vicious Dog: An owner of a vicious dog holding
a license pursuant to subsection (B) of this section may redeem an impounded
vicious dog if the vicious dog has been impounded pursuant to subsection (D) of
this section and the vicious dog has not caused severe injury to a person,
subject to the following conditions:
      1.   Proof of a valid license issued by the village under subsection (B)
of this section; and
      2.   Payment of the cost of keeping the vicious dog during the period of
impoundment.
   (F)   Sale Or Transfer Of Ownership Prohibited: No person shall sell,
barter, offer to breed or in any other way dispose of a vicious dog to any
person within the village unless a recipient person resides permanently in the
same household and on the same premises as the registered owner of such vicious
dog; provided, that the registered owner of a vicious dog may sell or otherwise
dispose of a vicious dog or the offspring of such vicious dog to persons who do
not reside within the village, provided they give written notice to the person
who will be receiving the vicious dog that such dog has been deemed a vicious
dog under this section.
   (G)   Animals Born Of Vicious Dogs: All offspring born of vicious dogs
registered within the village must be removed from the village within eight (8)
weeks of the birth of such animal.
   (H)   Reporting Requirements Of License: Any person holding a license
pursuant to subsection (B) of this section shall report the incidence of any of
the following events:
      1.   The sale, barter, exchange, gift or death of any vicious dog shall
be reported within forty eight (48) hours.
      2.   The escape from confinement of any vicious dog shall be reported
upon discovery of the escape.
      3.   The biting or nipping of any person or animal by a vicious dog shall
be reported upon occurrence.
      4.   The birth of any offspring of a vicious dog shall be reported within
forty eight (48) hours of the birth of the offspring.
      5.   The permanent removal of any vicious dog from the territorial limits
of the municipality shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours of such
removal by surrender of the license of the owner to the clerk of the village.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, the report of any incident
required to be reported under this subsection shall be made to the police
department of the municipality.
Further, all dog owners, whether or not their dog is licensed as a vicious dog,
receiving notice or having knowledge that their dog has bitten or attacked a
human being or domestic animal without provocation shall immediately notify the
police department of the village of said incident.
   (I)   Sign Required: All persons possessing a vicious dog shall display in a
prominent place on the premises where a vicious dog is to be kept a sign which
is readable by the public from a distance of not less than fifty feet (50')
using the words "Beware of Dog". A similar sign shall be posted on any
enclosure.
   (J)   Fighting Prohibited: No person shall fight or bait, conspire to fight
or bait, or keep, train, or transport for the purpose of fighting or baiting,
any dog. No person shall own or harbor any dog for the purpose of dogfighting,
or train, torment, badger, bait or use any dog for the purpose of causing or
encouraging said dog to attack human beings or domestic animals without
provocation.
   (K)   Revocation Of License: A license granted pursuant to this section
shall be automatically revoked upon the second violation by the licensee of any
provision of this section. In the event of a revocation of the license, the
license fee shall be retained by the village and the vicious dog must be
removed from the municipality within forty eight (48) hours.
   (L)   Exceptions: This section shall not apply to any K-9 patrol dogs or
police dogs while on duty.
   (M)   Penalties: Upon conviction of a violation of any provision of this
section, the court shall assess a fine of not less than two hundred dollars
($200.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Additionally,
any person found guilty of violating this section shall pay all expenses,
including shelter, food, veterinary expenses, and other expenses necessitated
by the seizure of the dog for the protection of the public, and such other
expenses as may be required for the destruction of any such dog.
   (N)   Failure To Comply: It shall be unlawful for the owner, keeper or
harborer of a vicious dog, registered with the village to fail to comply with
the requirements and conditions set forth in this section. Any vicious dog
found to be the subject of a violation of this section shall be subject to
immediate seizure and impoundment. In addition, failure to comply may result in
the revocation of the license of such animal resulting in the immediate removal
of the animal from the village.
   (O)   Severability: If any subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this
section is, for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid by a decision
of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the
validity of the remaining portions of this section. (Ord. 748, 6-23-2003)
6-4-1-8: ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS:
Anyone enforcing the provisions of this chapter shall not be held responsible
for any accident or disease that may happen to any dog or cat. (Ord. 748, 6-23-
2003)
6-4-1-9: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise specified in this chapter, any person violating or aiding the
violation of this chapter, or resisting, obstructing or impeding any authorized
officer in enforcing the act, or refusing to produce for inoculation any dog in
his possession not confined at all times to an enclosed area, or who removes a
tag from a dog for purposes of destroying or concealing its identity, shall pay
a penalty of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for the first violation, seventy five
dollars ($75.00) for the second violation occurring within a twelve (12) month
period and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the third and each successive
violation within a twelve (12) month period. Each day a person fails to comply
constitutes a separate offense. (Ord. 748, 6-23-2003)
ARTICLE II.  RABIES CONTROL
6-4-2-1: Rabies Vaccination Required
6-4-2-2: Certificate Of Vaccination
6-4-2-3: Duties Of Owner
6-4-2-4: Duties Of Persons Suspecting Any Dog To Be Suffering From Rabies
6-4-2-5: Duties Of Police Department
6-4-2-6: Confinement For Observation
6-4-2-7: Duties Of Owner Upon Reclaiming Dog
6-4-2-8: Rabies Epidemic; Power Of President
6-4-2-9: Duties Of Owners Upon Proclamation Of Rabies Epidemic
6-4-2-10: Police Authorized To Kill Certain Dogs Running At Large
6-4-2-11: False Reports Prohibited
6-4-2-1: RABIES VACCINATION REQUIRED:
   (A)   Every owner of a dog four (4) months or more of age shall cause such
dog to be inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian at such
intervals as may hereafter be established by regulations pursuant to the animal
control act of the state of Illinois.
   (B)   Every owner of a cat four (4) months or more of age shall cause such
cat to be inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian and shall
further cause said cat to be reinoculated against rabies by a licensed
veterinarian during each period of not more than twelve (12) months duration
thereafter.
   (C)   Evidence of such inoculation as set forth in subsections (A) and (B)
of this section shall consist of a certificate furnished and signed by the
person administering the vaccine containing such pertinent data as may be
prescribed by the administrator; and
      1.   One copy of such certificate shall be provided to the owner.
      2.   One copy of the certificate shall be filed with the Tazewell County
animal control department within twenty (20) days of inoculation.
      3.   One copy of the certificate shall be retained by the veterinarian
administering the vaccine for a period of five (5) years.
   (D)   The type and brand of rabies vaccine used shall be approved by the
United States department of agriculture and the department.
   (E)   Any licensed veterinarian who inoculates cats against rabies shall
procure from the administrator serially numbered tags, one to be issued with
each inoculation certificate. Such tag shall at all times be attached to a
collar or harness worn by the cat for which the certificate and tag have been
issued. A fee of one dollar ($1.00) shall be collected by the licensed
veterinarian administering inoculation at the time of the inoculation and such
tag fees shall be paid at such intervals as the administrator may direct to the
Tazewell animal control department to be used to defray the cost of the rabies
control program. (Ord. 271, 12-15-1975)
6-4-2-2: CERTIFICATE OF VACCINATION:
Every licensed veterinarian who vaccinates a dog shall issue a certificate of
vaccination to the owner of such dog stating the name and address of the owner,
a brief description of the dog and the date of such vaccination. (1971 Code)
6-4-2-3: DUTIES OF OWNER:
   (A)   Any owner receiving notice or having knowledge that his dog has been
bitten by any animal suffering or suspected to be suffering from rabies, or
that his dog has bitten any person, shall immediately notify or deliver his dog
to any police officer who shall place the dog in a licensed veterinary hospital
for observation, or such owner shall himself immediately notify the village
clerk of the name and location of such hospital.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any owner of a dog, upon receiving notice or
having knowledge that such dog has bitten any person or that such dog has been
bitten by any animal suffering or suspected to be suffering from rabies, to
sell or give away such dog, or permit such dog to run at large, or to be taken
beyond the village except to a veterinary hospital within the county; and it
shall also be unlawful for such owner to refuse to deliver said dog for
observation as provided herein. (1971 Code)
6-4-2-4: DUTIES OF PERSONS SUSPECTING ANY DOG TO BE SUFFERING FROM RABIES:
   (A)   Every veterinarian or other person discovering or suspecting any dog
to be suffering from rabies shall immediately report this matter to the police
department of the village, giving the name and address of the owner of such
dog, if known, the place where the dog can be found and the license tag number
of such dog, if known.
   (B)   For the purposes of this section only, any dog which has bitten any
person shall be presumed to be suffering from rabies. (1971 Code)
6-4-2-5: DUTIES OF POLICE DEPARTMENT:
Upon being notified that a dog has bitten any person or is suspected of
suffering from rabies, the police department shall:
   (A)   When the owner of the dog is known, notify such owner and direct such
owner to deliver up the dog to a licensed veterinary hospital for observation;
or
   (B)   When the owner of the dog is unknown, immediately take up said dog and
confine said dog to a licensed veterinary hospital for observation.
   (C)   When a dog is taken up under the provisions of subsection (B) of this
section, notify the owner, if known, of the confinement of such dog within
seven (7) days after the confinement begins or the identity of the owner is
discovered. (1971 Code)
6-4-2-6: CONFINEMENT FOR OBSERVATION:
   (A)   Confinement of a dog for observation under this article shall be for a
period of ten (10) days. The dog shall be examined immediately after
confinement and again before the ten (10) day period has expired.
   (B)   The veterinarian shall submit to the clerk a certificate following
each examination stating whether or not the dog shows symptoms of rabies.
   (C)   If the dog is found rabid the dog shall be destroyed in a humane
manner. If the dog is destroyed, or if it shall die within the ten (10) day
observation period, its head shall be sent to the veterinarian to the
laboratory of the state department of public health.
   (D)   If the dog is not found rabid by the end of the confinement period,
the owner shall be so notified and the dog may be released to its owner, and
the village clerk so advised. (1971 Code)
6-4-2-7: DUTIES OF OWNER UPON RECLAIMING DOG:
   (A)   An owner may reclaim any dog impounded under the provisions of this
article within seven (7) days after the period for observing said dog has
expired by paying the costs incurred during the observation period, and the
cost of a license if the dog was unlicensed, and the costs of a rabies
vaccination shot if the owner cannot prove the dog has been properly vaccinated
as provided in section
6-4-1-6 of this chapter.
   (B)   If the owner or keeper does not claim the dog within this time, then
any person may redeem it by making like payments.
   (C)   If the dog is not claimed as set forth herein, it shall be destroyed
in a humane manner, and any unpaid costs incurred by a licensed veterinarian in
compliance with this article shall be paid to said veterinarian in an amount
not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00) upon receipt by the village of an itemized
bill setting forth said costs. (1971 Code)
6-4-2-8: RABIES EPIDEMIC; POWER OF PRESIDENT:
   (A)   Whenever the president shall deem it necessary to prevent an epidemic
of rabies, he may issue a proclamation requiring the owners of all dogs to keep
them securely confined or to keep them properly muzzled or leashed, so they
cannot bite, for such times as may be designated in the proclamation or until
otherwise notified.
   (B)   The president shall publish such proclamation in a paper of general
circulation within the village and post such proclamation in the village hall.
(1971 Code)
6-4-2-9: DUTIES OF OWNERS UPON PROCLAMATION OF RABIES EPIDEMIC:
Following any proclamation as set forth in the preceding section, it shall be
unlawful for any owner to permit his dog to run at large in violation of the
provisions of such proclamation. In addition to the penalties provided with
respect to any such owner for violating this section, a dog running at large
unmuzzled shall be impounded. (1971 Code)
6-4-2-10: POLICE AUTHORIZED TO KILL CERTAIN DOGS RUNNING AT LARGE:
Any policeman may kill a dog running at large which is suspected of suffering
from rabies if the dog, in the opinion of the police officer, cannot be safely
taken up and impounded, or if the police officer deems such killing essential
to the safety of any person. (1971 Code)
6-4-2-11: FALSE REPORTS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make any report required by this article
without having a reasonable belief in its truth and accuracy. (1971 Code)
ARTICLE III.  OFFENSES INVOLVING ANIMALS
SECTION:
6-4-3-1: Annoying Noises
6-4-3-2: Causing Animal To Make Annoying Noises
6-4-3-3: Complaint Of Annoying Noises
6-4-3-4: Animals Disturbing The Peace Declared A Nuisance
6-4-3-5: Animals Prohibited From Running At Large
6-4-3-6: Animals Running At Large Declared A Nuisance
6-4-3-7: Defecation By Dogs On Private Property
6-4-3-8: Destruction Of Private Property By Dog
6-4-3-9: Restriction Of Animals From Public Places
6-4-3-10: Threatening Or Annoying Dogs
6-4-3-11: Dogs Chasing Vehicles Or Bicycles
6-4-3-12: Authority To Take Up Dogs Running At Large On Private Property Or
Public Places
6-4-3-13: Vicious And Dangerous Dogs
6-4-3-14: Impounding Dangerous Dogs (Rep. by Ord. 968, 4-14-2014)
6-4-3-15: Cruelty To Animals
6-4-3-16: Duty Upon Striking Animal With Motor Vehicle
6-4-3-17: Intentional Injuring Of Animals
6-4-3-18: Procurement Of Animal Without Knowledge Of Owner
6-4-3-19: Abandoning Animals Within Village
6-4-3-20: Keeping Animals In Sanitary Condition
6-4-3-21: Offensive Odors
6-4-3-22: Female Dogs And Cats In Heat
6-4-3-23: Use Of Animals For Indecent Purposes
6-4-3-24: Certain Animals Prohibited In Village
6-4-3-25: Diseased Or Dying Animals; Running At Large
6-4-3-26: Dead Or Dying Animals; Removal Required
6-4-3-27: Dead Or Dying Animals; Burial, Throwing Into Streets, Keeping
6-4-3-28: Fowl, Rabbits
6-4-3-1: ANNOYING NOISES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any animal which disturbs
the peace by loud noises at any time of day or night, and it shall be unlawful
for any such person to permit any animal to make such noises. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-2: CAUSING ANIMAL TO MAKE ANNOYING NOISES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to treat any animal in any manner which
causes such animal to disturb the peace by loud noises at any time of day or
night. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-3: COMPLAINT OF ANNOYING NOISES:
Any person residing in a neighborhood whose quietness has been disturbed by any
animal owned or possessed within the neighborhood may make a sworn complaint
before a village police officer or the village clerk against the owner or
possessor of said animal. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-4: ANIMALS DISTURBING THE PEACE DECLARED A NUISANCE:
Any animal which disturbs the peace by loud noises at any time of day or night
is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and may be impounded by the village dog
catcher or a village police officer, and may be redeemed only by paying the
appropriate fees as provided in section
6-4-4-5 of this chapter. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-5: ANIMALS PROHIBITED FROM RUNNING AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal, whether properly tagged and
certified by vaccination, registration or not, to permit or allow such animal
to run at large off the property of the owner. Violation of any provision of
this section shall be punishable by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 271, 12-15-1975; amd. Ord. 817, 5-14-2007)
6-4-3-6: ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE DECLARED A NUISANCE:
   (A)   The provisions of section
6-4-3-5 of this article shall not apply to animals being used in hunting, field
trials and animal shows while on public lands set aside for those purposes,
while on the private property of others with the actual, implied customary or
constructive consent of the owner of such private premises, or while on
federal, state, municipal or county roads or highways, in a rural area, while
going to or coming from a hunting, field trial or animal show site. Nor shall
the provisions or prohibitions in this subsection apply to bloodhounds or other
dogs used for tracking in conjunction with police activities, nor to dogs of
the canine corps of any municipal police force, the Illinois highway patrol,
and federal law enforcement agency, or the armed forces of the United States,
while being used to conduct official business or being used for official
purposes.
   (B)   Any animal found running at large off the premises of the owner shall
be apprehended and impounded at any existing or available public pound.
   (C)   When any animal is apprehended and impounded pursuant to this section,
notice of not less than seven (7) days shall be given to the owner, if known.
Such notice shall be mailed to the last known address of the owner. An
affidavit or testimony of the administrator, or his authorized agent, who mails
such notice shall be prima facie evidence of the receipt of such notice by the
owner of such animal. In case the owner of any impounded animal desires to make
redemption thereof, he may do so in the following conditions:
      1.   He must present proof of current inoculation and registration; or
      2.   He must pay for the rabies inoculation of the animal and
registration; and
      3.   He must pay the pound for the board of the animal for the period it
was impounded; and
      4.   He must pay an additional five dollars ($5.00) as a reclamation fee
for the first such occasion said animal was apprehended running at large and
ten dollars ($10.00) for each subsequent occasion, which reclamation fee shall
be paid into the animal control fund of the village. (Ord. 271, 12-15-1975)
6-4-3-7: DEFECATION BY DOGS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or possessor to permit a dog to walk or
defecate upon private property without the consent of the occupant thereof.
(1971 Code)
6-4-3-8: DESTRUCTION OF PRIVATE PROPERTY BY DOG:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or possessor of any dog to permit such dog
to damage or destroy any personal property of another person. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-9: RESTRICTION OF ANIMALS FROM PUBLIC PLACES:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or possessor of any animal to permit such
animal to enter any religious premises, public hall, bank building, automobile
gasoline station, public garage or any place where food or beverage is sold or
served during such time as these establishments are open for use to the public
or persons entitled to use the same; provided, however, that the owner of any
of the above establishments may permit a watchdog to remain therein if such dog
is held and restrained in such a way that such dog cannot injure any patron or
come in contact with any food. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-10: THREATENING OR ANNOYING DOGS:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or possessor of any dog to permit such dog
to cause reasonable fear of bodily injury to any person by attacking or
threatening to attack such person, or to permit such dog to jump upon any
person to the annoyance of said person. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-11: DOGS CHASING VEHICLES OR BICYCLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person owning or possessing any dog to permit such
dog to chase any motor vehicle or bicycle traveling upon any public or private
street or sidewalk. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-12: AUTHORITY TO TAKE UP DOGS RUNNING AT LARGE ON PRIVATE PROPERTY OR
PUBLIC PLACES:
Any person finding any dog running at large upon his property or upon any
premises enumerated in section
6-4-3-9 of this article to his injury or annoyance may take up such dog and
remove it or have it impounded. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-13: VICIOUS AND DANGEROUS DOGS:
There is hereby adopted 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15 - 5/15.4, and the
same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length
herein, and from the date on which this chapter shall take effect, the
provisions thereof shall be controlling. (Ord. 968, 4-14-2014)
6-4-3-14: IMPOUNDING DANGEROUS DOGS:
(Rep. by Ord. 968, 4-14-2014)
6-4-3-15: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to instigate, cause, procure or
encourage any fight between animals, either in private or in public.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt or attempt to kill by any
means any game animal or game birds within the village.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to treat any animal within the
village in any cruel manner whatsoever. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-16: DUTY UPON STRIKING ANIMAL WITH MOTOR VEHICLE:
It shall be unlawful for any person who kills or injures any animal while
driving a motor vehicle to leave the scene of the accident without first
stopping and rendering such assistance as is practical. Such person shall
immediately report the incident to the police department. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-17: INTENTIONAL INJURING OF ANIMALS:
In addition to the other prohibitions of this article, no person shall kill or
wound, or attempt to kill or wound, by any means whatsoever, any bird or
squirrel, or rob or injure the nest of such creatures, or enter upon any
private premises or public place, for the purpose of doing any act prohibited
by this section; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to crows,
starlings, hawks, sparrows and pigeons. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-18: PROCUREMENT OF ANIMAL WITHOUT KNOWLEDGE OF OWNER:
It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to procure or acquire, or
attempt to procure or acquire, or knowingly cause or aid in the procurement or
acquisition of any animal for any purpose without the consent of the owner
thereof. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-19: ABANDONING ANIMALS WITHIN VILLAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in control of any animal to
abandon such animal within the village 1 . (1971 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  6-4-1-1 of this chapter.
6-4-3-20: KEEPING ANIMALS IN SANITARY CONDITION:
Every owner or person in possession of an animal shall maintain his animal in a
clean and sanitary condition. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-21: OFFENSIVE ODORS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit offensive odors to
emanate from the premises where he keeps any animal. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-22: FEMALE DOGS AND CATS IN HEAT:
All female dogs and cats in heat shall be securely confined in an enclosed
place, which does not allow the confined animal to come in contact with other
animals. (Ord. 271, 12-15-1975)
6-4-3-23: USE OF ANIMALS FOR INDECENT PURPOSES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to in any manner instigate, cause, procure,
participate in or assist in any indecent, lewd or immoral show, use or
exhibition of an animal. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-24: CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED IN VILLAGE:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit to be at large within
the village or to use, or keep within the village any of the following animals:
bees, horses, cattle, sheep, ponies, mules, goats, pigs, swine, hogs, ducks,
geese, roosters, minks, foxes, or any other livestock or poultry or any wild or
vicious animal dangerous to mankind. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
   (B)   Any animal named above which is found at large within the village
shall be impounded, if possible; provided, however, that whenever any police
officer believes such animal endangers any person, such animal may be killed by
said officer.
   (C)   In addition to any other penalties imposed upon any person violating
this section, such person shall also be liable for the costs of impounding or
killing such animal, if necessary. (Ord. 976, 8-11-2014)
6-4-3-25: DISEASED OR DYING ANIMALS; RUNNING AT LARGE:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to allow any animal afflicted with any contagious
or infectious disease to run at large or to be exposed in any public place
whereby the health of the person or other animals may be affected; nor shall
such diseased animal be removed or shipped from the premises of the owner
thereof except under the supervision of the health officer or a licensed
veterinarian.
   (B)   The health officer shall cause such disposition of any diseased animal
and such treatment of affected premises as to prevent the communication or
spread of contagion or infection.
   (C)   Whenever any animal is in any street or public place within the
village and appears, in the estimation of any police officer or village health
officer, to be injured or diseased beyond recovery, and is not being attended
and properly cared for by the owner or other proper person in control thereof,
and whenever such animal has not been removed to some private premises or other
place designated by such officer within one hour after being found or left in
such condition, such animal may be put to death by such officer or his
authorized agent and, unless at once removed by the owner, shall be treated as
any other dead animal found on a street or public place, as hereinafter
provided. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-26: DEAD OR DYING ANIMALS; REMOVAL REQUIRED:
Any person possessing any dead animal, or animal injured or diseased beyond
recovery, which is not killed for meat or is improper for use as meat, or which
is in an offensive condition or sick with an infectious or contagious disease,
shall at once notify the village health officer thereof, and upon the health
officer's order, such person at his own expense shall at once remove or cause
the removal of such animal. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-27: DEAD OR DYING ANIMALS; BURIAL, THROWING INTO STREETS, KEEPING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon, deposit or throw upon any place
or street or public water, or to offensively expose or bury anywhere within the
village, the body or any part thereof of any dead or fatally diseased or
injured animal; nor shall any person keep any dead animal or any offensive
meat, bird, fowl or fish in a place where the same may be dangerous to the life
or detrimental to the health of any person. (1971 Code)
6-4-3-28: FOWL, RABBITS:
Any person wishing to keep or maintain fowl or rabbits within the corporate
limits of the village must first obtain a permit at the village hall of the
village of North Pekin. No fee shall be assessed for said permit. All fowl or
rabbits kept or maintained within the village limits of the village of North
Pekin must be kept in compliance with the following requirements:
   (A)   No person shall keep or maintain more than six (6) chickens in any
residential area within the corporate limits of the village. Roosters shall be
prohibited.
   (B)   No person shall keep or maintain more than twelve (12) pigeons/doves
in any residential area within the corporate limits of the village, subject to
the conditions below.
   (C)   No person shall keep or maintain more than twelve (12) rabbits in any
residential area within the corporate limits of the village, subject to the
conditions below.
   (D)   Any animals kept pursuant to this section shall only be permitted on a
lot with a single-family residence which shall be inhabited on a full time
basis. Chickens, pigeons/doves and rabbits shall be prohibited at duplex and
multi-family buildings.
   (E)   The pen, poultry house or other structure designed to confine or
shelter such chickens, pigeons/doves and rabbits must be located on the tract
so that the nearest portion thereof is not less than fifteen feet (15') from
the line of the adjoining property.
   (F)   The pen, poultry house or other structure shall be located behind the
rear plane of the existing dwelling (not in the front or side yard) and shall
be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. Said structure
shall be covered and ventilated to protect the animals from inclement weather
and predators. Said structure shall be located ten feet (10') from the side and
rear yard property lines and electric service to the structure shall not be
provided by an extension cord.
   (G)   Any animal kept pursuant to this section shall be kept for personal
use only, and shall be contained within a pen, poultry house or other enclosure
or run at all times.
   (H)   Storage vessels containing feed shall be impervious to pests and
vermin.
   (I)   Any animal kept pursuant to this section must be kept in a manner so
as not to cause inconvenience or disturbance to other persons by reason of
noise, odor, nuisance or other cause.
   (J)   Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who
resists or opposes the enforcement of any provision of this chapter shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined no less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
three hundred dollars ($300.00), and for each subsequent offense such person
shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00); and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate
offense for each and every day during which said violation continues. (Ord.
976, 8-11-2014)
ARTICLE IV.  IMPOUNDING OF ANIMALS
SECTION:
6-4-4-1: Village Animal Shelter
6-4-4-2: Animal Welfare Officer
6-4-4-3: Interference With Animal Welfare Officer
6-4-4-4: Minimum Period Before Disposal
6-4-4-5: Redemption Of Impounded Animals
6-4-4-6: Unclaimed Animals
6-4-4-7: Ex Officio Animal Welfare Officer
6-4-4-8: Temporary Animal Shelter
6-4-4-1: VILLAGE ANIMAL SHELTER:
The village shall provide and maintain an animal shelter suitable for the
impounding, confining and maintenance of all animals running at large or
otherwise subject to impounding as provided in this chapter. (1971 Code)
6-4-4-2: ANIMAL WELFARE OFFICER:
The village shall provide an animal welfare officer in charge of the animal
shelter whose duties shall include:
   (A)   The impounding of all animals delivered to him;
   (B)   The maintenance of suitable means for impounding such animals;
   (C)   The feeding, maintenance and humane treatment of all animals impounded
therein;
   (D)   The keeping of each animal separate from all other animals therein;
   (E)   The maintenance of a register in which he shall enter immediately upon
receiving an animal the breed, color, sex, age, and, if licensed the name and
address of the owner, and the number of the license tag. The disposition of
such animal shall be entered in the register at the proper time; and
   (F)   The giving of notice to the owner of a licensed animal by telephone,
mail or otherwise, or the exercise of a reasonable effort to ascertain and
notify the owner of any unlicensed animal impounded. If the owner of any animal
is not ascertained within twenty four (24) hours after impounding, such officer
shall cause public notice to be made thereof by posting a copy of the
description of such animal and the date of impounding at the shelter. (1971
Code)
6-4-4-3: INTERFERENCE WITH ANIMAL WELFARE OFFICER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to liberate or attempt to liberate any
animal impounded in the animal shelter, or any animal captured or within a
vehicle and being conveyed to the shelter, or to interfere in any manner with
the Animal Welfare Officer or his authorized agent in the performance of their
duties. (1971 Code)
6-4-4-4: MINIMUM PERIOD BEFORE DISPOSAL:
Except as provided by Article II of this Chapter with respect to dogs under
observation for rabies, an animal in the shelter shall be held therein at least
four (4) days for redemption. (1971 Code)
6-4-4-5: REDEMPTION OF IMPOUNDED ANIMALS:
   (A)   Any person seeking to redeem any impounded animal shall pay a fee of
ten dollars ($10.00) for the first and each subsequent time his animal is
impounded. An additional fee of three dollars ($3.00) for each day after the
first day during which such animal has been impounded shall also be paid. (Ord.
523, 2-25-1991)
   (B)   In addition, such person must prove that said animal is properly
licensed and inoculated or vaccinated against rabies as provided in this
Chapter. Absent such proof, no such animal shall be released from the shelter
until the animal be properly licensed and vaccinated, and until all costs and
expenses thereof be paid to the Village Clerk. (Ord. 236, 11-13-1972)
6-4-4-6: UNCLAIMED ANIMALS:
Whenever no person has redeemed an impounded animal, including the paying of
all required costs, within the allotted period, such animal may be killed in a
humane manner; provided, however, that when any reputable institution of
medical or scientific research of learning shall apply in writing to the
President for permission to use impounded and unclaimed animals for scientific
purposes only, the President may surrender to such institution such unclaimed
animals as are available. (1971 Code)
6-4-4-7: EX OFFICIO ANIMAL WELFARE OFFICER:
In the absence of a duly appointed Animal Welfare Officer, the Chief of Police
shall be ex officio Animal Welfare Officer and shall exercise the powers and
duties prescribed for the Animal Welfare Officer in this Chapter. (1971 Code)
6-4-4-8: TEMPORARY ANIMAL SHELTER:
In the absence of a permanently established Village Animal Shelter, the Board
of Trustees, by resolution, may designate any licensed veterinarian as the
temporary Village Animal Shelter. (1971 Code)
ARTICLE V.  PET SHOPS
SECTION:
6-4-5-1: Definition
6-4-5-2: State License Required
6-4-5-3: Duties Of Pet Shop Operator
6-4-5-4: Right Of Inspection
6-4-5-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this Article, "pet shop operator" means any person who
sells, offers for sale or exchange, or offers for adoption, with or without
charge or donation, any dogs, cats, birds or other animals commonly kept as
pets, or who sells or offers for sale or exchange any food, supplies or
equipment for such animals or pets. (1971 Code)
6-4-5-2: STATE LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business or activity of a
pet shop operator within the Village unless he shall be currently duly licensed
as such under the provisions of the "Pet Shop and Dog Dealer Licensing Act"
where required 1 . (1971 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 605/2.
6-4-5-3: DUTIES OF PET SHOP OPERATOR:
Every pet shop operator shall:
   (A)   Maintain proper sanitary conditions and ensure proper ventilation;
   (B)   Provide adequate nutrition and humane care and treatment for all
animals under his custody;
   (C)   Take reasonable care to release for sale, trade or adoption only those
animals which are free from disease, injuries or abnormalities. A health
certificate meeting the requirements of the State Health Department and issued
by a licensed veterinarian for any such animal within five (5) days before such
sale, trade or adoption shall be prima facie evidence that the pet shop
operator has taken reasonable care as required herein; and
   (D)   Comply with all applicable provisions of this Code regulating health,
sanitation and safety. (1971 Code)
6-4-5-4: RIGHT OF INSPECTION:
The Village Health Officer or his authorized agent shall have power to inspect
at any reasonable time the premises of any pet shop operator to determine
compliance with this Chapter or any applicable provisions of the State law.
(1971 Code)
ARTICLE VI.  PENALTIES
SECTION:
6-4-6-1: Liability Of Owner Or Keeper; Damage To Animals
6-4-6-2: Liability Of Owner Or Keeper; Injury To Persons
6-4-6-3: Liability Of Owner Or Keeper; Damage To Property
6-4-6-4: Penalty
6-4-6-5: Separability Of Penalties
6-4-6-1: LIABILITY OF OWNER OR KEEPER; DAMAGE TO ANIMALS:
The owner or keeper of any animal shall be liable for all damages that may
accrue to any other person by reason of any such animal pursuing, chasing,
wounding or killing any animal belonging to such other person; provided,
however, that no owner or keeper of any animal shall be liable for any damage
caused by such animal having rabies or other similar disease unknown to such
owner or keeper. (1971 Code)
6-4-6-2: LIABILITY OF OWNER OR KEEPER; INJURY TO PERSONS:
If an animal without provocation attacks or injures any person who is peaceably
conducting himself in any place where he may lawfully be, the owner or keeper
of such animal shall be liable in damages to the person so attacked or injured
to the full amount of the injury sustained. (1971 Code)
6-4-6-3: LIABILITY OF OWNER OR KEEPER; DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
The owner or keeper of any animal which damages or destroys any public or
private property shall be held liable for the full value of the property
damaged or destroyed. (1971 Code)
6-4-6-4: PENALTY:
Any person who violates, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists or
opposes the enforcement of any provision of this Chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be fined no less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than three
hundred dollars ($300.00), and for each subsequent offense such person shall be
fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00); and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for
each and every day during which said violation continues. (1971 Code)
6-4-6-5: SEPARABILITY OF PENALTIES:
The penalties provided for in this Article shall not be construed as precluding
each other or any other penalties and costs provided elsewhere in this Chapter.
(1971 Code)
CHAPTER 5
PARK REGULATIONS
SECTION:
6-5-1: Hours
6-5-1: HOURS:
All public parks in the village shall be closed between the hours of ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 899, 6-28-2010)
CHAPTER 6
PUBLIC NUDITY
SECTION:
6-6-1: Title
6-6-2: Intent
6-6-3: Definitions
6-6-4: Legislative Findings
6-6-5: Nudity, Sexual Conduct Prohibited In Establishments Dealing In Alcoholic
Beverages
6-6-6: Nudity Prohibited In Public Places
6-6-7: Exemptions
6-6-8: Territory Embraced
6-6-9: Enforcement And Penalties
6-6-10: Injunctive Relief
6-6-11: Severability
6-6-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known as the VILLAGE OF NORTH PEKIN PUBLIC NUDITY
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 623, 8-12-1996)
6-6-2: INTENT:
It is the intent of this Chapter to protect and preserve the health, safety,
welfare, and morals of the citizens of the Village by prohibiting a person from
intentionally or recklessly appearing or being nude, or causing another person
to appear or be nude, in a public place and in other places which may
reasonably be expected to be observed by the public within the incorporated
areas of the Village except:
   (A)   When such person appears nude in a place provided or set apart for
nudity provided: 1) such person is nude for the sole purpose of performing the
legal function(s) that is customarily intended to be performed within such
place provided or set apart for nudity and 2) such person is not nude for the
purpose of obtaining money or other financial gain for such person or for
another person or entity, or
   (B)   When the conduct of being nude cannot legally be prohibited by this
Chapter: 1) because it constitutes a part of a bona fide live communication,
demonstration, or performance by such person wherein such nudity is expressive
conduct incidental to and necessary for the conveyance or communication of a
genuine message or public expression and is not a guise or pretense utilized to
exploit nudity for profit or commercial gain (see, for instance, Board of
County Commissioners v. Dexterhouse, 348 So.2d 916 (Fla.2d DCA 1977)) and as
such is protected by the United States or Illinois Constitution or 2) because
it is otherwise protected by the United States or Illinois Constitution.
It is the Board's further intention to accomplish those intents and purposes
expressed by the Board in the "Whereas" provisions of Ordinance 623, each of
which are incorporated by reference into this Section. (Ord. 623, 8-12-1996)
6-6-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms, when used in this Chapter, shall have the following
meanings:
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES: All distilled spirits and all beverages containing one-
half of one percent (0.5%) or more alcohol by volume. The percentage of alcohol
by volume shall be determined by measuring the volume of the standard ethyl
alcohol in the beverage and comparing it with the volume of the remainder of
the ingredients as though said remainder ingredients were distilled water.
BREAST: A portion of the human female mammary gland (commonly referred to as
the female breast) including the nipple and the areola (the darker colored area
of the breast surrounding the nipple) and an outside area of such gland wherein
such outside area is: a) reasonably compact and contiguous to the areola and b)
contains at least the nipple and the areola and one-fourth (1/4) of the outside
surface area of such gland.
BUTTOCKS: (For a short general description see the last sentence of this
definition). The area at the rear of the human body (sometimes referred to as
the gluteus maximus) which lies between two (2) imaginary straight lines
running parallel to the ground when a person is standing, the first or top such
line being one- half inch (1/2") below the top of the vertical cleavage of the
nates (i.e., the prominence formed by the muscles running from the back of the
hip to the back of the leg) and the second or bottom such line being one-half
inch (1/2") above the lowest point of the curvature of the fleshy protuberance
(sometimes referred to as the "gluteal fold"), and between two (2) imaginary
straight lines, one on each side of the body (the "outside lines"), which
outside lines are perpendicular to the ground and to the horizontal lines
described above and which perpendicular outside lines are perpendicular to the
ground and to the horizontal lines described above and which perpendicular
outside lines pass through the outermost point(s) at which each nate meets the
other side of each leg. Notwithstanding the above, "buttocks" shall not include
the leg, the hamstring muscle below the gluteal fold, the tensor fasciae latae
muscle or any of the above described portion of the human body that is between
either: a) the left inside perpendicular line and the left outside
perpendicular line or b) the right inside perpendicular line and the right
outside perpendicular line. For the purpose of the previous sentence the left
inside perpendicular line shall be an imaginary straight line on the left side
of the anus: a) that is perpendicular to the ground and to the horizontal lines
described above and b) that is one-third (1/3) of the distance from the anus to
the left outside line, and the right inside perpendicular line shall be an
imaginary straight line on the right side of the anus c) that is perpendicular
to the ground and to the horizontal lines described above and d) that is one-
third (1/3) of the distance from the anus to the right outside line. (The above
description can generally be described as covering 1/3 of the buttocks centered
over the cleavage for the length of the cleavage.)
ENTITY: Any proprietorship, partnership, corporation, association, business
trust, joint venture, joint-stock company or other for-profit and/or not-for-
profit organization.
ESTABLISHMENT DEALING IN ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES: Any business, commercial or other
establishment (whether for-profit or not-for- profit and whether open to the
public at large or where entrance is limited by coverage charge or membership
requirement) including those licensed by the State for sale and/or service of
alcoholic beverages, and any bottle club; hotel; motel; restaurant; nightclub;
country club; cabaret; meeting facility utilized by any religious, social,
fraternal or similar organization; business, commercial or other establishment
where a product or article is sold, dispensed, served or provided with the
knowledge, actual or implied, that the same will be, or is intended to be
mixed, combined with or drunk in connection or combination with an alcoholic
beverage on the premises or curtilage of said business, commercial or other
establishment; or business, commercial or other establishment where the
consumption of alcoholic beverages is permitted. Premises, or portions thereof
such as hotel rooms, used solely as a private residence, whether permanent or
temporary in nature, shall not be deemed to be an establishment dealing in
alcoholic beverages.
NUDE: Any person insufficiently clothed in any manner so that any of the
following body parts are not entirely covered with a fully opaque covering:
   (A)   The male or female genitals, or
   (B)   The male or female pubic area, or
   (C)   The female breast (see the last sentence in this definition), or
   (D)   The buttocks. Attire which is insufficient to comply with this
requirement includes, but is not limited to, G-strings, T-backs, dental floss
and thongs.
Body paint, body dyes, tattoos, liquid latex whether wet or dried, and similar
substances shall not be considered opaque covering. Each female person may
determine which one-fourth (1/4) of her breast surface area (see definition of
"breast" in this Section) contiguous to and containing the nipple and the
areola is to be covered.
PERSON: Any live human being aged ten (10) years of age or older.
PLACES PROVIDED OR SET APART FOR NUDITY: Enclosed single-sex public restrooms,
enclosed single-sex functional shower, locker and/or dressing room facilities,
enclosed motel rooms and hotel rooms designed and intended for sleeping
accommodations, doctors' offices, portions of hospitals, and similar places in
which nudity or exposure is necessarily and customarily expected outside of the
home and the sphere of privacy constitutionally protected therein. This term
shall not be deemed to include places where a person's conduct of being nude is
used for his or her profit or where being nude is used for the promotion of
business or is otherwise commercially exploited.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any location frequented by the public, or where the public is
present or likely to be present, or where a person may reasonably be expected
to be observed by members of the public. Public places include, but are not
limited to, streets, sidewalks, parks, beaches, business and commercial
establishments (whether for-profit or not-for-profit and whether open to the
public at large or where entrance is limited by a cover charge or membership
requirement), bottle clubs, hotels, motels, restaurants, nightclubs, country
clubs, cabarets, and meeting facilities utilized by any religious, social,
fraternal or similar organization. Premises, or portions thereof such as hotel
rooms, used solely as a private residence, whether permanent or temporary in
nature, shall not be deemed to be a public place. (Ord. 623, 8-12-1996)
6-6-4: LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS:
In addition and supplemental to the findings and determinations contained in
the "Whereas" provisions of Ordinance 623 which are incorporated by reference
into this Section, it is hereby found by the Board, acting in its legislative
capacity for the purpose of regulating the conduct of appearing nude in public
places and for the purpose of regulating nudity and other conduct in
establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages, that, considering what has
happened in other communities, the acts prohibited in Section
6-6-5 of this Chapter encourage or create the potential for the conduct of
prostitution, attempted rape, rape, and assault in and around establishments
dealing in alcoholic beverages; that actual and simulated nudity and sexual
conduct, coupled with the consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places,
begets and has the potential for begetting undesirable and unlawful behavior;
that sexual, lewd, lascivious, and salacious conduct among patrons and
employees within establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages results in
violation of law and creates dangers to the health, safety, morals, and welfare
of the public and those who engage in such conduct; and, it is the intent of
Section
6-6-5 of this Chapter to specifically prohibit nudity, gross sexuality and the
simulation thereof in establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages. (Ord. 623,
8-12-1996)
6-6-5: NUDITY, SEXUAL CONDUCT PROHIBITED IN ESTABLISHMENTS DEALING IN ALCOHOLIC
BEVERAGES:
The following prohibitions and criteria shall apply within existing and/or
newly created establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages and the curtilages
thereof:
   (A)   No person shall knowingly, intentionally or recklessly appear, or
cause another person to appear, nude or expose to public view his or her
genitals, pubic area, vulva, or buttocks, or any simulation thereof.
   (B)   No female person shall knowingly, intentionally or recklessly expose,
or cause another female person to expose her breasts or any simulation thereof
to public view.
   (C)   No person or entity maintaining, owning, or operating an establishment
dealing in alcoholic beverages shall encourage, allow or permit any person to
appear nude or to expose to public view his or her genitals, pubic area, vulva,
anus, or any portion of the buttocks or simulation thereof. This Section shall
be violated if any portion of the buttocks is visible from any vantage point.
   (D)   No person or entity maintaining, owning, or operating an establishment
dealing in alcoholic beverages shall encourage, allow or permit any female
person to expose her breasts or any simulation thereof to public view.
   (E)   No person shall engage in and no person or entity maintaining, owning,
or operating an establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages shall encourage,
allow or permit any sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral
copulation, flagellation, lap dancing, straddle dancing, any sexual act which
is prohibited by law, touching, caressing, or fondling of the breasts,
buttocks, anus, or genitals, or the simulation thereof.
   (F)   The prohibitions of this Section shall not apply when a person appears
nude in a place provided or set apart for nudity provided: 1) such person is
nude for the sole purpose of performing the legal function(s) that is
customarily intended to be performed within such place provided or set apart
for nudity and 2) such person is not nude for the purpose of obtaining money or
other financial gain for such person or for another person or entity.
   (G)   Each female person may determine which one-fourth (1/4) of her breast
surface area (see definition of "breast" in Section
6-6-3 of this Chapter) contiguous to and containing the areola is to be
covered.
   (H)   This Section shall not be deemed to address photographs, movies, video
presentations, or other nonlive performances. (Ord. 623, 8-12-1996)
6-6-6: NUDITY PROHIBITED IN PUBLIC PLACES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly, intentionally or recklessly
appear, or cause another person to appear, nude in a public place or in any
other place which is readily visible to the public, except as provided in
Section
6-6-7 of this Chapter. It shall also be unlawful for any person or entity
maintaining, owning, or operating any public place or establishment to
encourage, suffer or allow any person to appear nude in such public place,
except as provided in Section
6-6-7 of this Chapter. (Ord. 623, 8-12-1996)
6-6-7: EXEMPTIONS:
The prohibitions of Section
6-6-6 of this Chapter shall not apply:
   (A)   When a person appears nude in a place provided or set apart for nudity
provided: 1) such person is nude for the sole purpose of performing the legal
function(s) that is customarily intended to be performed within such place
provided or set apart for nudity and 2) such person is not nude for the purpose
of obtaining money or other financial gain for such person or for another
person or entity, or
   (B)   When the conduct of being nude cannot legally be prohibited by this
Chapter: 1) because it constitutes a part of a bona fide live communication,
demonstration or performance by a person wherein such nudity is expressive
conduct incidental to and necessary for the conveyance or communication of a
genuine message or public expression and is not a mere guise or pretense
utilized to exploit the conduct of being nude for profit or commercial gain
(see, for instance, Board of County Commissioners v. Dexterhouse, 348 So.2d 916
(Fla. 2nd DCA 1977)) and as such is protected by the United States or Illinois
Constitution or 2) because it is otherwise protected by the United States or
Illinois Constitution.
   (C)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter, a mother may
breast feed her baby in any location, public or private, where the mother is
otherwise, authorized to be, irrespective of whether the nipple of the mother's
breast is uncovered during or incidental to the breast-feeding. (Ord. 623, 8-
12-1996)
6-6-8: TERRITORY EMBRACED:
All territory within the legal boundaries of incorporated Village of North
Pekin shall be embraced by the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 623, 8-12-
1996)
6-6-9: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
Any person or entity violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be
prosecuted in the same manner as misdemeanors are prosecuted. Such violations
shall be prosecuted in the name of the State of Illinois in a court having
jurisdiction of misdemeanors by the prosecuting attorney thereof and, upon
conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars
($500.00) or by imprisonment in the County jail not to exceed sixty (60) days
or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each incident or separate occurrence of
an act that violates this Chapter shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord.
623, 8-12-1996)
6-6-10: INJUNCTIVE RELIEF:
In addition to the procedures provided herein, establishments dealing in
alcoholic beverages that are not in conformity with these requirements shall be
subject to appropriate civil action in the court of appropriate jurisdiction
for abatement. (Ord. 623, 8-12-1996)
6-6-11: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, word or provision of this
Chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of
competent jurisdiction, whether for substantive, procedural, or any other
reason, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent
provision, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portions of this Chapter. (Ord. 623, 8-12-1996)
TITLE 7
HEALTH AND SANITATION
CHAPTER 1
LITTER
SECTION:
7-1-1: Definitions
7-1-2: Litter; Prohibition And Penalties
7-1-3: Owner To Maintain Premises Free Of Litter
7-1-3A: Placement And Storage Of Containers And Dumpsters
7-1-4: Penalties
7-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
GARBAGE: Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
LITTER: "Garbage", "refuse" and "rubbish" as defined herein and all other waste
material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a
danger to public health, safety and welfare.
PARK: A park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other
public area in the Village, owned or used by the Village and devoted to active
or passive recreation.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other
public ways and any and all public squares, spaces, grounds and buildings.
REFUSE: All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes),
including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals and solid
market and industrial wastes.
RUBBISH: Nonputrescible solid waste consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible waste, including, but not limited to, paper, wrappings,
cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding,
crockery, mattresses, discarded furniture and appliances, and similar
materials. (1971 Code; amd. Ord. 584, 11-23-1992)
7-1-2: LITTER; PROHIBITION AND PENALTIES:
No person shall:
   (A)   Litter In Public Places: Throw or deposit litter in or upon any
street, sidewalk or other public place within the Village except in public
receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection or in official
Village dumps.
   (B)   Litter Thrown By Persons In Vehicles: While a driver or passenger in a
vehicle, throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within
the Village, or upon private property.
   (C)   Dropping Litter From Aircraft: While in an aircraft, throw out, drop
or deposit within the Village any litter, handbill or any other object.
   (D)   Litter In Parks: Throw or deposit litter in any park within the
Village except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will
be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of
the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are
not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person
responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere.
   (E)   Truckloads Causing Litter: Drive or move any truck or other vehicle
within the Village unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to
prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any
street, alley or other public place.
   (F)   Litter On Private Property: Throw or deposit litter on any private
property within the Village, whether owned by such person or not. Such person
in control of private property shall maintain authorized private receptacles
for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being
carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public
place or upon private property.
   (G)   Litter On Vacant Lots: Throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant
private property within the village whether owned by such person or not. (1971
Code)
   (H)   Violation: Violation of any provision of this section shall be
punishable by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 817, 5-14-2007)
7-1-3: OWNER TO MAINTAIN PREMISES FREE OF LITTER:
The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times
maintain the premises free of litter. Provided, however, that this section
shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for
collection. (1971 Code)
7-1-3A: PLACEMENT AND STORAGE OF CONTAINERS AND DUMPSTERS:
   (A)   Except as provided in subsection (B) of this section, containers and
dumpsters shall at all times be stored and kept within side and rear lot lines
of any premises owned or occupied by the person or persons who own or use such
containers and dumpsters, and containers and dumpsters shall further be stored
and kept behind the front (and side for corner lots) setback lines established
for any structure on such premises.
   (B)   For garbage collection purposes only, containers and dumpsters and
materials described in subsection (C) of this section, may be placed in the
parkway area in front of any premises at or near the curb line no sooner than
the day preceding the regularly scheduled garbage collection day for such
premises and shall be removed no later than the day next following such
regularly scheduled garbage collection day.
   (C)   Except as provided in subsection (B) of this section, no privately
owned container or dumpster shall be stored or kept in or on any street,
sidewalk, alley, or other public place or public property within the village.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner of the
container or dumpster, occupant, tenant, or members of their families, or a
scavenger employed or licensed by the village, or the owner's agent, employees,
or servant, to deposit any article, substance, or thing in any container or
dumpster, or to remove, displace, injure, deface, destroy, uncover, or in any
manner disturb such container or dumpster, or any container or dumpster that is
placed at any curb line for collection.
   (E)   Any litter, garbage, refuse, or rubbish not placed in a container or
dumpster shall, for garbage collection purposes, be placed in such other secure
bag or container, and shall be placed for collection no sooner than the day
preceding the regularly scheduled garbage collection day for such premises.
(Ord. 583, 11-23-1992)
7-1-4: PENALTIES:
Violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of not
less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation is continued or permitted
to continue shall constitute a separate offense, and shall be punishable as
such. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 2
CESSPOOLS; PRIVIES
SECTION:
7-2-1: Construction To Comply With Regulations
7-2-2: Maintenance Of Privy Near Other Buildings
7-2-3: Privies In Places Of Human Habitation
7-2-4: Watertight Cesspool Required
7-2-5: Contents Not To Become Offensive
7-2-6: Abatement Of Offensive Contents
7-2-7: Overflowing
7-2-8: Removal; Permit Required
7-2-9: Disinfection
7-2-10: Depositing Garbage In Wells
7-2-11: Wells And Cisterns To Be Adequately Covered
7-2-12: Cistern Overflow Pipes
7-2-13: Privies Prohibited
7-2-14: Privies To Be Demolished
7-2-1: CONSTRUCTION TO COMPLY WITH REGULATIONS:
No vault, privy, catch basin or cesspool shall hereafter be constructed or
rebuilt in the Village except in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter
and the regulations of the Board of Health. (1971 Code)
7-2-2: MAINTENANCE OF PRIVY NEAR OTHER BUILDINGS:
It shall be unlawful and it is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to
erect or maintain any privy within forty feet (40') of any street, dwelling,
ship, school, factory, church or public hall, or within one hundred feet (100')
of any well, unless the same is furnished with a substantial vault, six feet
(6') deep and made tight so that the contents cannot escape therefrom and is
sufficiently secured and enclosed. (1971 Code)
7-2-3: PRIVIES IN PLACES OF HUMAN HABITATION:
It shall be unlawful to have the general privy accommodations of any place of
human habitation within any such place of habitation, or under any sidewalk
adjacent thereto. (1971 Code)
7-2-4: WATERTIGHT CESSPOOL REQUIRED:
All cesspools shall be watertight. (1971 Code)
7-2-5: CONTENTS NOT TO BECOME OFFENSIVE:
The contents of any tub, or of any receptacle, cesspool, privy, catch basin,
vault, sink, water closet, cistern or any thing in any room excavation, vat,
building, premises or place shall not be allowed to become a nuisance or
offensive, so as to be dangerous or prejudicial to health. (1971 Code)
7-2-6: ABATEMENT OF OFFENSIVE CONTENTS:
All privies or catch basins, any part of the contents of which are above the
surface, or within two feet (2') of the surface of the earth, and all other
privies or catch basins that are foul, omitting smells and odors that are
prejudicial to the public health, are hereby declared nuisances, and the Health
Officer shall have the power to abate the same, as provided in Section
6-3-3-1 of this Code. (1971 Code)
7-2-7: OVERFLOWING:
No person shall draw off or allow to run off onto any ground, street or place
of the Village the contents or any part thereof, of any vault, cistern,
cesspool or catch basin; nor shall any owner, tenant or occupant of any
building to which any vault, catch basin, privy or cesspool shall appertain or
be attached permit the contents, or any part thereof, to flow therefrom or to
rise within two feet (2') of any part of the top, or such contents to become
offensive; nor shall any privy or any other structure mentioned in this Section
be filled with or covered with dirt, until its filthy contents shall be
emptied. (1971 Code)
7-2-8: REMOVAL; PERMIT REQUIRED:
The owner, tenant or occupant of any building or premises within the Village
shall not cause or permit any part of the contents of any privy, vault, catch
basin or cesspool over which he has control to be removed, except according to
a permit issued by the Health Officer and subject to any rules of the Board of
Health for removing the same. (1971 Code)
7-2-9: DISINFECTION:
All privies, catch basins, vaults and cesspools, when cleaned, shall be
disinfected with freshly burned lime, and the work of such disinfection shall
be done by the person removing such contents. (1971 Code)
7-2-10: DEPOSITING GARBAGE IN WELLS:
No person shall throw into or deposit in any well, vault, sink, privy, catch
basin, or cesspool any offal, ashes, meat, fish, garbage, or any other
substance, nor shall any slops or kitchen waste be allowed to run into any well
or privy without regard to whether such well, vault, sink, privy, catch basin,
or cesspool is presently in use or is abandoned or not in use by its owner.
(Ord. 253, 4-8-1974)
7-2-11: WELLS AND CISTERNS TO BE ADEQUATELY COVERED:
The owner or occupant of any dwelling, building or other structure within the
Village is hereby required to place and maintain suitable coverings over all
wells or cisterns outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or
within any unoccupied or abandoned building, dwelling or structure, that is
accessible to children. (1971 Code)
7-2-12: CISTERN OVERFLOW PIPES:
No cistern used for the collection and storage of rainwater from roofs shall
have its overflow pipes directly connected with any sewer. Wherever an overflow
pipe is provided for such cistern, such pipe shall lead to an area or gutter
and shall have its outlet protected with a suitable metal screen. (1971 Code)
7-2-13: PRIVIES PROHIBITED:
No permit to construct a privy upon property served by the sanitary sewer of
the Village shall be issued to any person. (1971 Code)
7-2-14: PRIVIES TO BE DEMOLISHED:
Within six (6) months of the installation of a State-approved septic system or
sanitary sewer system capable of serving the property upon which any privy is
located, such privy shall be demolished and filled in. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 3
TOBACCO PRODUCTS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Definitions
7-3-2: Sale, Use And Possession Of Tobacco Products
7-3-3: Enforcement
7-3-4: Penalties
7-3-5: Severability
7-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation and enforcement of
this chapter:
POSSESSION: To have upon one's person or have in close proximity or in one's
control.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco (which means tobacco in
any form which is suitable for dipping and/or chewing), or tobacco in any form.
(Ord. 634, 7-14-1997)
7-3-2: SALE, USE AND POSSESSION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS:
   (A)   Sale To And Use Of Tobacco Products By A Minor: It shall be unlawful
for any person, whether acting individually, or as an owner, officer, employee
or agent of or on behalf of any person, firm, or corporation to sell, buy for,
distribute samples of, furnish, exchange or give away any tobacco product in
any form to any individual under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   (B)   Possession Of Tobacco Products By A Minor: No individual under
eighteen (18) years of age shall have in his or her possession any tobacco
product in any of its forms. It shall not be a violation of this section for
any such person to have in his or her possession tobacco products while in the
presence of his or her parents or legal guardian, or in the performance of a
religious ceremony or while participating in any theatrical performance where
possession of a tobacco product is necessary. (Ord. 634, 7-14-1997)
7-3-3: ENFORCEMENT:
The observation of a violation of subsection
7-3-2(B) of this chapter shall not constitute the sole reason for law
enforcement authorities to stop a motor vehicle in which an alleged offender is
a driver or passenger. (Ord. 634, 7-14-1997)
7-3-4: PENALTIES:
   (A)   A violation of subsection
7-3-2(A) of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine as established in
section
1-4-1 of this code.
   (B)   A violation of subsection
7-3-2(B) of this chapter may be punishable by a fine as established in section
1-4-1 of this code. In addition to or in lieu of a fine or any other penalty
assessed upon a finding of guilt, admission of guilt or admission of the
commission of a first or second violation of subsection
7-3-2(B) of this chapter a final disposition may include community service,
education alternatives or any similar program authorized by the village board.
However, any nonfine disposition must be successfully completed by the offender
as deemed appropriate by the village board or a fine shall be assessed pursuant
to subsection
7-3-2(A) of this chapter. (Ord. 634, 7-14-1997; amd. Ord. 817, 5-14-2007)
7-3-5: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, clause or provision of this chapter or the application thereof
to any person or circumstance is held invalid by a court of competent
jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter or the application of such
sections, paragraphs, clauses or provisions to persons or circumstances other
than those to which it is held invalid shall not be affected hereby. (Ord. 634,
7-14-1997)
CHAPTER 4
GROUND WATER USE FOR POTABLE WATER SUPPLY
SECTION:
7-4-1: Definitions
7-4-2: Use Of Ground Water As Potable Water Supply Prohibited
7-4-3: Memorandum Of Understanding
7-4-4: Penalties
7-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust,
estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption, including, but
not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes, or
preparing foods. (Ord. 771, 9-27-2004)
7-4-2: USE OF GROUND WATER AS POTABLE WATER SUPPLY PROHIBITED:
Except for such uses or methods in existence before the effective date hereof,
the use or attempt to use as a potable water supply ground water from within
the corporate limits of the village of North Pekin in the area described below,
by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby
prohibited, except at points of withdrawal by the village of North Pekin.
The area prohibited is as described as follows:
Bounded on the north by the southern boundary of the former Amoco Oil Company
petroleum storage terminal;
Bounded on the east by Main Street;
Bounded on the west by the right of way for the Peoria and Pekin Union
Railroad; and
Bounded on the south by Market Street, Forest Drive, Glen Lane, and Plaines
Street. (Ord. 771, 9-27-2004)
7-4-3: MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING:
The mayor of the village of North Pekin is hereby authorized and directed to
enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Illinois environmental
protection agency (Illinois EPA), in which the village of North Pekin assumes
responsibility for tracking remediated sites, notifying the Illinois EPA of
changes to this chapter, and taking certain precautions when siting public
potable water supply wells. (Ord. 771, 9-27-2004)
7-4-4: PENALTIES:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine
of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. (Ord. 771, 9-27-
2004)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
SIDEWALKS; STREETS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Permit Required
8-1-2: Construction Of Sidewalks
8-1-3: Material
8-1-4: Dangerous Walks
8-1-5: Concrete Sidewalks
8-1-6: Private Construction; Report
8-1-7: Obstructions
8-1-8: Barricades
8-1-9: Excavations
8-1-10: Moving Buildings
8-1-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or lay any sidewalk upon any
of the streets and alleys in the Village without first having obtained
permission from the President and Board of Trustees to construct or lay the
same, according to the provisions hereof. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
8-1-2: CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS:
When any person directly interested shall make application to the President and
Board of Trustees for the construction of any sidewalk upon any of the streets
of the Village, the President and Board may order the construction of the same
under the supervision of the Superintendent of Streets, of such material, and
such width as they may direct. The cost of the material and the expense
incurred in the construction of such sidewalk shall be paid by the party
applying for the same, unless otherwise ordered by the President and Board;
provided that when the party applying for such sidewalk shall desire the same
to be over five feet (5') in width, the President and Board may so order, if
the party applying therefor shall agree to pay all necessary expense incurred
thereby, and enter into an obligation to keep such additional width of sidewalk
in good condition and repair, without any expense to the Village so long as
said sidewalk shall remain in use, and well and truly keep said Village free
from all harm, damages and costs of suits, actions, judgments and executions
that shall or may at any time arise, come or be brought against the Village on
account of any accident that may occur to any person by reason of said portion
of said sidewalk being out of repair or in a dangerous condition at any time
hereafter. (Ord. 691, 8-28-2000)
8-1-3: MATERIAL:
All sidewalks hereafter constructed in any portion of the Village shall be
composed of concrete and shall be of such width as shall be determined by
resolution of the President and Board of Trustees. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
8-1-4: DANGEROUS WALKS:
Whenever it is brought to the notice of the President of the Village or to the
Superintendent of Streets, that any sidewalk or part thereof in the Village has
become dangerous to the public safety, he shall cause the same to be
immediately repaired or removed and report such action to the next meeting of
the Board. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
8-1-5: CONCRETE SIDEWALKS:
All concrete sidewalks hereafter constructed in the Village shall be in
accordance with the specifications furnished by the Clerk as furnished by the
Board of Trustees, and when any person shall enter into any contract for the
construction of concrete sidewalks within the Village, before entering upon the
performance of the same, he shall file with the Clerk a bond in the penal sum
of two hundred dollars ($200.00) with good and sufficient security, to be
approved by the Clerk, conditioned that such sidewalk shall be constructed in
accordance with the plans and specifications furnished by the Clerk, and that
such sidewalks shall be by him kept in good condition and repair for the period
of one year after the completion thereof. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
8-1-6: PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION; REPORT:
When any person shall obtain permission to construct any sidewalk within the
Village, as hereinbefore provided, he shall construct the same under the
direction and supervision of the Street and Alley Committee, and according to
the plans and specifications furnished him by the Clerk, and when such sidewalk
is completed he shall apply to the Street and Alley Committee for their
acceptance of the same, and if the Street and Alley Committee shall refuse to
accept the same, he shall report to the Board of Trustees the amount of
sidewalk so constructed, the material composing the same, and the manner in
which it has been constructed, for their acceptance or rejection, and if the
President and Board of Trustees refuse to accept the same, he shall proceed at
once to rebuild it according to the plans and specifications furnished by the
Clerk. If he shall refuse or neglect to rebuild such sidewalk as herein
provided, and such sidewalk is in a dangerous condition or constructed contrary
to any of the provisions of this Code relating to sidewalks, the Superintendent
of Streets shall remove or rebuild the same as the President and Board of
Trustees may direct. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
8-1-7: OBSTRUCTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, throw or have or cause to be
placed any obstruction in or upon any sidewalk within the Village except as
authorized by any of the provisions of this Code. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
8-1-8: BARRICADES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, change or alter any barricade or
sign which has been placed upon any street or other place in the Village by the
Village, its officers or employees, and it shall be unlawful for any person to
drive or operate any motor vehicle or any other type of a vehicle on any street
or any other place in the Village, which street or place has been closed for
traffic or for any person to walk or go upon any street or to lead or drive any
horse or other animal upon any street or place within the Village which has
been closed for traffic. (Ord. 60, 11-7-1956)
8-1-9: EXCAVATIONS:
No person not authorized by the President of the Board of Trustees of the
Village shall make any excavations or do any plowing in any street or alley or
public grounds in the Village at any time. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
8-1-10: MOVING BUILDINGS:
No person shall remove or cause to be removed, any building through or along
any street or alley in the Village without permission of the President and
Board of Trustees of the Village first obtained therefor. (Ord. 8, 8-6-1947)
CHAPTER 2
RAILROADS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Duty Of Railroad Companies
8-2-2: Notice In Writing
8-2-3: Penalty For Failure To Comply
8-2-4: Failure To Keep Light And Watchman
8-2-5: Obstructing Streets
8-2-6: Blowing Whistle Prohibited
8-2-7: Speed Of Trains
8-2-8: Ringing Bell; Headlights
8-2-9: Enforcement
8-2-10: New Tracks Laid Prohibited
8-2-11: Duty Of Chief Of Police
8-2-1: DUTY OF RAILROAD COMPANIES:
