8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this
Chapter shall be as follows:
APPROVED: Acceptable to or accepted by the Superintendent of Public Works as
complying with the provisions of this Chapter.
COMBINED SEWER: A sewer intended to carry domestic sewage and such industrial
wastes as may be permitted, as well as storm and surface water.
DOMESTIC SEWAGE AND SANITARY SEWAGE: The water or discharge from toilet or
other household plumbing fixtures, wash water and dishwater, interior basement
drainage and other dirty water from places of human residence, business
buildings or institutions, but not including industrial wastes.
EMERGENCY: A sudden and unexpected condition, the making of remedies for which
cannot be postponed until a permit has been secured without endangering life or
property.
GROUND WATER: Water which is contained in or flows through the ground.
HOUSE SANITARY CONNECTION AND HOUSE CONNECTION: The conduit or pipe for
conveying domestic sewage from residences, human habitations, institutions,
stables, garages, business buildings or industries to the connection to a
sewer.
HOUSE STORM DRAIN AND HOUSE DRAIN: A pipe or conduit which is used to conduct
surface, storm, ground, roof and yard drainage away from any building.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: Liquid wastes or wastes used in or resulting from industrial
processes.
MANHOLE: An opening constructed on a sewer of sufficient size to permit a man
to gain access thereto.
PRIVATE SEWER: A privately owned sewer.
PUBLIC SEWER: A publicly owned sewer.
SATISFACTORILY OR SATISFACTORY: In a manner approved by the Superintendent of
Public Works as complying with the provisions of this Chapter.
SEPARATE SANITARY SEWER AND SANITARY SEWER: A sewer intended to carry domestic
sewage and such industrial wastes as may be permitted, without the admixture of
storm water.
SEWAGE: Liquid waste flowing in or from residences, human habitation,
institutions, stables, garages, business buildings and industries, and it may
consist of a combination of any one or more the these, and/or with such storm
and ground water as may be admitted to or find its way into the sewers.
SEWER: Any outside conduit, pipe or structure designed to convey sewage of any
kind and to serve two (2) or more properties within the corporate limits of the
Village, and shall include all manholes, intercepting chambers, pumping plants
and other appurtenances thereto within the corporate limits of the Village.
SEWER CONSTRUCTION WORK: The construction of any sewer for any purpose and
shall include house sanitary connections and house storm drains within the
corporate limits of the Village.
SEWERAGE: The works comprising the complete system of sewers, connection and
drains within the jurisdiction of the Village, including pumping stations,
manholes and appurtenances thereto necessary to the collection, treatment or
disposal of sewage, including sewage treatment plants.
SEWERAGE (Adjective): Having to do with the collection, treatment or disposal
of sewage.
SOLID WASTES: Includes garbage, ashes, rags, manure wastes, household food,
offal and other solids. The term "ashes" as herein employed shall include coal,
coke, wood and the residuum resulting from the combustion of any material or
substance and includes soot, cinders, slag and charcoal.
STORM WATER: That portion of rain, snow or sleet which flows off over the
surface of the ground, streets and structures into sewers and drainage channels
or into low points.
SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS: The person designated or appointed by the Board
of Trustees to administer the provisions of this Chapter.
VILLAGE SEWER OR SEWER OF THE VILLAGE: Refers to any sewer constructed, under
construction or maintained within the corporate limits of the Village and shall
include all manholes, intercepting chambers, pumping plants or other
appurtenances thereto. (1971 Code)
8-5-2: OFFICE CREATED:
As provided in Section
1-14-3 of this Code, the Superintendent of Public Works may appoint an employee
to serve as Superintendent of Sewers. (1971 Code)
8-5-3: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the superintendent of sewers:
   (A)   To examine and approve plans and specifications for sewer construction
work;
   (B)   To issue permits for such work upon the fulfillment by the applicant
of the provisions of this chapter therefor; (1971 Code)
   (C)   To collect fees as provided herein and to deliver all fees collected
to the village clerk or her duly authorized representative within fifteen (15)
days after the collection of any such fee or fees; (Ord. 282, 9-27-1976)
   (D)   To inspect sewers, including house sanitary connections and house
storm drains and the materials to be used therein;
   (E)   To conduct tests thereon;
   (F)   To issue certificates of approval;
   (G)   To keep records of actions taken and examination, inspections and
tests made, and of permits and certificates issued;
   (H)   To make a monthly report of his acts and doings to the board of
trustees; and
   (I)   To advise the public, when requested, in the manner of these
regulations relating to the sewerage system. (1971 Code)
8-5-4: WORKMANSHIP:
All workmanship in connection with the construction of any sewer or house
sanitary connection or house storm drain shall be of such character as to fully
secure the results sought to be obtained in all the sections of this chapter.
(1971 Code)
8-5-5: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Any persons, other than the actual bona fide owner of the premises involved,
who desires to engage or who shall hereafter engage at any time in the
construction, alteration or repair of any sewer, sanitary connection, or storm
drain for any other person in the village, shall make application to the
superintendent of public works for a license before commencing such work, and
shall deliver to the superintendent of public works the following: a) a
certificate of insurance in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00)
for any and all liability for personal injury and bodily injury, and in the
amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for property damage. Said
certificate of insurance shall certify that such applicant is insured to
indemnify and save harmless the village of and from all liability for damages
by reason of or resulting directly or indirectly from the construction,
alteration, maintenance or repair by such person of any sewer, sanitary
connection or storm drain or any work or act of omission or commission
incidental thereto or in connection therewith; b) certificate of insurance
showing the minimum statutory limits of workers' compensation coverage; and c)
a bond signed by the applicant and two (2) sureties in the amount of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or a corporate surety bond in the sum of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00). Said bond or certificate shall also be
conditioned upon the conformance by such applicant with all the conditions and
requirements of the provisions of this code, for performing such work, and
conditioned also upon the restoration by such applicant of the street, alley,
sidewalk and pavement disturbed by him so as to leave the same in as good
condition as before the work was undertaken. Such bond or certificate shall be
signed by the applicant for such license, and by the surety or sureties on such
bond or instrument or indemnification. Upon receipt of said bond or certificate
by said superintendent of public works, it shall be the duty of the
superintendent of public works to present same to the public works committee.
The chairperson of the public works committee shall present his or her
recommendation to the village board at the next regular meeting of said board
or at any special meeting called for that purpose for approval or rejection.
Upon approval of said bond or certificate by the board of trustees, the
superintendent of public works shall forthwith issue to such applicant a
license to engage in the construction, alteration or repair of sewers, sanitary
connections, and storm drains in said village. Each application for such
license shall be accompanied by a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and such
license shall run from May 1 of each year to May 1 of the following year.
Nothing herein contained shall be construed as preventing an individual from
constructing a sewer, house connection or storm drain for his own home or on
his own premises. However, this provision shall not be construed to exempt such
person from all other requirements specified in this chapter. (Ord. 766, 4-12-
2004)
8-5-6: PERMIT:
No sewer of any kind, public or private or house sanitary connection, or house
storm drain, shall be constructed or made, altered or repaired, nor shall a
connection of any sewer or house sanitary connection or house storm drain to
any sewer, public or private, be constructed or made, altered or repaired
without first having obtained from the superintendent of public works a written
permit therefor. No permit shall be issued for such construction, alteration or
repair work until the plans and specifications therefor, or required data
concerning it, have first been submitted to and approved by the superintendent
of public works.
Before issuing such permit, an application shall be filed with the
superintendent of public works, and all applications for permits shall be in
writing on blanks to be furnished by the superintendent of public works. The
application shall be signed by the owner of the premises on which the proposed
work is to be done and shall be accompanied by a complete and legible set of
plans and specifications for the work to be done, or in lieu thereof such
written description or information as shall be acceptable to the superintendent
of public works.
All details concerning the construction of any sewer or house storm drains and
their appurtenances shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent of
public works. (1971 Code)
8-5-7: PERMIT FEE; LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES:
Each application for such permit shall be accompanied by a fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) and each applicant, if he be the owner of the premises upon which the
proposed work is to be done by him personally, shall upon the granting of the
permit agree to indemnify and save the village harmless from any and all
liability for damages to persons or property by reason of or resulting directly
or indirectly from the construction, alteration, maintenance or repair by such
person of any sewer, sanitary connection or storm drain, or any work or act of
omission or commission by such person incidental thereto or in connection
therewith. Each applicant shall further agree to conform to all of the
conditions and requirements of the provisions of this code for performing such
work, and conditioned also upon the restoration by such applicant of the
street, alley, sidewalk and pavement disturbed by him so as to leave the same
in as good a condition as before the work was undertaken. Upon inspection of
said work, and approval by the public works department of the work performed,
the fifty dollar ($50.00) permit fee shall be refunded to the applicant.
It is expressly stipulated and provided, however, that if application for a
permit specifies that the work therein described is to be performed by a person
licensed to perform such work under the provision of section
8-5-5 of this chapter, no further bond shall be required as a condition to the
issuance of such permit.
No applicant owing money to the village for fees required by this chapter even
for the work described in any such application or for any previous work
performed, or inspections made hereunder, shall be granted a permit for such
work. (Ord. 964, 2-10-2014)
8-5-8: FORFEITURE OF PERMIT OR LICENSE:
Any person or other party to whom a permit or license shall have been issued
and who shall neglect, refuse or fail to make good any defect or fault in any
of the work done or materials used under any permit or license after thirty
(30) days' written notice thereof from the superintendent of public works,
shall not be permitted to do any further or additional work of constructing any
sewer, connection or drain or appurtenances until such defects or faults have
been made good in manner satisfactory to the superintendent of public works. In
the event of such neglect, refusal or failure, any existing permit or license
in favor of such person or other party shall be revoked by the superintendent
of public works and the bond of such person enforced as to past defaults. (1971
Code)
8-5-9: CHANGES IN PLANS:
Any changes or modifications in the proposed work shall be considered as new
work, and no such changes or modifications shall be installed or made without a
supplementary permit therefor, subject to the same terms and conditions as
herein contained. The fee for such supplementary permits shall be two dollars
($2.00). (1971 Code)
8-5-10: EXPIRATION OF PERMIT:
If the work is not commenced under any permit within six (6) months after the
issue of said permit, or if the work is not satisfactorily prosecuted after its
commencement, such permit will be considered as having expired and shall be
null and void. (1971 Code)
8-5-11: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
   (A)   All property owners within the village are required to attach any
operating human waste disposal systems on their property to available lateral
sanitary sewer mains, in such a manner that no sewage is discharged except into
said mains.
   (B)   For the purposes of this section, "available lateral sanitary sewer
mains" shall mean lateral sanitary sewer mains within two hundred feet (200')
of any property line describing the lot or tract in question, and which empty
into a disposal plant approved by the state.
   (C)   This section shall not apply to persons who bring their property into
compliance with the requirements of this section within twelve (12) months
after the date of completion of available lateral sewer mains, if there are no
available lateral sanitary sewer mains for the property in question at the time
of passage of this section, provided that said property is maintained in
compliance with said requirements thereafter.
   (D)   For the purposes of this Section "date of completion of available
lateral sanitary sewer mains" shall mean the date upon which the Village Board
certifies that said mains are completed and ready for use.
   (E)   Notwithstanding subsection (C) of this Section, discharge of human
waste at any time in such a manner or location so as to create a health hazard
shall be a violation of this Section, said violation to be subject to the
penalties of this Section.
   (F)   The discharge of sewage in violation of any of the provisions of this
Section shall constitute and is hereby declared to constitute a public
nuisance.
   (G)   Any person violating the provisions of this Section shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount
not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall
constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
   (H)   No septic tank or cesspool now existing or hereafter constructed shall
be connected in any way, directly or indirectly, to the public sewer system.
   (I)   Notwithstanding the time limit imposed under subsection (C) of this
Section, any operating human waste disposal systems of any new dwelling, house
or commercial building completed after the date of completion of available
lateral sanitary sewer mains shall be connected to said available lateral
sanitary sewer mains in such a manner that no sewage is discharged except into
said mains. (Ord. 276, 5-10-1976)
8-5-12: PROTECTION OF SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM:
   (A)   The separate sanitary sewer system of the Village was built to carry
away the domestic or sanitary sewage, the commercial sewage, and as may be
permitted, the industrial wastes of the Village. It was not designed to carry
any storm water, surface water, or ground water. Any act which shall cause any
storm water, surface water or ground water to be conveyed to and into the
sanitary sewers is herewith directly forbidden. Furthermore, such drainage is
forbidden within the sewers of the Village. Such acts are directly contrary to
the provisions of this Chapter and shall be subject to the penalties provided
in this Code. (Ord. 692, 8-28-2000)
   (B)   The sanitary or domestic sewage from all buildings in general shall be
conveyed in house sanitary connections to the public system of sanitary sewers.
Sanitary or domestic sewage shall include basement floor drainage; however,
this shall not include any storm or ground water intentionally conveyed to the
sanitary sewer system. (1971 Code)
8-5-13: NEW BUILDINGS, CESSPOOLS, SEPTIC OR SEWAGE TANKS:
   (A)   No cesspool, septic or other sewage tank shall be constructed
hereafter on property to which a public sanitary sewer is accessible.
   (B)   No septic tank or cesspool hereafter constructed shall be connected in
any way, directly or indirectly, to the public sewer system. (1971 Code)
8-5-14: SEWAGE TREATMENT REQUIRED:
   (A)   Where liquid wastes from any source are not discharged into a public
sewer, such wastes shall be treated or disposed of so as not to endanger or
contaminate any water supply that is or may be used for drinking or domestic
purposes or for bathing or so as not to create any nuisance or unsanitary
conditions which shall be considered either by the Superintendent of Public
Works or the Health Department of the Village as dangerous and unhealthy to the
residents and citizens of the Village.
   (B)   The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having:
1) a five (5) day biochemical oxygen demand greater than three hundred (300)
parts per million by weight of suspended solids, or 2) containing more than
three hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight of suspended solids, or
3) having an average daily flow greater than two percent (2%) of the average
daily sewage flow of the Village shall be subject to the review and approval of
the Village. Where necessary, the owner shall provide, at his expense, such
preliminary treatment as may be necessary to: 1) reduce the biochemical oxygen
demand to three hundred (300) parts per million and the suspended solids to
three hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight, or 2) reduce
objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits
provided for in item 1) herein, or 3) control the quantities and rates of
discharge of such waters or wastes. Plans, specifications and any other
pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities
shall be submitted for the approval of the Engineer and no construction of such
facilities shall be commenced until said approval is obtained in writing. (1971
Code)
8-5-15: INDUSTRIAL WASTES AND SEWAGE:
No person shall discharge or cause or permit the discharge of industrial wastes
into any public sewer system which directly or indirectly discharges into the
sewer system of the Village without the approval of the Superintendent of
Public Works and the Board of Trustees. (1971 Code)
8-5-16: NOTICE:
In every case of a proposed sewer connection, notice shall be given to the
Superintendent of Public Works specifying the time and place where the work is
to commence. Such notice shall be in writing and given at least three (3) full
days prior to the commencement of the work. (1971 Code)
8-5-17: SEWER CONNECTIONS:
   (A)   All connections with any sewer fifteen inches (15") or smaller shall
be made by means of a "Y" or "T" branch or other special fitting provided in
such sewer for that purpose.
If a connection to a sewer must be made at any place where a "Y" or "T" branch
has not been placed, where feasible, a "Y" fitting shall be placed in the main
sewer in the following manner: a section of sewer pipe shall be removed from
the main sewer by breaking it into pieces, care being taken not to break,
disturb or injure the adjacent pipe. The "Y" fitting shall then be inserted
without chipping or breaking the pipe or branch where possible; where not
possible, the upper half (when in position) of the bell on the run of the "Y"
branch to be inserted, and the upper half of the nearest and adjacent bell on
the existing pipe in the trench, shall then be carefully removed and the "Y"
branch inserted wrong side up, and revolved to bring the branch to the side it
is intended for, with the broken part of the bell up. The joint shall then be
cemented in the proper manner, the broken parts of the bells being well rounded
over with a liberal amount of cement mortar or other approved material.
   (B)   Connections to a sewer may also be made by inserting in the sewer a
standard saddle fitting. Such a fitting shall be one designed for that purpose
and shall not be improvised from the bell end of a straight length of pipe.
Before cutting the hole in the sewer of the saddle fitting, the sides and
bottom of the length of pipe in which the hole is to be cut shall be
strengthened by a layer of concrete not less than three inches (3") in
thickness at any point. The hole in the pipe shall be carefully marked and
chipped or pinched out; the saddle placed so that no part projects into the
pipe and carefully mortared into position. Sections of pipe shall then be
fitted into the saddle to form a riser and all such pieces of pipe which are
vertically over the sewer shall be encased in a shaft of concrete having a
thickness about the pipe of not less than three inches (3"). The shaft shall
firmly rest on the block of concrete encasing the sewer pipe in which the
connection was made. The concrete shaft shall be poured into a form of light
sheet metal or stove pipe which form shall be left in place as the trench is
backfilled. The earth backfill around the shaft shall be carefully tamped and
the backfill brought up uniformly on all sides to prevent lateral loads upon
and the possible breaking of the shaft. (1971 Code)
8-5-18: QUALITY OF MATERIALS:
All materials used in any sewer, house sanitary connection or house storm
drain, or part thereof, shall be free from defects.
   (A)   Vitrified Clay Or Concrete Pipe: All vitrified clay pipe shall conform
to American Society for Testing Materials specification C 200-73T (extra
strength). All concrete pipe shall conform to American Society for Testing
Materials specification C-76 Class III.
   (B)   Cast Iron Pipe: All cast iron pipe and fittings used for sewers, house
connections or drains shall be coated with asphaltum or coal-tar pitch and
shall conform to the standard specifications for extra heavy cast iron soil
pipe and fittings of the American Society for Testing Materials, or shall
conform to the latest standard specifications for cast iron water pipe of the
American Water Works Association.
   (C)   PVC Pipe: PVC pipe shall be used only for house sanitary connections.
PVC pipe used for house sanitary connections shall conform with American
Society for Testing Materials specifications 3034, SDR 35. Appropriate adapters
shall be used in making transitions between vitrified clay pipe and PVC pipe or
between cast iron pipe and PVC pipe.
   (D)   Prohibited Material: Not permitted for use in any sewer connection or
construction are pipes known as "slip seal" or fiber (Orangeburg) pipe. (Ord.
275, 5-3-1976)
8-5-19: JOINTS AND CONNECTIONS:
   (A)   Precast Asphalt Joints: All joints in new sanitary sewers and house
sanitary connections wherein vitrified pipe shall be used shall consist of
precast asphalt, cement or other types of asphalt joints of proper workmanship.
   (B)   Cement Joints: In the event that cement joints shall be made, such
cement joints shall be made as follows: The space between the pipe and socket
shall be as uniform as possible and shall be tightly caulked with a dry jute or
oakum. The jute or oakum shall be long enough to reach entirely around the pipe
and thick enough to bring the bottom of the pipes to the same level. It shall
be well caulked into place with suitable yarning tools. After it is in place
the joint shall be solidly and completely filled with Portland cement mortar
composed by volume of not less than one part Portland cement to one of clean
sand thoroughly mixed dry, sufficient water being afterwards slowly added to
give with mixing the proper consistency. Said mortar shall be used as soon as
made and shall be solidly rammed into the joints and finished with a bevel
outside the bell in such a manner as to produce a watertight joint. Joints
shall be carefully wiped inside and out. The interior of the pipe shall be
carefully freed from all dirt, cement or superfluous materials as the work
proceeds. No cement joint as above described, shall be laid in any sanitary
sewer or house sanitary connection or commercial building connection without
approval therefor from the superintendent of public works. (1971 Code)
   (C)   PVC Pipe: Joints in PVC pipe shall be made only with rubber gaskets.
Solvent joints in PVC pipe are prohibited, except at "Y's", "T's" and elbow
joints.
   (D)   Cast Iron Pipe: All joints in cast iron pipe shall be lead joints,
except that a "mission" type coupling is hereby required when joining cast iron
pipe to plastic pipe or clay tile. (Ord. 604, 12-12-1994)
   (E)   Lead Joints: In jointing two (2) pipes, the spigot end shall be
properly seated in the adjacent bell and adjusted so as to give a uniform space
for the joint, which will be made with twisted hemp packing and soft pig lead.
The packing shall be thoroughly driven into the bell so that the lead, after
having been poured and caulked into the joint, shall have a depth of at least
two inches (2"). The joints shall be thoroughly caulked with proper tools.
(1971 Code)
8-5-20: PROHIBITED SUBSTANCES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to permit or cause the flow of any of the
following substances into the sanitary sewer system of the village:
      1.   Grease, Oil, And Sand: Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be
provided when, in the opinion of the North Pekin superintendent of public
works, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing
grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful
ingredients. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the
North Pekin superintendent of public works, and shall be located as to be
readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. All such facilities
must be adequately and properly operated and maintained by the owner so as to
prevent the discharge of such substances into the village sewer system.
      2.   Stone Dust, Sand, Dirt: Any stone dust, sand, dirt, gravel, sawdust,
metal filings, broken glass or any material which may cause or create an
obstruction in the sewer.
      3.   Foreign Matter: No butcher's offal, garbage, dead animals, or
liquids containing silt, hair, feathers, fibers, grease and oil in excess of
one hundred milligrams per liter (100 mg/l), or other obstructing materials
shall be permitted to enter any public sewer.
      4.   Harmful Wastes: Acid, corrosive, or harmful wastes, and wastes at a
temperature higher than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) shall not
be discharged into any public sewer.
      5.   Explosives; Flammable Matter: No explosive or flammable matter shall
be discharged into any public sewer.
      6.   Milk Products: Milk or any liquid milk waste products in quantities
in excess of ten (10) gallons during each twenty four (24) hour period.
   (B)   If a facility is known to have caused the village sewer system to be
blocked or is known to allow large deposits to develop in the system, all costs
to have the system returned to normal operation shall be billed to said
facility.
   (C)   Existing facilities that cause the aforesaid substances (subsection
(A)3 of this section) in their waste entering the village sewer system must
install an outside interceptor designed for the maximum flow of the facility by
a licensed engineer. All costs incurred for testing, engineering and
installation shall be paid by the owner of the facility. Said facilities shall
have thirty (30) days to design and install said interceptor.
   (D)   Before construction, new facilities that are known to produce the
aforesaid substances must install an outside interceptor designed by the
owners, engineers, or architects for the anticipated maximum flows. The village
board of trustees must approve the plans before any work is to begin and before
any permits are issued for said construction.
   (E)   The maintenance of now existing and new interceptors must be
documented in a written, understandable form. The maintenance record must be
kept for at least the previous five (5) years and must include the date the
interceptor was cleaned, to where the waste was removed and by whom the
interceptor was cleaned. These records must be accessible to the village
superintendent of public works during normal business hours.
   (F)   All waste must be disposed of and hauled away by an EPA licensed waste
hauler. Records of the waste removal must be kept for inspection by the village
superintendent of public works for a period of five (5) years and can be
accessed during normal business hours. (Ord. 731, 10-14-2002)
8-5-21: CHEMICALS:
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to flow into the sanitary sewer system
any cyanide, phenols or any other chemical or substance which interferes with
or prevents the functioning of the sewage treatment plant. (1971 Code)
8-5-22: DISTURBING, INJURING OR ENTERING SEWERS:
No person other than an authorized village employee shall disturb, or enter any
public sewer, manhole, catch basin or other part of the public sewer system
without a written permit from the superintendent of public works. (1971 Code)
8-5-23: TRAPS AND RECEIVING TANKS:
   (A)   Gasoline And Oil Traps Required: A gasoline and oil trap shall be
provided on the waste from all garages, automobile wash floors, cleaning
establishments or establishments from which gasoline, benzine or other similar
substance may be discharged. Said trap shall be installed on the waste pipe
above its junction with any other pipe or receptacle containing sewage. The
passing of human or animal excrement through such a trap is prohibited.
   (B)   Grease Traps Required: A trap designed for the collection of grease or
other fatty materials shall be installed in all restaurants, taverns, or other
locations or establishments engaged in the cooking or preparation of food for
sale to the public. Said trap shall be installed on the waste pipe above its
junction with any other pipe or receptacle containing sewage. The passing of
human or animal excrement through such a trap is prohibited. The trap shall be
cleaned and maintained as often as is necessary to prevent the discharge of any
grease or other fatty material into the sanitary sewer system of the Village.
   (C)   Sumps And Receiving Tanks: In a building in which the whole or part of
the plumbing system lies below the house connection to the public sewer the
outlet from said plumbing system or part thereof shall discharge into a sump or
receiving tank from which the sewage shall be pumped through a pipe to the
house connection or to the public sewer.
The said sump or receiving tank shall be adequate in capacity. It should be
discharged not less frequently than once each hour. It shall be constructed in
a watertight and substantial manner of masonry, vitrified clay or metal. It
shall be provided with an airtight cover. Any pipe discharging into the sump or
receiving tank shall not be submerged.
No storm, surface or ground water shall be conducted to a sump or tank
receiving domestic sewage. Such water may be conducted to a separate sump for
the purpose of pumping it to the surface of the ground or to a storm sewer if
such exists. (Ord. 368, 2-22-1982)
8-5-24: FUNCTION OF HOUSE CONNECTIONS AND DRAINS:
The domestic sewage from residences, human habitations, institutions, stables,
garages, business buildings and industries shall be conveyed from said
structures in a conduit or pipe herein termed a "house sanitary connection".
The connection shall extend to a public separate sanitary or combined sewer, if
such sewer serves the property. No storm, surface or ground water shall be
permitted to enter this house sanitary connection discharging into a sewer. No
sanitary sewage shall be discharged into a separate storm sewer. (1971 Code)
8-5-25: INDEPENDENT CONNECTIONS AND DRAINS:
Each residence, institution or business building shall have its own separate
house sanitary connection. A house sanitary connection shall not be permitted
to serve more than one residence or other unit except connections for duplexes,
apartment houses or other multiple unit users, and then only by express
permission of the Superintendent of Public Works. (1971 Code)
8-5-26: MATERIALS:
   (A)   House sanitary connections shall be of six inch (6") vitrified clay,
concrete, or PVC pipe, except within five feet (5') of the outside of a
building it shall be of four inch (4") or six inch (6") cast iron or ductile
iron pipe.
   (B)   All underground pipes when within four feet (4') or less of the
surface of the ground under a driveway shall be cast iron pipe or of vitrified
clay pipe having an envelope of concrete of a mix of 1:2:4 or better and at
least three inches (3") in thickness.
   (C)   Where a connection or drain is laid at a distance less than five feet
(5') from the exterior wall of the building, or in ground where it will be
subjected to a vibration or to settlement, cast iron pipe shall be used. Where
the ground is of sufficient solidity for a proper foundation or where special
supports or a secure foundation are provided, vitrified clay, concrete, PVC,
cast iron, or ductile iron pipes may be used. (Ord. 275, 5-3-1976)
8-5-27: LAYING:
No house sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet (3') of any
bearing wall which might thereby be weakened. The house sewer shall be laid at
sufficient depth to protect it from frost.
All sewer and drain pipes shall be laid carefully in a trench in a straight
line and on a straight grade. Where deviation from a straight run is necessary,
it shall be made with a curve or other acceptable fitting.
In the bottom of the trench a groove shall be cut for each hub, in order to
give the pipe a solid bearing for its entire length, and the soil backfill
shall be well rammed on either side of the pipe. (1971 Code)
8-5-28: PIPES TO BE CLOSED:
The ends of all pipes not to be immediately connected shall be securely stopped
by tile, brick, cement or other watertight and durable material. (1971 Code)
8-5-29: BACKWATER:
Where the plumbing system of a building may be subjected to backflow of sewage
or water, suitable provision shall be made to prevent overflow into the
building by the installation of a satisfactory backwater valve or valves or
other satisfactory means. (1971 Code)
8-5-30: STORM, SURFACE AND GROUND WATER:
No roofs or outside areas of any kind shall be drained into any house
connection which drains into a sewer and no roof downspouts or conductors shall
in any case be discharged directly or indirectly into the house connection and
thence into a sewer in the Village. (1971 Code)
8-5-31: INSPECTIONS:
All piping and appurtenances of a sewer system or house sanitary connections
shall be inspected by the Superintendent of Public Works to ensure compliance
with all the requirements of this Chapter and the installation and construction
of the system in accordance with any approved plan and the permit. (1971 Code)
8-5-32: NOTIFICATION:
It shall be the duty of the owner or his agent to notify the Superintendent of
Public Works orally, by telephone, or in writing not less than eight (8)
working hours before the work is to be inspected and have a time set for the
inspection.
If the Superintendent of Public Works finds on inspection that the work and
materials entered into said work are not satisfactory, the owner or his agent
shall remedy said defect and then renotify the Superintendent of Public Works
as above and arrange for a reinspection.
If the Superintendent of Public Works fails to appear within twenty four (24)
hours of the time set for an inspection, the inspection shall be deemed to have
been made. (1971 Code)
8-5-33: DEFECTIVE WORK:
If upon inspection defects in material or in work shall be found, such defects
in work or materials shall be redone or replaced within three (3) days or as
the Superintendent of Public Works may direct, and the aforementioned
inspection shall be repeated. (1971 Code)
8-5-34: CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL:
If said sewer construction work is approved by the Superintendent of Public
Works, he shall issue a certificate of satisfactory inspection, but no
certificate shall be issued unless all sewer construction is in strict
conformity with the rules and regulations of this Chapter. (1971 Code)
8-5-35: FEES:
Before the certificate of satisfactory inspection is issued, all fees due the
Village in connection with the application for a permit required under the
terms of this Chapter shall have been paid to the Superintendent of Public
Works. (1971 Code)
8-5-36: CONDEMNED MATERIALS:
The presence of any material near the site of work, other than provided for in
this Chapter, shall be sufficient cause for condemning part or the entire work.
If inspection discloses defective material or unworkmanlike construction which
does not conform to the requirements of this Chapter, such defective material
or unworkmanlike construction shall be condemned and the owner or his agent
shall be removed within three (3) days following the condemnation thereof or as
the Superintendent of Public Works may direct. (1971 Code)
8-5-37: USE OF SEWERS PROHIBITED:
No part of any new, reconstructed or repaired sewer work shall be used for
which a certificate of approval has not been issued by the Superintendent of
Public Works. Any person attempting to use or flow any sewage into the public
sewer system for any new, reconstructed or repaired sewer work without
obtaining the certificate of approval as herein provided shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. In addition thereto, the Superintendent of Public Works shall
proceed forthwith to disconnect such new, reconstructed or repaired sewer work
for which no certificate of approval has been issued and may enter upon any
public or private property for the purpose of such disconnection. (1971 Code)
8-5-38: INSPECTION; RIGHT OF ENTRY:
In order that the sewers of the public sewer system may be fully protected
against improper use and injury, the Superintendent of Public Works shall have
free and unobstructed access to any part of any premises for the purpose of
examining the construction, condition and usage of house sanitary connections
and house storm drains at any time between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00)
A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. during said construction and at any time
thereafter. Any owner, occupant or other person refusing to allow said
Superintendent of Public Works access to the premises for such purpose shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor. (1971 Code)
8-5-39: CHARGES FOR USE OF VILLAGE SEWER:
There shall be and there is hereby established a minimum charge and a basic
user rate for the use of and for service supplied by the waste water facilities
of the Village.
Beginning January 1, 2018, a minimum charge of four dollars forty cents ($4.40)
per month shall be applied to all users. A basic user rate of four dollars
seventy three cents ($4.73) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water
discharged shall be applied to all users.
Beginning January 1, 2019, a minimum charge of four dollars eighty four cents
($4.84) per month shall be applied to all users. A basic user rate of five
dollars twenty cents ($5.20) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water
discharged shall be applied to all users.
Beginning January 1, 2020, a minimum charge of five dollars thirty two cents
($5.32) per month shall be applied to all users. A basic user rate of five
dollars seventy two cents ($5.72) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water
discharged shall be applied to all users.
Beginning January 1, 2021, a minimum charge of five dollars eighty five cents
($5.85) per month shall be applied to all users. A basic user rate of six
dollars twenty nine cents ($6.29) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water
discharged shall be applied to all users.
Beginning January 1, 2022, a minimum charge of six dollars forty three cents
($6.43) per month shall be applied to all users. A basic user rate of six
dollars ninety two cents ($6.92) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water
discharged shall be applied to all users.
The volume of waste water discharged shall be determined on or about the 15th
day of each month by the methods provided under the terms of this Code. The sum
determined to be due thereby shall be billed monthly on or about the 1st day of
each month.
The increase in rate shall be effective as of the dates above and shall be
reflected beginning with the invoices generated on January 1st of each year.
The Village reserves the right to make such reasonable changes in rates and the
conditions herein established and to establish further rules and regulations
from time to time as may be found expedient or necessary. (Ord. 1011, 11-13-
2017)
8-5-40: MEASUREMENT OF VOLUME OF WASTE DISCHARGED:
To compute basic user charges under this chapter, the volume of waste
discharged shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even
increments of one hundred (100) gallons.
   (A)   If the person discharging wastes into the public sewers procures any
part or all of his water from sources other than the public waterworks system,
all or a part of which is discharged into the public sewers, the person shall
install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type approved by the
Department of Public Works for the purpose of determining the volume of water
obtained from these other sources.
   (B)   Devices for measuring the volume of water discharged may be required
by the Department of Public Works if these volumes cannot be otherwise
determined by the metered water consumption records.
   (C)   Metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be
installed, owned and maintained by the person; following approval and
installation such meters may not be removed, unless service is canceled,
without the consent of the Department of Public Works.
   (D)   Any consumer may request that service be suspended for a specified
period of time. However, during such suspension of service, the consumer shall
continue to be charged the minimum charge outlined in section
8-5-39 of this chapter. (Ord. 1022, 8-27-2018)
8-5-41: INJURY TO PUBLIC SEWER SYSTEM:
No person or persons shall wilfully, maliciously or negligently break, deface,
destroy or injure any public sewer or appurtenances thereto in the Village.
(1971 Code)
8-5-42: INTERFERENCE WITH PUBLIC SEWER SYSTEM:
No person shall interfere with, molest, uncover, take off covers from manholes
or lamp holes, or disturb any portion of the public sewer system or
appurtenances thereto in the Village.
Any person or persons violating any of the provisions of this chapter or any
section thereof, shall become liable to the Village for any expense or damage
occasioned to the Village by reason of such violation, and in addition thereto
shall be subject to any of the fines and penalties as in this Code provided.
(1971 Code)
8-5-43: VIOLATION; REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
The permit or license of a sewer builder shall become void in the Village when
he shall refuse or neglect within three (3) days' time after notification
thereof in writing to make such necessary corrections to the sewer work either
in workmanship or material as shall have been ordered by the Superintendent of
Public Works, or as such person shall permit the use of his name by another
person or persons for the purpose of obtaining a permit or license to do sewer
work.
Any sewer builder who shall construct or install any sewer work in violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter, and any builder, contractor, architect
or designer designing, drawing or issuing plans for or having charge of such
sewer work or who shall permit it to be so constructed or installed shall be
liable to the penalties provided or imposed in this code. (1971 Code)
8-5-44: FEES FOR ATTACHING TO SEWER SYSTEM:
   (A)   A connection fee in an amount determined as hereinafter set forth
shall be charged for any extension of any sanitary sewer mains or the
installation of any new "tee" or other tap- in to the village's sanitary sewer
system. The connection fee shall be in the following amount:
      1.   For each single-family residence or residential site, the sum of two
hundred dollars ($200.00).
      2.   For each multiple-family residence, the sum of two hundred dollars
($200.00) for the first unit and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
additional unit.
      3.   For each residential lot zoned for the construction of two (2)
living units per lot, the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00).
      4.   For each residential lot zoned for the construction of more than two
(2) living units per lot, the sum of four hundred dollars ($400.00).
      5.   For commercial or industrial buildings or commercial or industrial
sites, the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per lot.
   (B)   In the case of buildings, lots, or parcels annexed to the village, the
fees herein provided shall be paid prior to commencing work on connection of
the respective building, lot or parcel to the sanitary sewer system.
   (C)   Where lots are created by the subdivision of property already lying
within the corporate limits of the village at the time of subdivision, the fee
herein provided shall be paid upon the approval of the plat of subdivision but
before assent to the subdivision is indicated on the plat for recording
purposes.
   (D)   The fee for such connection shall be in addition to any assessments
which may from time to time be levied against such parcels for the cost of
constructing, reconstructing or extending any sewer lines.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person, by himself or through his
employees, agents or contractors to connect or commence work on the connection
to the sanitary sewer system prior to the payment in full of any fees
prescribed in this section. (Ord. 390, 5-23-1983)
8-5-45: DELINQUENT CHARGES; LIEN:
   (A)   Whenever the charges for sewer service are not paid within fifteen
(15) days after the rendition of the bill therefor, such charges shall be
deemed and are hereby described to be delinquent, and thereafter the village
shall have a continuing lien upon the premises and real estate upon or for
which sewer is used or supplied.
   (B)   Every such lien shall, upon compliance with the conditions hereinafter
set forth, become and be prior and superior to the rights and interests of
creditors, encumbrances, purchasers and other parties in interest in the
premises and real estate. (Ord. 412, 9-10-1984)
8-5-46: AFFIDAVIT; RECORDING, NOTICE TO CONSUMER:
   (A)   Whenever a bill for sewer service remains unpaid fifteen (15) days
after it has been rendered, the village clerk shall file with the recorder of
deeds of Tazewell County, state of Illinois, a statement of lien claim verified
by the affidavit of herself or other officer of the village having knowledge of
the facts. The statement shall contain a sufficiently correct description of
the lot, lots or tracts of land to identify the same, the balance due after
allowing all credits, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this
amount, as well as for all charges for sewer supplied subsequent to the period
covered by the bill.
   (B)   No such lien shall be defeated to the proper amount thereof because of
an error or overcharge on the part of the village, nor shall any such lien be
defeated upon proof that such sewer was consumed or contracted for by a tenant
of the premises or occupant thereof other than the owner.
   (C)   If the consumer of sewer whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the
premises, and the village clerk has notice of this fact, notice shall be mailed
to the owner of the premises, if his address be known to the clerk, whenever
such bill remains unpaid for a period of fifteen (15) days after it has been
rendered.
   (D)   The failure of the clerk to record such lien claim or to mail such
notice, or the failure of the owner of such premises to receive such notice,
shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid sewer bills, as
provided in section
8-5-47 of this chapter. (Ord. 412, 9-10-1984)
8-5-47: ENFORCEMENT:
   (A)   If payment shall not be made as provided in this chapter, any amount
due for sewer service when the same becomes due, the village may file or cause
to be filed a complaint in the circuit court of Tazewell County for a
foreclosure of such lien or, upon becoming a defendant in any pending suit
affecting the premises or real estate, an answer to the complaint in the nature
of an intervening petition or a cross complaint, and the village may proceed in
its corporate name to foreclose such lien in like manner and with like effect
as provided by the statutes of the state in foreclosure of mechanic's liens or
other statutory liens. Such suit shall be commenced or answered by cross
complaint filed within two (2) years after the accrual of such sewer rates,
charges or benefits. Any decree rendered in the court may be enforced and
collected as other decrees or judgments in the same court.
   (B)   The remedy provided in this section for the collection of delinquent
sewer rates, charges or benefits shall not be construed to abridge or in any
manner interfere with the right and power of the village to enforce a
collection thereof by any other action or as otherwise provided in this
chapter, but the remedy herein provided shall be taken and held as an
additional means to enforce payment of such delinquent sewer rates, charges or
benefits. (Ord. 412, 9-10-1984)
8-5-48: RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR OF SEWER SYSTEM:
The village shall be responsible for the repair and maintenance of that portion
of the system located upon, on and under the village's right of way, or any
easement given to the village for installation of the sewer system. Any portion
of the sewer system located on, across, or under private property shall be
maintained and repaired at the expense and pursuant to the responsibility of
the property owner upon whose property such portion of the sewer system is
located. (Ord. 533, 6-10-1991)
CHAPTER 6
DRIVEWAYS

8-6-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall construct a driveway for vehicles or animals across any
sidewalk in the village without obtaining a permit therefor.
Applications for such permits shall be made to the clerk and shall be
accompanied by the fee required.
No permit for the construction of a driveway for commercial use, or the
habitual use of any other than the owner or occupant of the premises served,
shall be issued except upon the order of the board of trustees. (1971 Code)
8-6-2: FEE 1 :
(Rep. by Ord. 862, 10-15-2008)
 
Notes
1 2. See subsections
  10-13-2(A)5(j) and (A)5(k) of this code.
8-6-3: GRADE SURFACE:
No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a steep, sharp
depression or other obstruction in the sidewalk. The grade shall be as nearly
as possible the same as that of the adjoining sidewalk. It shall be unlawful to
have the surface finish of any driveway where the same crosses the sidewalk
constructed of such material as to render it slippery or hazardous for
pedestrians, or to have the grade of such portion vary from the grade of the
sidewalk, or be other than level. (1971 Code)
8-6-4: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
   (A)   All driveways leading from the street to the garages or parking areas
must be dust free, or of blacktop or concrete construction. Where village curbs
are removed for the purposes of making entrance, the curb and gutter must be
removed as far away from the driveway entrance as the nearest contraction or
expansion joint, or a sawed joint, and then replaced so as to ensure a smoothly
joining entrance. The radius of the return of the driveway must be five feet
(5'). No village curb can be removed without first obtaining a curb removal
permit from the superintendent of public works. (Ord. 863, 10-15-2008)
   (B)   No driveway shall be constructed across a natural drainage ditch or
manmade drainage ditch, except where a curb and gutter already exist, without
first installing a culvert pipe in said ditch under the area where the driveway
is to be constructed. The culvert pipe is to be constructed of corrugated
galvanized steel or some other product of equal or higher quality and be a
length and diameter sufficient to ensure proper drainage. The superintendent of
public works or, in his absence, a person designated by the village to act in
his place, shall inspect and approve the length, diameter, level and grade of
the culvert pipe and drainage ditch before final construction of a driveway may
occur over a natural or manmade drainage ditch. All culverts shall be installed
by or at the direction of the superintendent of public works, or in his
absence, a person designated by the village to act in his place, at his
discretion. The property owner shall pay for all expenses of installation of
any culvert except village employee labor expense.
   (C)   Whenever an existing driveway lies across a natural or manmade
drainage ditch and impedes the proper drainage of said ditch, the
superintendent of public works or, in his absence, a person designated by the
village to act in his place, shall require the owner of the property where said
driveway lies to assume responsibility for:
      1.   Installation of a culvert pipe under said driveway according to the
specifications set forth in subsection (B) of this section, or
      2.   Reconstruction of the existing culvert pipe lying under said
driveway according to the specifications set forth in subsection (B) of this
section.
   (D)   Whenever an existing driveway lies across a natural or manmade
drainage ditch and impedes the proper drainage of said ditch, if the
superintendent of public works or, in his absence, a person designated by the
village to act in his place, determines that the property owner has failed and
refuses to either assume responsibility for installation of a culvert pipe or
reconstruct an existing culvert pipe as required in subsection (C) of this
section, then said superintendent of public works or, in his absence, a person
designated by the village to act in his place, shall proceed to install a
culvert pipe or reconstruct the existing culvert pipe on behalf of said
property owner and record a lien for the cost of the materials, equipment and
labor incurred in connection therewith against the real estate involved. (Ord.
690, 8-28-2000)
8-6-5: REPAIR:
It shall be the duty of every person maintaining a driveway to keep the same in
good repair where it crosses the sidewalk and free from obstruction and
openings. (1971 Code)
CHAPTER 7
STORM DRAINS
SECTION:
8-7-1: Connection Prohibited
8-7-1: CONNECTION PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or cause to be connected, any
drain carrying, or to carry, any toilet, sink, basement, septic tank, cesspool,
industrial waste, or any fixture or device discharging polluting substances, to
any separate storm water drain in the Village 1 . (1971 Code)

  8-5-12 of this Title.
CHAPTER 8
EXTENSION OF MUNICIPAL SERVICES BEYOND VILLAGE LIMITS
SECTION:
8-8-1: Extension Of Services
8-8-1: EXTENSION OF SERVICES:
No Municipal services of the Village, including fire protection; police
protection; water facilities; sewer facilities; and street maintenance, repair
and snow removal shall be provided beyond the corporate limits of the Village
where it is legally possible for the territory outside the Village limits which
is served or desires to be served by any of the above Municipal services to
annex to the Village. (Ord. 202, 5-24-1971)
