   Bakeries.
   Banks and savings and loan offices.
   Barber and/or beauty shops.
   Craft shops - selling and/or making.
   Dance and/or tumbling academies.
   Executive, administrative or professional offices.
   Flower shops.
   Gift shops.
   Government offices or other government uses.
   Laundromats and/or dry cleaning shops.
   Medical and dental offices, including clinics.
   Medical or dental clinics.
   Photograph galleries.
   Publicly owned buildings and public utility offices.
   Restaurants.
   Shoe repair shops.
   Tailoring or seamstress shops.
   It is understood that the above designated business establishments or any
other establishments approved for commercial operation within the village
limits shall in no manner be of such nature to be noxious or offensive to the
residents of adjacent areas. Complaints of such nature may be made either to
the zoning enforcement officer or directly to the planning and zoning
commission.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-7A-2: SPECIAL USES:
The following special uses may be permitted subject to the provisions in this
chapter. Any person or entity proposing to utilize any property for one of the
following special uses shall submit a site plan and use plan to the planning
and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission shall review the site
plan and use plan, conduct a hearing and submit a recommendation to the village
board. The village board may permit said special use subject to such conditions
as the village board deems appropriate. Special uses which may be permitted,
subject to the conditions herein, are as follows:
   Electric repair and/or small appliance repair shops.
   Garden and/or lawn sales and repair.
   Hardware stores.
   Sign shops.
   Store or shop for light retail business.
   Other uses which are similar to the above uses are permissible special uses
with board approval.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-7A-3: MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Off street parking space shall be provided at the rate of one space
for each three hundred (300) square feet of floor area in the building which is
used for commercial purposes.
   (B)   Ingress and egress shall enter and exit off of a public street only,
and shall not conflict with adjacent business uses or general traffic flow.
   (C)   A six foot (6') obscuring wall or fence must be provided where
abutting or adjacent to a residential zoned district.
   (D)   All lighting shall be shielded from adjacent residential districts and
from abutting streets.
   (E)   All restroom doors shall be shielded from adjoining properties.
   (F)   It is further understood that any living quarters constructed within
the B-2 designated area must have a minimum of five hundred twenty five (525)
square feet of living area and appropriate electric, water, sewer and sanitary
utilities.
   (G)   Any use of semi-trailers or cargo containers shall be allowed only by
a viable, on-site business and shall be governed by section
6-3-2-10 of this Code.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-7A-4: HEIGHT REGULATIONS:
No building shall exceed two and one-half (21/2) stories or thirty feet (30')
in height in the B-2 District except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-7A-5: AREA REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Front Yard: The front yard shall be determined by the setback which
shall be a minimum of fifty feet (50') from the property line to provide a
parking area.
   (B)   Side Yard: The side yard requirements are the same as the front yard
when the building abuts a street on two (2) sides, that is, on the front and
one side. Otherwise, there shall be a minimum side yard requirement of five
feet (5') from the property line, which shall be left unobstructed.
   (C)   Rear Yard: The rear yard shall be ten feet (10') from the property
line, which shall be left unobstructed.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-7A-6: PRIOR NONCONFORMING USE:
The area designated as being zoned B-2 Business and Commercial District shall
be subject to the following provision:
Any present use which does not conform to the uses outlined in a B-2 Business
and Commercial Zoning District may remain in its current use as long as said
property is maintained in that use by the same owner. However, once said
property is sold, or if there is any change in any ownership of the business
conducted upon said property or if said property's use changes from the use in
existence at the time of passage hereof, said property must comply with B-
2 Business and Commercial Zoning District approved zoning requirements.  (Ord.
1040, 8-10-2020)
10-7A-7: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   (A)   Any person or entity wishing to open a business or change any business
in the B-2 Business and Commercial District must apply for and obtain a
business permit from the Village Clerk of North Pekin.
   (B)   Application forms for the necessary business permit shall be available
at the Village Hall and must be returned to the Village Hall when completed. A
fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) must be submitted with every application
for a permit.
   (C)   The application shall then be submitted to the Zoning Enforcement
Officer, who shall either approve or reject the application for business
permit. If the business permit is rejected by the Zoning Enforcement Officer,
the person or entity shall be entitled to appeal that decision to the Planning
and Zoning Commission, within thirty five (35) days of the rejection.
   (D)   If the business permit is approved by the Zoning Enforcement Officer,
a business permit shall immediately be issued to the person or entity
submitting the application. The business permit must be prominently displayed
in the business establishment.
   (E)   This business permit is in addition to any County or State
requirements for business permits and/or licenses and does not supersede any
requirements imposed by the County of Tazewell or State of Illinois.  (Ord.
1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 8
I-1 INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT (LIGHT)
SECTION:
10-8-1: Use Regulations
10-8-2: Parking Regulations
10-8-3: Height Regulations
10-8-4: Area Regulations
10-8-5: Permit Required
10-8-6: Residency Prohibited
10-8-1: USE REGULATIONS:
The regulations set forth in this chapter or set forth elsewhere in this title
when referred to herein are the district regulations in the I-1 industrial
district (light).
   A building or premises shall be used only for the following purposes:
   Any use permitted in the B-1 business and commercial district.
   Blacksmith shop.
   Bottling works.
   Coal yards.
   Dyeing and cleaning establishments.
   Industrial and manufacturing plants, where the operations are conducted in
one or more buildings and not more than ten percent (10%) of the tract is used
for open storage of products, materials or equipment.
   Lumber or building materials yard.
   Milk distribution station.
   Painting plants.
   Public utility substations and facilities.
   Warehouses and storage plants.
   Wholesale establishments.
   Wholesale storage of oil, gasoline or other petroleum products.  (Ord. 1040,
8-10-2020)
10-8-2: PARKING REGULATIONS:
Parking space shall be provided on the lot or in a building on the lot adequate
to accommodate the vehicles of the employees, customers and delivery
personnel.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-8-3: HEIGHT REGULATIONS:
No building shall exceed three (3) stories or forty five feet (45') in height
in the I-1 district.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-8-4: AREA REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Front Yard: The front yard shall be determined by the setback which
shall be a minimum of fifty feet (50') from the street to provide a parking
area.
   (B)   Side Yard: The side yard requirements are the same as the front yard
when the building abuts a street on two (2) sides, that is, on the front and
one side. Otherwise, there shall be a minimum side yard requirement of five
feet (5') from the property line, which shall be left unobstructed.
   (C)   Rear Yard: The rear yard shall be ten feet (10') from the lot line and
shall be left open.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-8-5: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   (A)   Any person or entity wishing to open a business or change any business
in the I-1 industrial district (light) must apply for and obtain a business
permit from the Village Clerk of North Pekin.
   (B)   Application forms for the necessary business permit shall be available
at the village hall and must be returned to the village hall when completed. A
fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) must be submitted with every application
for a business permit.
   (C)   This business permit is in addition to any county or state
requirements for business permits and/or licenses and does not supersede any
requirements imposed by the county of Tazewell or state of Illinois.  (Ord.
1040, 8-10-2020)
10-8-6: RESIDENCY PROHIBITED:
No person or family shall be allowed to reside within an I-1 industrial
district (light). An I-1 industrial district (light) is not a dwelling district
pursuant to section
10-1-1 of this title.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 9
I-2 INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT (HEAVY)
SECTION:
10-9-1: Use Regulations
10-9-2: Parking Regulations
10-9-3: Height Regulations
10-9-4: Area Regulations
10-9-5: Permit Required
10-9-6: Residency Prohibited
10-9-1: USE REGULATIONS:
The regulations set forth in this chapter or set forth elsewhere in this title
when referred to herein are the district regulations in the I-2 industrial
district (heavy).
All uses not otherwise prohibited by law, except any residential use; provided,
however, that no building permit shall be issued for any of the following uses
until or unless the location of such use shall have been approved by the board
of trustees after a public hearing thereon by the planning commission, shall be
permitted in the I-2 district:
   Ammonia, bleaching powder or chlorine manufacture.
   Ammunition manufacture and/or storage.
   Animal black, lampblack or bone black manufacture.
   Arsenal.
   Bone distillation.
   Carbon manufacture.
   Celluloid manufacture.
   Coal distillation.
   Coke ovens.
   Dead animal and offal reduction.
   Distillation of tar.
   Explosives, fireworks and gunpowder manufacture or storage.
   Fat rendering.
   Grease, lard or tallow manufactured or refined from animals.
   Hair manufacture.
   Hog farm.
   Incineration, reduction, storage or dumping of slaughterhouse refuse, rancid
fats, dead animals or offal.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-9-2: PARKING REGULATIONS:
Parking space shall be provided on the lot or in a building on the lot adequate
to accommodate the cars of the employees of any of the uses permitted in this
district as well as the trucks and other vehicles owned by or in custody of the
establishment.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-9-3: HEIGHT REGULATIONS:
No building shall exceed three (3) stories or forty five feet (45') in height
in the I-2 district.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-9-4: AREA REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Front Yard: The front yard shall be determined by the setback which
shall be a minimum of fifty feet (50') from the street to provide a parking
area.
   (B)   Side Yard: The side yard requirements are the same as the front yard
when the building abuts a street on two (2) sides, that is, on the front and
one side. Otherwise, there shall be a minimum side yard requirement of five
feet (5') from the property line, which shall be left unobstructed.
   (C)   Rear Yard: The rear yard shall be ten feet (10') from the lot line and
shall be left open.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-9-5: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   (A)   Any person or entity wishing to open a business or change any business
in the I-2 industrial district (heavy) must apply for and obtain a business
permit from the Village Clerk of North Pekin.
   (B)   Application forms for the necessary business  permit shall be
available at the Village Hall and must be returned to the Village Hall when
completed. A fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) must be submitted with every
application for a business permit.
   (C)   This business permit is in addition to any county or state
requirements for permits and/or licenses and does not supersede any
requirements imposed by the county of Tazewell or state of Illinois.  (Ord.
1040, 8-10-2020)
10-9-6: RESIDENCY PROHIBITED:
No person or family shall be allowed to reside within an I-2 industrial
district (heavy). An I-2 industrial district (heavy) is not a dwelling district
pursuant to section
10-1-1 of this title.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 10
NONCONFORMING USES; SPECIAL PERMITS
SECTION:
10-10-1: Nonconforming Uses; Continuance; Removal
10-10-2: Special Use Permits
10-10-1: NONCONFORMING USES; CONTINUANCE; REMOVAL:
If a building is being used for a lawful purpose at the time of the adoption of
this title, the building can continue to be used for said purpose,
notwithstanding the fact that said use does not conform to the provisions of
this title, where the continued use of the premises is allowed by a majority
vote of the village board of trustees after notice, hearing and recommendation
by the planning and zoning commission.
Where a building that has been used for a nonconforming use is changed to be
used for a more restricted use or a conforming use, the building loses its
ability to be used for a less restricted use again unless the continued use of
the premises is allowed by a majority vote of the village board of trustees
after notice, hearing and recommendation by the planning and zoning commission.
Where a building that has previously been recognized as a nonconforming use is
damaged by fire, explosion, acts of God, or criminal conduct to the extent that
its value has been reduced by fifty percent (50%) or more, the building may
only be restored in conformity with the regulations of this title, unless the
restoration of the structure to replicate the previously existing structure is
allowed by a majority vote of the village board of trustees after notice,
hearing and recommendation by the planning and zoning commission.
Where a building that has previously been recognized as lawfully allowing a
nonconforming use, and where the use of the building or premises has been
discontinued or stopped for a period of twelve (12) consecutive months or more,
all uses thereafter shall conform to the regulations of the district where it
is located, unless the continued use of the premises is allowed by a majority
vote of the village board of trustees after notice, hearing and recommendation
by the planning and zoning commission.
This provision also applies to districts whose zoning is hereinafter changed.
Any nonconforming structure in violation of this title may be validated under
this title at the election of the proper village officials, or may be ordered
removed or corrected by the proper officials at any time.
No commercial buildings shall exist in a dwelling district. (Ord. 1040, 8-10-
2020)
10-10-2: SPECIAL USE PERMITS:
   (A)   Overview:
      1.   Applicability: Special uses are uses which are appropriate for the
applicable zoning district only upon site specific review according to the
standards established by ordinance and upon approval of the village of North
Pekin. Review and determination of special uses shall be governed by the
provisions of this section. The nature of what special uses are allowable
within any given area and what restrictions are placed thereon shall be at the
discretion of the village. (Ord. 869, 12-8-2008; amd. Ord. 913, 2-14-2011)
      2.   Definitions:
 
          Any business conducted in property that is zoned R-1, R-2 or R-3,
          which may have an impact on the residents of the village of North
          Pekin, Illinois. A special use permit shall not be required for any
BUSINESS: business which does not have an impact on the residents of the
          village of North Pekin, Illinois, and/or which does not generate
          local sales tax revenues, including, but not limited to: paper
          routes, independent distributor business (such as Avon).
 
   (B)   Application and Review Procedure:
      1.   Special use permit applications may only be initiated by the fee
owners of the property, or his designated agent.
      2.   The planning and zoning commission shall conduct the application and
hearing process for all special use permits.
      3.   A nonrefundable initial application fee of one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) shall be charged for all special use permit applications.
      4.   Along with submitting the special use permit application form,
applicants for a special use permit must also produce site plans depicting the
general layout of the parcel, a survey and legal description of the property
(where requested by the planning and zoning commission), a floor plan (where
applicable) and a letter stating the proposed use for the parcel, the
approximate gross floor area of existing or intended buildings or structures, a
statement that the applicable standards to the specific use have and will
continue to be met, and for businesses requiring licensing, a description of
client population, the state or county agency responsible for licensing the
facility, and proof of current license and a description of the types of
services to be provided on the property.
      5.   The planning and zoning commission shall study the application, make
relevant inquiry and conduct a publicly noticed hearing with regard to the
issuance of the special use permit in which they shall hear any evidence or
statement presented by the applicant or his representative or by other persons
attending the hearing, as well as consider any other written or oral statements
or evidence as they, in their sole discretion, deem relevant. The planning and
zoning commission shall make a written report of their findings, including any
recommended conditions of special use permit, if any, to the board of trustees
of the village of North Pekin, within sixty (60) days after acceptance of the
completed application.
      6.   The board of trustees shall review the written report and
recommendations of the planning and zoning commission toward the issuance of
the special use permit, and any recommended conditions. If the planning and
zoning commission recommends against the issuance of the special use permit,
the permit can only be issued if the village board votes for the same to be
issued by an affirmative two-thirds (2/3) vote of the elected members of the
village board of trustees. The village board of trustees shall grant or deny
the special use permit application within thirty (30) days of receipt of the
written report of the planning and zoning commission. In the event that the
village board of trustees does not take any action within thirty (30) days of
receipt of the written report of the planning and zoning commission, then said
application shall be placed on the agenda of each and every regular meeting of
the village board of trustees until the application is approved or rejected.
      7.   The village board of trustees may impose conditions upon any special
use permit issued which, if not complied with or which have been altered in
scope, application or design, shall be grounds for revocation of the special
use permit. All stipulations or conditions imposed on the issuance of any
special use permit shall be maintained in perpetuity with the special use.
   (C)   Renewal Of Special Use Permits:
      1.   Any special use permit issued prior to November 1, 2008, must be
renewed on or before December 31, 2009, by bringing documentation of the same
to the village hall and paying the newly instituted annual renewal fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00). The holders of same will not be required to pay a
new application fee for the renewal of same.
      2.   A record of all special use permits existing within the village of
North Pekin shall be maintained by the village of North Pekin. The village of
North Pekin shall provide a copy of all current special use permits to the
chief of police and the fire chief on an annual basis for the purpose of
assisting with enforcement and maintaining the peace.
      3.   All special use permits and renewals are good until December 31 of
the year following the date of issuance. A thirty (30) day grace period for
renewal of the permits shall begin on the first day following the expiration of
the special use permit. The permit holder may renew the permit at any time
during that thirty (30) day period. However, the date for the renewal begins
the date the permit expired regardless of the date the renewal fee is paid.
After the thirty (30) day grace period has expired, the special use permit
shall not be renewed and the permit holder must apply for a new special use
permit and pay all initial permit application fees if they seek to reapply for
a special use permit.
   (D)   Revocation of Special Use Permit:
      1.   Where the village obtains information regarding an alleged violation
of a special use permit, the village police department will investigate the
situation. If the police report indicates a violation may exist, the matter
shall be referred to the planning and zoning commission. A hearing before the
planning and zoning commission will be scheduled on the matter no later than
the second meeting from the date of the police report. The holder of the
special use permit will have an opportunity to respond to the allegations and
police report at said hearing.
      2.   Following a proper hearing before the planning and zoning
commission, the commission shall issue a written report and recommendation
regarding the revocation of the special use permit. The opinion shall be
forwarded to the village board of trustees, who shall make the final decision
as to the revocation of the permit. Said decision of the village board of
trustees shall be made within thirty (30) days of receipt of the written report
of the planning and zoning commission. In the event that the village board of
trustees does not take any action within thirty (30) days of receipt of the
written report of the planning and zoning commission, the recommendations of
the planning and zoning commission, shall be deemed accepted by the village of
North Pekin.
      3.   The revocation of the special use permit shall require the permit
holder to stop the use authorized by the special use permit.
      4.   After revocation, the special use permit holder may not reapply for
a reissuance of a special use permit within one hundred eighty (180) days of
the revocation action. In this instance, all fees shall apply as if there had
never been a special use permit issued.
      5.   The decision of the village board of trustees is final. Any appeal
of the decision shall be to the Tazewell County circuit court. (Ord. 869, 12-8-
2008)
   (E)   General Restrictions With Regard To Special Use Permits:
      1.   A business operating under a special use permit within a residential
district of the village of North Pekin is permitted to have a single sign
advertising the business which meets the following requirements:
         (a)   The sign shall be no larger than twenty four inches (24") high
by thirty six inches (36") wide;
         (b)   The sign shall be purchased or constructed to be placed or
driven into the ground such as a real estate sign, with a maximum frame height
of forty one inches (41") high by thirty seven inches (37") wide;
         (c)   Sign shall be removable and not permanently installed with
concrete or any other means other than driving frame into ground;
         (d)   No illumination is allowed;
         (e)   Special use permit number will be on both sides of sign in a
minimum of one inch (1") block letters;
         (f)   Sign shall be placed only on the owner's property and set back
beyond the village easement;
         (g)   Sign shall be removed upon expiration or revocation of the
special use permit.
      2.   All special use permits are issued contingent upon the requisite
number of fire extinguishers being present in the structure and compliance with
all public safety measures addressed by the village fire department.
      3.   The proprietor/manager of the business must be the petitioner and
permit holder for the special use permit. In addition, the petitioner must
specify the name and address of the owner of the property. If the petitioner
for a special use permit is not the owner of the property, the property owner
must supply written approval of the petitioner's intended use.
      4.   Only one nonresident employee is allowed at each business operating
under a special use permit.
      5.   Business can only be conducted from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to
eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. for businesses requiring the ingress and egress of
customers to the location of the business.
      6.   Permit holder is required to provide adequate parking for the
traffic created by their business.
      7.   Special use permit holders must locate, store and dispose of
business equipment, customer owned items, nonhazardous material, and hazardous
materials consistent with requirements placed on them by the village board of
trustees and/or the village fire department and village police department.
      8.   The village board of trustees may require fences or other measures
be taken to control offensive appearances, odors or sound levels created by the
existence of the special use.
      9.   If fencing is part of the plan for a special use permit, the
guidelines for the installation and existence thereof are located in section
10-2-7 of this title.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 11
COMMUNITY UNIT PLAN
SECTION:
10-11-1: Community Unit Plan
10-11-1: COMMUNITY UNIT PLAN:
The owner or owners of any tract of land may submit to the Village Board a plan
for the use and development of all of the tracts of land for residential and
allied purposes. The development plan shall be referred to the Planning
Commission for study and report and for a public hearing. If the zoning
committee approves the plans, they shall then be submitted to the Village Board
for consideration and approval. The approval and recommendations of the
Planning Commission shall be accompanied by a report stating the reasons for
approval or disapproval of the application and specific evidence that the
proposed community unit plan meets or does not meet with the following
conditions:
   (A)   The property adjacent to the area included in the plan will not be
adversely affected.
   (B)   The plan is consistent with the intent and purposes of this Title to
promote public health, safety, morals and general welfare.
   (C)   The buildings shall be used only for single-family dwellings or
multiple family contained in the site, excluding churches.
   (D)   The average lot area per family contained in the site, exclusive of
the area occupied by streets, will not be less than the lot area per family
required in the district in which the development is located. (Ord. 1040, 8-10-
2020)
CHAPTER 12
VARIANCES; AMENDMENTS
SECTION:
10-12-1: Variances
10-12-2: Amendments
10-12-1: VARIANCES:
The district regulations hereinafter set forth shall qualify or supplement, as
the case may be, the district regulations appearing elsewhere in this title.
   (A)   Public, semipublic or public service buildings, hospitals,
institutions or schools, when permitted in a district, may be erected to a
height not exceeding sixty feet (60') and churches and temples may be erected
to a height not exceeding seventy five feet (75') if the building is set back
from each yard line at least one foot (1') for each foot of additional building
height above the height limit otherwise provided in the district in which the
building is located.
   (B)   Single-family and two-family dwellings may be increased in height by
not more than ten feet (10') when the side and rear yards are increased over
the yard requirements of the district in which they are located by not less
than ten feet (10'), but they shall not exceed three (3) stories in height.
   (C)   Chimneys, cooling towers, elevator bulkheads, fire towers, monument
stacks, stage towers or scenery lofts, tanks, water towers, ornamental towers
and spires, church steeples, radio towers, or necessary mechanical
appurtenances, may be erected to a height in accordance with existing or
hereafter adopted provisions of this code.
   (D)   Accessory buildings may be built in a required rear yard but such
accessory buildings shall not occupy more than thirty percent (30%) of the
required rear yard.
   (E)   Whenever a lot abuts upon an alley, one-half (1/2) of the width of the
alley may be considered as a portion of the required rear yard. (Ord. 1040, 8-
10-2020)
10-12-2: AMENDMENTS:
The board of trustees may from time to time on its own motion or on petition
after report by the planning commission and after hearing and public notice of
such hearing given by one publication in the village at least fifteen (15) days
before the time of hearing, amend, supplement or change by ordinance the
regulations and districts herein or subsequently established. In case of
written protest against any proposed amendment signed and acknowledged by the
owners of twenty percent (20%) of frontage proposed to be altered, or by the
owners of twenty percent (20%) of the frontage immediately adjoining or across
an alley therefrom, or by the owners of twenty percent (20%) of the frontage
directly opposite the frontage proposed to be altered as to such regulations or
district, filed with the clerk, such amendment shall not be passed except by
the favorable vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all of the members of the board of
trustees.
The village board shall not be required to take action for the conduct of a
hearing on petition by property owners to amend, supplement or change the
boundaries of any district or to reclassify any property, but whenever owners
of fifty percent (50%) or more of the street frontage in any block shall
present to the village board a petition, duly signed and acknowledged,
requesting such amendment or reclassification, it shall be the duty of the
village board to refer said petition to the planning commission to hold a
hearing thereon, as provided by statute.
Before any action shall be taken, as provided herein, the party or parties
petitioning for a change shall deposit with the village treasurer the sum of
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to cover the costs involved with variance
petitions for such amendments, supplementation or change, and under no
conditions shall said sum or any part thereof be refunded for failure of said
petition, amendment, supplementation or change to be enacted into law. (Ord.
1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 13
ENFORCEMENT; PERMITS
SECTION:
10-13-1: Enforcement
10-13-2: Permits
10-13-1: ENFORCEMENT:
This title shall be enforced by the Zoning Enforcement Officer who shall be
appointed by the President of the Village Board, by and with the consent of the
Board. No building permit or demolition permit shall be issued by him except
where the provisions of this title shall have been complied with.
This title controls over the 2006 international building code in regard to
issuance of building permits. If conflicts arise with the 2006 international
building code, all permits are to be issued according to the requirements of
this title.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-13-2: PERMITS:
It shall be unlawful to establish any use of a building, structure, or land,
either by itself or in addition to another use, or to erect a new building or
structure or part thereof, or to rebuild, structurally alter, add to or
relocate any building or structure, or part thereof, or to demolish any
building or structure or part thereof, without obtaining a permit from the
Zoning Enforcement Officer in accordance with the following regulations:
Unless otherwise specifically provided in this title, violations of any
provision of this title, shall be punishable by a fine of not less than twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day
that a violation is continued or permitted to continue shall constitute a
separate offense, and shall be punishable as such. 
   (A)   Permits:
      1.   Contents Of Application: Application for permits shall be filed in
written form with the Enforcement Officer, shall state the legal description of
the property, the name and address of the owner, the applicant, and the
contractor, the estimated costs, and shall describe the uses to be established
or expanded, or indicate why demolition is required and shall give such
information as may be required by this title for its proper enforcement.
      2.   Drawing: All applications for a building permit shall be accompanied
by a dimensioned drawing of the building plot showing the location of buildings
and structures, lot areas to be used, and auto parking areas.
      3.   Accessory Structures: Each permit issued for a main building shall
also cover any accessory structures or buildings to be constructed or
demolished at the same time on the same premises, and such permit shall be
posted in plain sight on the premises for which it is issued, until completion
of construction or demolition.
      4.   Documents To Be Filed: All applications and a copy of all permits
issued shall be systematically filed and kept by the Village Clerk for ready
reference.
      5.   Permit Fees: To partially defray the expenses for reviewing the
plans of said property, the following fees shall be charged by the Village at
the time a permit is issued:
                                                                 $150.00 first 1,200 square feet, excluding basement,

    curb for the purpose of making entrance 
 
      Individuals applying for a permit will make application at the Village
Hall. A ten dollar ($10.00) processing fee will be charged at that time.
Subsequently, the Zoning Enforcement Officer will review the application and
the proposed construction or demolition site. Upon approval of the application,
a permit will be issued. Payment of the permit fee may be made by the applicant
either at the Village Hall or to the Zoning Enforcement Officer, who shall
remit said fee to the Village on a regular basis. No refund of the processing
fee or permit fee will be made.
      Building permits issued for work in Village residential districts shall
be valid for twelve (12) months from the date issued. If the structure is not
completed within that time, a new permit, which will add six (6) months to the
completion date, will be required at a cost of one and one-half (11/2) times of
the original permit fee. Noncompletion of the structure by the end of the six
(6) month extension may result in a stop work order being issued and/or review
by the Village Board and Village Attorney for possible legal action.
   Permits issued for work in Village business, commercial or industrial
districts shall be valid for eighteen (18) months from the date issued. At that
time, a new permit, extending the completion date by twelve (12) months, may be
issued at one and one-half (11/2) times of the original permit fee.
Noncompletion of the structure by the end of the twelve (12) month extension
may result in review by the Village Board and Village Attorney for possible
legal action.
      A demolition permit shall be valid for six (6) months from the date
issued. If the demolition is not completed within that time, a new permit,
valid for an additional six (6) months will be required at a cost of two (2)
times the original permit fee. Noncompletion of demolition within the twelve
(12) months of the original permit will be subject to review by the Village
Board and Village Attorney for possible legal action.
      A permit may be revoked under the following circumstances:
         (a)   If any work or change in use authorized by the permit has not
substantially begun within ninety (90) days of issuance; or
         (b)   If the Zoning Enforcement Officer finds by his personal
observation or from competent evidence that the rules and regulations under
which it has been issued have been violated.
      Any work on-site subsequent to such revocation shall require that a new
permit be applied for and issued at one and one-half (11/2) times the original
permit fee. The new permit will be subject to the same time to complete
requirements and penalties for noncompliance as any other new permit.
      6.   Size: A building permit shall be required for any proposed
structure, either temporarily or permanently affixed, with greater than one
hundred forty four (144) square feet of floor area.
      7.   Replacement: Subsection (A)5 of this section is hereby declared to
supersede and replace any conflicting provisions contained in the 2006
International Building Code which has been incorporated in title 4, chapter 1,
of this Code heretofore adopted.
      8.   Stop Work Orders: To defray additional cost of administering "stop
work" orders posted by the Zoning Enforcement Officer as a result of
construction or demolition without the appropriate permit as required herein,
or construction or demolition contrary to the authority of the permit, there
shall be an additional charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00). If the stop
work order is placed on construction outside the authority of the permit and it
is found that the Village was at fault on the authority of the permit, then the
one hundred dollars ($100.00) charged shall be refunded. (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 14
INTERPRETATION; VIOLATIONS
SECTION:
10-14-1: Interpretation
10-14-2: Violations
10-14-1: INTERPRETATION:
In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this Title shall be
held to be minimum requirements, adopted for the promotion of the public
health, morals, safety and the general welfare. Wherever the requirements of
any other lawfully adopted rules, regulations or ordinances shall apply, the
most restrictive or that imposing the higher standards shall govern.
It is not intended by this Title to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way
impair or interfere with private restrictions placed upon property by covenant,
deed or other private agreement, or with restrictive covenants running with the
land. Where this Title imposes a greater restriction upon land, buildings or
structures than is imposed or required by such existing provisions of law,
ordinance, contract or deed, the provisions of this Title shall control. (Ord.
1040, 8-10-2020)
10-14-2: VIOLATIONS:
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or
who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this Title shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished therefor as in this Code provided.
Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate
offense.
In case any building or structure is erected, constructed, reconstructed,
altered, repaired, converted or maintained or any building, structure or land
is used in violation of this Title, the proper authorities of the Village in
addition to other remedies may institute any appropriate action or proceedings
to prevent such unlawful erection, maintenance or use; to restrain, correct or
abate such violation; to prevent the occupancy of said building, structure or
land; or to prevent any illegal act, conduct, business or use in or about such
premises. (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 15
SUBDIVISIONS
SECTION:
10-15-1: Purpose
10-15-2: Streets
10-15-3: Utility Easements
10-15-4: Gas Mains, Electrical Distribution Lines
10-15-5: Monuments
10-15-6: Water Mains, Fire Hydrants
10-15-7: Streetlights
10-15-8: Street Signs
10-15-9: Maintenance Of Streets; Bonds
10-15-10: Inspection Of Improvements
10-15-1: PURPOSE:
The Board of Trustees of the Village is called upon to accept subdivisions for
and on behalf of the Village, whereby the Village assumes certain
responsibilities, including responsibilities for the care and maintenance of
the streets included in said subdivisions, and that for the purpose of the
present and future development of the Village and for the promotion of the
public health and safety, comfort, morals and welfare of the persons living
within the territory governed, the provisions and regulations hereinafter
contained shall govern the subdividing and platting of lands lying within the
corporate limits of the Village. (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-15-2: STREETS:
No subdivision shall be accepted by the Village unless the streets therein
platted shall have a minimum width of fifty feet (50') and are graded with
thirty six feet (36') of roadway between the curbs. All streets shall be
blacktopped with curbs and gutters approved by the Village Engineer. Unless
otherwise required hereunder all lots shall be provided with entrance culverts
of reinforced concrete or standard culvert pipe being a minimum of twelve
inches (12") in diameter by fifteen feet (15') in length, by parties other than
the Board. If deemed necessary for the health, safety and welfare of the
Village, the Superintendent of Public Works or, in his absence, a person
designated by the Village Board may require any lot to have an entrance culvert
in excess of the minimum standard. The full dedicated width of all streets
shall be brought to the appropriate elevation of the grade established, and in
no case below or more than one foot (1') above the established grade. It is
further provided that dead-end streets and dead-end courts of all kinds shall
be avoided where practical, however, subdivisions shall be accepted wherein
courts are provided with a minimum width of fifty feet (50') with a traveled
way of thirty six feet (36') and with a turnaround having an inside diameter of
not less than fifty five feet (55') in which case sufficient footage of the
turnaround will be dedicated to facilitate future improvements.
All dimensions listed in this Chapter unless otherwise specifically provided
represent minimum requirements.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-15-3: UTILITY EASEMENTS:
No subdivision shall be accepted unless provision is made for utility easements
deemed by the Village Board to be adequate and proper.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-15-4: GAS MAINS, ELECTRICAL DISTRIBUTION LINES:
No subdivision shall be accepted unless adequate gas mains and electrical
distribution lines, wherever the same shall be available, shall be provided or
arranged for by the subdivider prior to acceptance.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-15-5: MONUMENTS:
No subdivisions shall be accepted until steel pipes or rods or concrete posts
shall be installed at all block corners and other survey control points for use
as permanent monuments.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-15-6: WATER MAINS, FIRE HYDRANTS:
No subdivision shall be accepted by the Village unless the subdivider shall
have provided or arranged for adequate water main installations and proper fire
hydrants in a minimum number at locations for proper fire protection in
accordance with and subject to the approval of the Village Water Commission,
and the rental for said fire hydrants shall be paid for by said subdivider in
advance for a minimum period of three (3) tax years subsequent to acceptance of
said subdivision.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-15-7: STREETLIGHTS:
No subdivision shall be accepted by the village unless the subdivider shall
have provided the same with proper streetlights in a minimum number and
location for proper lighting in accordance with the approval of the engineer of
the village and the estimated cost of the village for electricity and
maintenance of said streetlights for a minimum period of three (3) tax years
subsequent to the acceptance of said subdivision shall be paid for by said
subdivider in advance prior to the acceptance of the subdivision.  (Ord. 1040,
8-10-2020)
10-15-8: STREET SIGNS:
No subdivision shall be accepted by the village unless appropriate street and
traffic control signs shall be erected or arranged for at each street
intersection within the subdivision. The subdivider shall pay for all expense
and cost of materials and labor to install any and all signs deemed necessary
or appropriate and approved by the village board. The type of signs and
location thereof shall be subject to the approval and direction of the village
board at its discretion.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-15-9: MAINTENANCE OF STREETS; BOND:
As a condition to the acceptance of any subdivision, the person or persons
presenting said subdivision for acceptance shall agree to maintain the streets
of said subdivision for a period of three (3) years from the date of completion
of application of the final top coat on said street. Said person shall post
with the village board a surety bond, as provided by law, and approved by the
board, in the amount of ten percent (10%) of the cost of the original paving of
streets lying within the limits of the map or plat. The bond shall remain in
force until the provisions of this chapter are complied with and then released,
in writing, by the president of the board.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-15-10: INSPECTION OF IMPROVEMENTS:
All improvements to be made under the provisions of this chapter shall be
inspected during the course of construction by the village engineer and the
subdivider will reimburse the village for the cost of such inspections. The
final acceptance of all such improvements shall be subject to the approval
thereof by the village board and the village engineer. Subdividers are urged to
avail themselves of the advice and assistance of the street maintenance and
improvement committee of the village and to consult with this committee before
preparation of the plat and before formal application for its approval is
made.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 16
M-1 MOBILE HOME PARK DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-16-1: Use Regulations
10-16-2: Area Regulations
10-16-1: USE REGULATIONS:
The regulations set forth herein, or set forth elsewhere in this Title when
referred to in this Chapter, are the district regulations in the M-1 Mobile
Home Park District.
Premises shall be used only for the following purposes: harbor mobile homes and
travel trailers, and such facilities as are needed to ensure maximum beneficial
use of said structures.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-16-2: AREA REGULATIONS:
The regulations pertaining to area in regards to mobile home parks will be the
same as those set out in Title 3, Chapter 10 of this Code. (Ord. 1040, 8-10-
2020)
CHAPTER 17
R-4 MULTIPLE-FAMILY DWELLING DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-17-1: Use Regulations
10-17-2: Area Regulations
10-17-3: Parking Regulations
10-17-4: Height Regulations
10-17-5: Site Plan Approval
10-17-1: USE REGULATIONS:
The regulations set forth herein, or set forth elsewhere in this Title when
referred to in this Chapter, are the district regulations in the R-4 Multiple-
Family Dwelling District.
A building or premises shall be used only for the following purposes:
   (A)   Single-family dwellings must meet the requirements of a single family
dwelling with a minimum of nine hundred fifty (950) square feet of foot print
of main structure, with a variance allowance of two percent (2%) thereof,
exclusive of one-story open porches and garages, or eight hundred (800) square
feet with full basement.
   (B)   Two-family and multiple-family dwellings with a minimum of six hundred
(600) square feet per apartment, exclusive of one-story open porches and
garages, with a variance allowance of two percent (2%) thereof.
   (C)   Accessory buildings including a Class I garage and accessory uses
customarily incident to the above uses. Accessory buildings shall also include
church or school bulletin boards and signs not exceeding twenty (20) square
feet in area and temporary signs appertaining to the lease, hire or sale of the
premises on which it is located. Such temporary sign shall not exceed ten (10)
square feet in area.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-17-2: AREA REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Density: The number of families occupying a lot or tract of land shall
not exceed the whole number resulting from dividing the area of the lot or
tract by two thousand (2,000).
   (B)   Front Yard: No building shall be erected or extended to a point closer
than twenty five feet (25') from any street. When the setback of the houses on
the street are uniformly in line, the new construction or any addition must be
built to maintain continuity of the prevailing setback of the existing
dwellings.
   (C)   Side Yard: There shall be side yard on each side of a building having
a width of not less than ten percent (10%) of the lot width. In no case shall a
side yard be less than five feet (5'), except that a detached garage or other
accessory building located sixty feet (60') or more from the front property
line and having a wall roughly parallel to the side lot line twenty four feet
(24') or less in length may be located within two feet (2') of the side lot
line.
      A side yard need not exceed twenty feet (20') in width.
   (D)   Rear Yard: The rear yard shall have a depth of at least twenty percent
(20%) of the lot depth, but in no case less than twenty feet (20'). Rear yard
depth need not exceed forty feet (40').
   (E)   Lot Coverage: The total lot area covered by all buildings on a lot
shall not exceed twenty percent (20%).
   (F)   Space Between Buildings: When more than one building containing
apartments is located on a lot the distance between opposing walls of any two
(2) buildings containing apartments shall be at least thirty feet (30'), if
either wall contains windows within the portions where the walls overlap, or
fifteen feet (15') if neither wall contains windows within the portions where
they overlap.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-17-3: PARKING REGULATIONS:
Off-street parking shall be provided at the rate of two (2) spaces for each
apartment. Such space shall not be located within twenty five feet (25') of any
street, not less than five feet (5') of any side or rear lot line, unless
located within a detached garage or carport which is located sixty feet (60')
or more from the front property line and such garage or carport has a wall
roughly parallel to the adjoining lot line twenty four feet (24') or less in
length, in which case it may be located not less than two feet (2') from that
lot line or lines.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-17-4: HEIGHT REGULATIONS:
No building shall exceed two and one-half (21/2) stories or thirty feet (30')
in height in the R-4 District.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
10-17-5: SITE PLAN APPROVAL:
All principal uses involving the housing of more than three (3) families upon a
separate lot shall be permitted only after review and approval of the site
plans for such use have been recommended by the Zoning Board after a public
hearing thereon and approved by the Village Board. In its review the Zoning
Board shall seek the advice of the Village Engineer, Superintendent of the
Village Sewer and Water Department, and the Chief of the Fire Department, as
deemed appropriate. Subsequent development of the site shall comply with the
approved site plan.
   (A)   The site plan, at a scale of not less than one inch equals one hundred
feet (1" = 100'), shall show the following: existing and proposed property
lines, streets, easements and utilities; existing and proposed contours at five
foot (5') intervals or less as deemed necessary to adequately show topography;
watercourses and existing drainage facilities; wooded areas and significant
isolated trees; existing buildings and structures with an indicator of those
which will be removed and those to be retained, and including those buildings
and structures on immediately adjoining land. The site plan shall also show the
proposed development, including all buildings, structures and other
improvements with the number of dwelling units in each building shown thereon;
streets, vehicular drives and off-street parking facilities, including the
number of spaces to be provided pedestrian paths; open spaces and recreation
areas, including type of surfacing, intended use, landscaping, including size
and type of plant material; type, height and intensity of external
illumination; placement, type and screening of solid waste/garbage storage
facilities; fencing or landscape screening and buffering of the development
perimeter; size, design, placement and illumination of any signs intended to be
viewed from outside the development perimeter; location and size of all
utilities, and for storm drainage, the outfall point.
   (B)   The site plan shall be accompanied by the following: elevations or
perspectives of all buildings and improvements sufficient to convey the
developer's intent; a development schedule indicating the approximate date for
beginning construction; the stages in which the project will be built with
dates of beginning construction and completion.
   (C)   In reviewing a site plan for approval, the Zoning Board shall give due
consideration to the following:
      1.   The impact the development would have on immediately surrounding
properties.
      2.   The effect the development will have on streets giving access to the
site.
      3.   The impact on sanitary sewer and water supplies and on the ability
of existing storm sewers and surface watercourses to handle increased flows
generated by the development.
      4.   The extent to which the proposed development will meet the needs for
housing for low and moderate income residents of the Village, and up to its
proportionate share of the metropolitan area's need for adequate housing for
low and moderate income persons.
      5.   If a development is proposed to be phased, the Board shall find that
any particular phase, either of itself or taken together with phases previously
completed, meets all of the yard, open space and parking requirements of this
Chapter.  (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
CHAPTER 18
FLOODPLAIN AREAS
SECTION:
10-18-1: Purpose
10-18-2: Definitions
10-18-3: Base Flood Elevation
10-18-4: Duties Of The Zoning Officer
10-18-5: Development Permit
10-18-6: Preventing Increased Flood Heights And Resulting Damages
10-18-7: Protecting Buildings
10-18-8: Subdivision Requirements
10-18-9: Public Health And Other Standards
10-18-10: Carrying Capacity And Notification
10-18-11: Variances
10-18-12: Disclaimer Of Liability
10-18-13: Penalty
10-18-14: Abrogation And Greater Restrictions
10-18-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to this Village
by the Illinois Municipal Code 1  in order to accomplish the following
purposes:
   (A)   To prevent unwise developments from increasing flood or drainage
hazards to others;
   (B)   To protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from
flood damage;
   (C)   To promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare
of the citizens from the hazards of flooding;
   (D)   To lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control, repairs to
public facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations;
   (E)   To maintain property values and a stable tax base by minimizing the
potential for creating blight areas;
   (F)   To make federally subsidized flood insurance available; and
   (G)   To preserve the natural characteristics and functions of watercourses
and floodplains in order to moderate flood and storm water impacts, improve
water quality, reduce soil erosion, protect aquatic and riparian habitat,
provide recreational opportunities, provide aesthetic benefits and enhance
community and economic development. (Ord. 1040, 8-10-2020)
 
Notes
1 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/11-30-2, 5/11-30-8 and 5/11-31-2.
10-18-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are adopted:
               The flood having a one percent (1%) probability of being equaled or exceeded in
BASE FLOOD:    any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year flood. The base
               flood elevation at any location is as defined in section
               10-18-3 of this chapter.
BASE FLOOD
ELEVATION      The elevation in relation to mean sea level of the crest of the base flood.
(BFE):
BASEMENT:      That portion of a building having its floor sub-grade (below ground level) on all
               sides.
               A walled and roofed structure, including gas or liquid storage tank that is
               principally above ground including manufactured homes, prefabricated buildings
BUILDING:      and gas or liquid storage tanks. The term also includes recreational vehicles and
               travel trailers installed on a site for more than one hundred eighty (180) days
               per year.
               Any facility which is critical to the health and welfare of the population and,
               if flooded, would create an added dimension to the disaster. Damage to these
               critical facilities can impact the delivery of vital services, can cause greater
               damage to other sectors of the community, or can put special populations at risk.
CRITICAL       Examples of critical facilities where flood protection should be required
FACILITY:      include: emergency services facilities (such as fire and police stations),
               schools, hospitals, retirement homes and senior care facilities, major roads and
               bridges, critical utility sites (telephone switching stations or electrical
               transformers), and hazardous material storage facilities (chemicals,
               petrochemicals, hazardous or toxic substances).
               Any man-made change to real estate including, but not necessarily limited to:
               (A)   Demolition, construction, reconstruction, repair, placement of a building,
               or any structural alteration to a building;
               (B)   Substantial improvement of an existing building;
               (C)   Installation of a manufactured home on a site, preparing a site for a
               manufactured home, or installing a travel trailer on a site for more than one
               hundred eighty (180) days per year;
               (D)   Installation of utilities, construction of roads, bridges, culverts or
               similar projects;
DEVELOPMENT:   (E)   Construction or erection of levees, dams, walls or fences;
               (F)   Drilling, mining, filling, dredging, grading, excavating, paving, or other
               alterations of the ground surface;
               (G)   Storage of materials including the placement of gas and liquid storage
               tanks; and
               (H)   Channel modifications or any other activity that might change the
               direction, height, or velocity of flood or surface waters.
               "Development" does not include routine maintenance of existing buildings and
               facilities, resurfacing roads, or gardening, plowing, and similar practices that
               do not involve filling, grading, or construction of levees.
               A manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities
EXISTING       for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed or
MANUFACTURED   buildings to be constructed (including, at a minimum, the installation of
HOME PARK OR   utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the
SUBDIVISION:   pouring of concrete pads) is completed before the effective date of the
               floodplain management regulations adopted by a community.

AN EXISTING    servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including
MANUFACTURED   the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site
HOME PARK OR   grading or the pouring of concrete pads).

               A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally
FLOOD:         dry land areas from the overflow, the unusual and rapid accumulation, or the
               runoff of surface waters from any source.

FREEBOARD:     of safety for uncertainties in calculations, future watershed development,

               The lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement). An unfinished

               floodplain management regulations adopted by a community.
               A vehicle which is:
RECREATIONAL   (A)   Built on a single chassis;

TRAVEL         (C)   Designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light duty truck
